HEADLINE: Forging An Olympic Legacy;
Atlanta Sees Games As a Great Sales Tool

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 31

 BODY:
In Montreal, they're still paying off Olympic i.o.u.'s that shot past $1 billion. While Barcelona pulled off one of Europe's grandest waterfront restorations and made a small operating profit, it also wound up with debts of $1.4 billion. Los Angeles made a profit, too, but gained little in jobs or other economic benefits.
Atlanta politicians and business executives are determined to do better. They are parlaying the Games into this self-promoting city's greatest corporate recruiting tool ever. Their immodest goal: grab enough new offices, factories and corporate headquarters to complete Atlanta's transformation from regional outpost to global business nexus. 
 For the Olympics, Atlanta has reupholstered its hard sell with cushy treatment, including prime Olympic tickets, tables in the best restaurants, rooms in the nicest hotels and constant cossetting from business and political leaders. Georgia's government and corporate officials have endowed hundreds of visiting executives and their spouses with privileges usually reserved for heads of state. For the triumph of the American women's gymnastics team last week, "We had better seats than President Clinton," said Susan Mills, who arranges high-tech alliances and other deals at Technology Marketing Partners in Berkeley, Calif.
Just where the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games ends and the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce begins is impossible to say: Andrew Young, the former mayor, United Nations delegate, civil rights leader and minister, is both co-chairman of the committee and chairman of the chamber.
"I'm not just interested in how much economic growth we add right now," he said Tuesday night at a reception for local and visiting executives and friends. "I'm interested in sustained 5 percent growth. It's what's required to sustain good race relations. If Yugoslavia had 5, 6, 7 percent economic growth, there would be no war in Bosnia."
For Atlanta's leaders, snatching up companies and jobs from other states and nations is all but a moral crusade. Hours before the opening ceremonies, Bernard Marcus, the chief executive of Home Depot Inc., an Olympic sponsor that is based here, joined Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia in addressing the top executives of 40 of Home Depot's largest suppliers. Over brunch in the Governor's colonnaded mansion, Mr. Marcus drove home a point that Governor Miller had only begun to make. "The Governor's message is subtle," he said. "Mine is not. If any of you need to consider a new location, this is where you should be."
Judging the results will take years, but early returns show some promise. Among the more formal efforts, Operation Legacy, organized by the state government and the Georgia Power Company, entertained 300 executives, most with their spouses, on pre-Olympic tours, with 200 more visiting during the Games. Executives from 15 companies who came before, including Komatsu, Conagra Inc., the Fisher-Price unit of Mattel Inc. and the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, have already decided to bring Georgia another 2,000 jobs. Other business and government campaigns have won pledges from investors including Prince Charles of Britain, who will give $800,000 toward a monument to international athletics.
Local business leaders concede that many of the new jobs would have come without their efforts. Atlanta has, by some counts, led the nation in employment growth for each of the last three years, partly due to the Games but also because of its enduring attractions for business.
"It's a perennial favorite," said Charles Galloway, an executive vice president of the Moran, Stahl & Boyer relocation agency. His firm reports that in Atlanta prime office space costs less than $20 a square foot and the corporate income tax is 6 percent; in New York the lease rate is $35 a square foot and the corporate tax 17.85 percent. In recent years, Atlanta has raided the New York area for the headquarters of companies and organizations like United Parcel Service and Care, the international charity group.
Few executives visiting the Olympics fault their hosts for packed subways, inflated costs and lost bus drivers. Their handlers, however, do their best to insulate them. And while the Centennial Park bombing chilled them, the visitors say it could have happened anywhere.
Thomas J. Cunningham, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, sees an economic slowdown after the Games lasting only a few months as hospitality and retailing cut back and hamburger flippers no longer command $10 an hour. Then, he predicts, the area will resume growing at least 1 percent faster than the nation.
Almost every Olympics host city has gained civic improvements. But Atlanta has gained so much that even some members of the International Olympic Committee have bristled. Los Angeles, charging corporate sponsors of the 1984 Olympics $4 million each, made do mostly with existing stadiums and arenas. Atlanta, charging sponsors $40 million each, got corporations, ticket buyers and broadcasters to pay nearly $700 million for new stadiums, parks and an Olympic village that will become college dormitories.
Let other cities wrestle with rebellious taxpayers to build new stadiums for sports teams that threaten to leave. To replace its own aging ball park, Atlanta will simply convert the Olympic stadium into a new home for the Atlanta Braves.
But the best measure of a host city's success might be long-term development and new jobs. By this standard, others have faltered. In Los Angeles, Peter V. Ueberroth finished the Olympics with a surplus of more than $200 million that financed new amateur athletic programs. But the region's economy collapsed a few years later following big cuts in military spending. And when the city exploded in riots in 1992, even Mr. Ueberroth, assigned the task of rallying corporations to the inner city, was unable to lure many jobs.
As much fun as the 1984 Games were for residents and visitors, said Larry J. Kimbell, director of the University of California at Los Angeles's business forecasting project, in economic terms "it was about the biggest nothing that's ever been."
Barcelona took the opportunity to rebuild and fortify tourism, courting tour operators long before the 1992 Games. But there, taxpayers rebelled as lingering debts raised taxes and deepened a recession.
Montreal's Olympic committee finished with a healthy operating surplus but huge cost overruns contributed to debts of about $1.5 billion including $400 million still outstanding. "What a nightmare," said John Derepentigny, controller for the agency that manages Montreal's Olympic facilities.
Atlanta's Olympic Committee still says it will break even on a $1.7 billion budget. About $1.1 billion in security costs and local improvements will leave public debts of $150 million.
Well worth it, Atlantans say.
"We are using the Olympics as a marketing tool to attract businesses to our state," Randy Cardoza, chief of the state's Department of Industry, Trade and Tourism, said. The Olympic tours his department helps organize add a day in Savannah, the North Georgia mountains or other business sites to the Altanta circuit.
Atlanta's appeals to wealthy and influential out-of-towners date back to before Gen. William T. Sherman accepted an invitation to return on more friendly terms in 1879 to the city his troops burnt 15 years before. In his book, "Atlanta Rising" (Longstreet Press) Frederick Allen writes that in 1926, Atlanta became the region's first airmail hub by inviting down an assistant postmaster general for potentate treatment, complete with a motorcade up Peachtree Street, a banquet with the mayor, governor and business leaders and a sumptuous hotel suite.
To understand how Atlanta and Georgia have played the game during the Olympics, meet Gil Ziegler, owner of Alken-Ziegler Inc., a growing automotive-parts maker in Kalkaska, Mich. He was given a pre-Olympic tour late in 1994 that allowed politicians and business leaders the chance to persuade him that taxes were reasonable, schools improving and environmental regulators as friendly to business as to birds and trees.
"You may think I'm bragging a lot about Atlanta and Georgia," he said one of his tour guides drawled. "But my daddy says it's a sorry dog that won't wag its own tail."
Mr. Ziegler went home and decided to build a new plant in Jasper, Ga., about an hour north of Atlanta, his first outside Michigan. His aides argued for a site farther north, in Kentucky or Tennessee, that would be closer to clients, but Mr. Ziegler's logic carried the day. "My name's on the building," he said, "so I usually get what I want."
Mr. Ziegler credited the Georgians for singling him out and flying him in. "You can put all you want in a brochure," he said, "but unless you see it yourself it doesn't mean anything."
With 35 employees already, his Georgia plant will grow to 100 jobs by the year's end, he said, with further expansion in Georgia a strong possibility. Mr. Ziegler has come to like the area so much that he has purchased a second house for himself on a golf course.
To thank him and encourage further expansion, he and his wife were invited back for the Games, where they stayed on the 57th floor of the Westin Peachtree Plaza and saw the Dream Team dominate the men's basketball competition. As Mr. Ziegler chatted last week at the swimming competition at the Olympic Aquatic Center, the announcer said that an American who was leading a qualifying heat in the men's 200 meter backstroke was on an Olympic record pace. "Go! Go! Go!," Mr. Ziegler said, punching into the air.
The heat ended with no record, but Mr. Ziegler's spirits remained buoyant. "For most decisions in life, you can say they're analytical," he said, "but they're really emotional."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Mariners' Maneuver: Stock Up on Left-Handers

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
If this is the way the Seattle Mariners want to play, they just better look at what happened to the Baltimore Orioles.
The Orioles kept pace with the Yankees step for step, move for move last winter in putting together what they were certain would be a strong contender for the division championship. But look at them now. While the Yankees have flourished, the Orioles have been unmasked as a contending fraud, a team full of name players but no spirit and less talent. 
 What does the Orioles' stunning failure have to do with the Mariners? On successive days this week, the Mariners traded for left-handed starting pitchers, adding Jamie Moyer on Tuesday and Terry Mulholland on Wednesday. Presumably, they wanted to bolster their rotation for possible post-season games against the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians, the two teams they played last October and two teams that have been vulnerable to left-handed starters.
In games started by right-handers this season, entering last night's games, the Yankees had a 48-26 record (.649) and the Indians 50-27 (.649). In games left-handers started against them, the Yankees have a 15-16 record (.484) and the Indians 15-15 (.500).
But Lou Piniella said those teams should not take the Mariners' moves personally.
"We didn't do it with the post-season in mind," the Seattle manager said by telephone from Milwaukee before he watched Moyer win in his first Mariners start. "We just did it to solidify our chances to get into the post-season."
But Piniella added that most of the teams the Mariners play in the final two months of the season do not have winning records in games started by left-handers. Two of those teams happen to be the Yankees, whom the Mariners play seven times, and the Indians, whom they play six times.
But just as they countered the Orioles' moves last winter, the Yankees, in one large swoop, blunted the Mariners' moves. Cecil Fielder can do that.
His presence in the middle of the lineup should make a large difference in the Yankees' success against left-handers. It also should increase the team's output of home runs, which has been among the league's lowest. "He'll help them," Piniella said. "We played Detroit over the weekend in Seattle and he hit three or four home runs. He hit our lefties and our righties."
Whatever the Mariners' motive for stocking up on left-handers, if they were to play the Yankees in October (they would in the first round of the playoffs if they won the A.L. West championship and the Texas Rangers were the wild-card team), they could start Randy Johnson (assuming he's back and healthy), Sterling Hitchcock, Mulholland and Moyer.
Then Fielder would have the opportunity to show how potent he can be. By acquiring him, the Yankees have shown how potent their economic resources continue to be. Not only did the Yankees raise their payroll (now at $55 million) because Fielder's salary is higher than the departed Ruben Sierra's, but they also gave the Tigers $1 million, the maximum amount of cash allowed in a deal.
On the same night the Yankees added Fielder, the Milwaukee Brewers traded away their No. 1 run producer, Greg Vaughn, because they didn't feel they could give him the $19.5 million or so for three years he wanted to remain with them instead of becoming a free agent after the season.
In discussing the Fielder acquisition, an official of another club talked yesterday about the advantage the Yankees have over most teams. He spoke not critically but matter of factly, with what sounded like a touch of envy attached.
"I feel the Yankees can make more mistakes than most people," the official said. "Look at their payroll and how much they spend sending guys up and down and replacing guys who are on the disabled list. They signed Tim Raines to a two-year contract and he's been out for so long. So what? They go out and get somebody else."
Offering the Brewers as a contrast, the official recalled several players they signed in years past: Ted Higuera, Ron Robinson and Franklin Stubbs. Higuera and Robinson collected most of their money on the disabled list; Stubbs was a bust. "They couldn't spend more money," he said. "They had to wait until their contracts expired before they made other moves. There's no bottom line the Yankees have to look at. Melido Perez, a $4 million pitcher, is hurt, they go out and sign Kenny Rogers for $5 million. They need to fortify their lineup against left-handers, they get Fielder."
On the other hand, the Orioles spent millions, too, in acquiring Roberto Alomar, Randy Myers, B. J. Surhoff, David Wells, Kent Mercker, Roger McDowell and Mike Devereaux, not to mention a new general manager, Pat Gillick, and a new manager, Davey Johnson. Their owner, Peter Angelos, is learning how it feels to squander millions, a feeling George Steinbrenner has experienced more often than not.
This year, finally, the Yankee spending promises to produce dividends. Consider Fielder an insurance policy that enhances the chances for those dividends.

HEADLINE: 3 Major Steel Companies Raising Prices by 3% to 5%

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Trying to move up toward the price levels that prevailed in 1994, three major steel companies announced yesterday that they would raise prices by 3 to 5 percent for steel used for such things as cars, trucks, appliances and home construction. But steel is now so small a part of the economy that the price increases, if they stick, are not expected to be inflationary.
The pricing announcements came from the USX-U.S. SteelGroup, the nation's largest steel maker; the LTV Corporation, the third largest, and the smaller AK Steel Holding Company. The increases ranged from $15 to $25 a ton, effective in most cases in late September, but for USX, partly in September and partly in January. 
 Other major steel companies, including the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the second largest, are expected to join the third attempt this year by the industry to raise steel prices. The first two, in April and July, "stuck in part," said Thomas Ferrall, a USX spokesman.
The new increases are likely to follow a similar pattern, said Walter Carter, a steel expert at DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic consulting company near Boston. "Demand for steel is strong, but no longer rising," he said, "and the pressure from imports is likely to keep pricing soft."
The increases would affect mostly spot purchases of steel. Auto makers and appliance companies, in contrast, buy steel under long-term contracts, and the contracts are already in place for the steel that will go into 1997 model cars and into appliances, including air-conditioners, which are piling up in warehouses because of an unusually cool summer.
"The percentage of air-conditioners that have been shipped and actually sold is only about 70 percent," said Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers, an economic consulting and forecasting company in St. Louis. "Normally it is 85 percent to 90 percent."
Still, the increases would play a role in the next negotiations with appliance makers and in talks with the auto industry next March for contracts to buy steel for 1998 model cars.
But even if the latest price increases are entirely successful, sheet steel prices will still be 10 percent or more below their levels in the fall of 1994, when they reached a peak for the 1990's after several major increases, and then began a decline that did not bottom out until the first quarter of this year.
Despite the price runup in 1993 and 1994, the inflation rate for the economy as a whole was only 2.7 percent in each of those years, a bit less than the annual rate today.
One major reason is that domestic steel today, selling at an average price of under $500 a ton, represents less than 1 percent of the nation's nearly $7 trillion economy, down five percentage points or so over the last 30 years.
"Cars used to sell for $3,000 and the steel in one was $300 or 10 percent of the price," said Bernard Lashinsky, director of steel consulting for AUS Consultants in Moorestown, N.J. "Now a car costs $20,000 and the steel is around $500 so you are talking 2.5 percent and the same sort of shrinkage is happening in construction and in many other products, where the added cost comes from plastic or electronic components or other nonsteel items."
The American steel industry produces about 110 million tons of steel a year, down from 118 million at the peak in 1974-1975, when the national economy was roughly 55 percent of its present size.
The price increases announced yesterday, which varied somewhat from company to company, were for hot-rolled steel, up $15 a ton to about $340; for cold-rolled steel, up $20 a ton to about $478, and coated steel, up $25 to $557 a ton.
In January, hot-rolled steel was at a low of $300 a ton, cold-rolled steel, $430, and coated-steel, $480.

HEADLINE: Growth Rose In the Spring; Easing Is Seen

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The economy boomed in the spring but it may now be easing to a more sustainable pace, according to new figures issued today. They gave a sharp lift to financial markets and touched off a daylong spate of campaign-related argument in Washington.
The Commerce Department reported that the gross domestic product, the most widely cited indicator of the nation's economic pulse, rose at a 4.2 percent annual pace during the April-June quarter, the fastest in two years. This compared with a 2 percent growth rate during the first three months of the year. There was little sign of accelerating inflation. 
 Then, at least temporarily alleviating fears that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates soon to try to rein in the economy, the managers who make buying decisions for American industry reported a broad weakening in July.
Wall Street fixed on that evidence of slackening activity, which is more recent than the report on gross domestic product, and the bond and stock markets rallied smartly. Interest rates fell across the board, while the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 65.84 points, to 5,594.75.
Another report today showing a sizable drop in the number of first-time claims for unemployment benefits last week was mostly ignored. And despite the enthusiasm in the markets over the soft purchasing managers report, sentiment could shift quickly if the July employment survey, to be issued on Friday, indicates unexpectedly rapid growth. Four of the last five monthly employment reports have spurred steep selloffs in the markets after they came in much stronger than expected.
Politicians of both parties seized on the growth figures for a back-and-forth that appeared to be a warm-up for election-season debates to come.
The White House, in an unusually energetic effort to take credit for economic success, assembled eight Cabinet and other ranking officials to stand beside President Clinton in the Rose Garden. The President proclaimed that the new figures were confirmation of what he called "the strongest economy in a generation" and cautioned against "dramatic" policy changes that could undermine budget discipline.
"This economic news shows that our strategy is working, the economy is growing, our nation is moving in the right direction," Mr. Clinton said.
Responding to a question, Mr. Clinton said a broad tax cut, like Bob Dole is expected to propose next week, would have a "very adverse" economic impact if it led to a swelling of the budget deficit.
Mr. Dole, set to become the Republican Presidential nominee, charged that the President first broke his promise of a tax cut for the middle class and now "steps forward to crow about reigning over the first recovery since World War II to leave the American worker behind."
And Senate Republicans, led by Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Connie Mack of Florida, took an hour out from the debate over welfare to join in attacking the economy's performance during the Clinton Administration. They contended that the current business expansion, which began in 1991, was the weakest in more than a century. They pointed to stagnating wages and family incomes, a slump in savings they attributed partly to the 1993 tax increase and a trade deficit they calculated as three times as large as under President George Bush.
But while the G.D.P. report, which slightly exceeded recent expectations, brought about today's debate, it was regarded by private economists as more about the past than the future. Much more important for deliberations at the Federal Reserve, whose main policy arm is scheduled to meet Aug. 20, will be the employment survey on Friday and today's purchasing managers report, which strongly suggested that manufacturing activity had started to slow.
The index from the National Association of Purchasing Management fell to 50.2 from 54.3 in June, with all the major components, especially new orders, moving down sharply. Employment fell as well. And the rate at which suppliers fill orders -- a gauge closely watched at the Federal Reserve to see if bottlenecks are emerging that could lead to inflation -- also speeded up significantly.
The Commerce Department's tally of the national output showed the second-quarter surge reflecting gains in all major components except trade and spending on nonresidential structures.
"The economy was certainly on the move," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.
Consumers were particularly vigorous, lifting personal consumption to a 3.7 percent pace after an already brisk 3.5 percent for the first quarter, the report showed. Spending on cars and other long-lived goods climbed at a 14.1 percent pace, though much of this unsustainable strength reflected recovery from the first-quarter strike at the General Motors Corporation.
Indeed, one department official was said to have calculated that had there been no strike, overall G.D.P. would have grown at a 3.2 percent pace in the first quarter and 3.1 percent in the second.
Inflation, gauged by the price index for gross domestic purchases, ran at a 2 percent rate in the latest quarter compared with 2.3 percent in the first part of the year when the Northeast blizzard magnified the result because Government employees were being paid when they could not work.
In current dollar terms, G.D.P. grew at a 6.1 percent pace in the spring after a rise of 4.2 percent in the winter.
Today's report included a "limited" annual revision of national income and products accounts back through the first quarter of 1993 but the changes were small. Real growth was one-tenth of a point higher in 1993 than previously calculated and no quarterly change was larger than two-tenths of a point, the amount by which the first quarter of 1996 has now been reduced.
Today's labor-market data found 292,000 new claims for unemployment insurance last week, down from 321,000 for the week ended July 20. But analysts said this erratic series was particularly suspect these days because of seasonal shutdowns in the automotive industry.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the second quarter of 1996 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Immigration Overhaul Moves Toward Vote

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
House and Senate Republicans cleared the way today for a vote on overhauling immigration law, resolving a sharpdispute over how to educate children who are illegal immigrants.
If passed, the legislation would tighten the nation's borders and clamp down on millions of illegal immigrants living and working here. 
 But critics contend that the compromise on the education provision could throw thousands of children onto the streets.
"Our goals are to do all we can to discourage the unchecked flow of illegal immigration and to encourage those illegal immigrants already here to go home," said Representative Elton Gallegly, a California Republican who championed the education provision.
The bill's best chances for passage before lawmakers take a monthlong recess are in the House, where the leaders are expected to put the legislation on a fast track for a floor vote by Friday or Saturday. But Democrats opposed to the education provision could block Senate approval.
Earlier this year, both House and Senate gave overwhelming approval to similar bills, which would nearly double -- to almost 10,000 -- the number of Border Patrol officers, stiffen penalties against document fraud and provide ways to verify that employers hire only legal workers. About 300,000 foreigners a year enter the country illegally or overstay their visas, many vanishing into the underground economy.
Reconciling the two bills hit a snag beginning in May, mainly over a provision that the House included but the Senate did not, that would allow states to deny public education to children who are illegal immigrants.
The ban is particularly popular in California, where the Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, has been a fervent supporter. The state spends $1.8 billion a year to educate more than 350,000 children who are illegal immigrants.
But school administrators and law-enforcement officers have condemned the measure, saying that by putting children out of school and onto the streets, it would jeopardize public health and safety. President Clinton has promised to veto any bill that includes the education measure. Several prominent Republicans including former President George Bush and Gen. Colin L. Powell oppose the measure.
The education compromise hammered out over the past several days by Senate and House Republicans, without Democrats' participation, would allow illegal immigrants now enrolled in elementary school to stay without penalty so long as they did not change school districts.
But once these children advanced to the seventh grade, local school districts could require that they pay annual tuition costs of more than $5,000 a student through the 12th grade. Opponents of this measure say that parents unable or unwilling to pay the tuition would pull these children out of class, a step that would almost certainly identify the family as deportable by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Illegal immigrant children now in grades 7 through 12 would not be affected.
The provision would take effect in the 1997-98 academic year, permitting states to deny public education to any illegal immigrant who arrived from then on.
Republican negotiators struck a final deal today after Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, insisted that the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, assess the measure's impact on children two and a half years and five years after the provision takes effect.
Senior Administration officials criticized the compromise as still leaving children out on the street. "We don't want to create a farm system for gang leaders and drug dealers to recruit from," said Rahm I. Emanuel, an aide to Mr. Clinton who follows immigration issues.
House and Senate Republican negotiators, working without bipartisan participation, as is customary in conference committees, resolved several other differences in the bill before presenting it to Democrats as a done deal.
The House had sought to make gaining asylum status more difficult for immigrants who lack valid travel documents and who say they are fleeing persecution. The House would have had a lone immigration officer determine the foreigner's fate, without a judicial review. The compromise allows immigrants a hearing before an immigration judge and a reasonable time to prepare for it.
The House wanted to require that an immigrant's sponsor earn at least 200 percent of the Federal poverty level for a household that included the sponsor's family and the immigrant, a level that would preclude nearly half of all Americans from sponsoring a foreigner. The Senate proposed 125 percent. The compromise was 140 percent if the immigrant was the sponsor's spouse or child, and 200 percent for anyone else. The current level is 100 percent.
The Senate had proposed directing the immigration service to test several mandatory pilot programs in states with many immigrants to find one that best allows employers to verify the legal status of people whom they want to hire. The House wanted to make the programs voluntary, fearing that using a national data base to verify a worker's status could lead to a national identification card. The compromise was to conduct three voluntary pilot programs.

HEADLINE: Antitrust Chief to Resign From Justice Department

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Anne K. Bingaman said today that she would resign as the Justice Department's antitrust chief, leaving behind a record of aggressive enforcement efforts and mixed results.
Mrs. Bingaman, a law professor and antitrust litigator before being appointed to her post in 1993 by President Clinton, said she was leaving for "purely personal reasons" and would return to the private sector, although she did not disclose specific plans. Mrs. Bingaman, who is 53 and married to Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, a Democrat, said she would leave her job as the Assistant Attorney General for the antitrust division by Nov. 15. 
 "I want to see my 16-year-old son before he goes to college," Mrs. Bingaman said. "I'm going to go back to work to replenish the family finances."
Clinton Administration officials gave no indication of who might replace her, although the most likely candidate, some officials said, was her principal deputy, Joel Klein.
Mrs. Bingaman "made real strides in promoting competition for the benefits of American consumers and maintaining a level playing field for American businesses," Attorney General Janet Reno said.
After 12 years of Republican administrations that brought a free-market, deregulatory approach to antitrust law, Mrs. Bingaman, who represented antitrust plaintiffs while in private practice, took a much more activist role in reviewing mergers, price-fixing allegations and other competition issues.
She cast a wide net, filing cases in far greater numbers than had her predecessors in the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
"There came a time in the mid-1980's when the strong consensus for antitrust enforcement that shaped our economy from the early part of the century got lost for a while," Mrs. Bingaman said. "I felt we needed to do important cases, to do strong work, to do it in a non-political way. I think we've done that."
Under Mrs. Bingaman, the Justice Department took an active role in the debate over the continuing deregulation of the telecommunications industry and did extensive work on the competitive implications of the changes sweeping the health care industry. She also gave the antitrust department a more international focus. For example, she developed a program to work with Canada on joint investigations.
Last month, after a two-year investigation, Mrs. Bingaman settled a civil suit with 24 securities firms that had been charged with colluding to inflate their profits from trading shares on the Nasdaq stock market.
Among the other high-profile cases she led was an investigation of the Microsoft Corporation's dominance of the software industry. The Microsoft case ended in a settlement that was widely criticized by Microsoft's competitors as too lenient.
Perhaps her biggest defeat was a criminal case she pursued against the General Electric Company for price-fixing in the industrial diamond industry. The case was quickly thrown out of court by a judge who ruled that the evidence presented by prosecutors was too weak.
Mrs. Bingaman challenged many mergers within industries, often forcing partial divestitures to insure that competition in narrow fields would not be inhibited. In June she gave conditional approval to a major consolidation of the legal publishing industry, giving the go-ahead to the Thomson Corporation's $3.4 billion acquisition of the West Publishing Company only after Thomson agreed to sell 58 of its legal publications and license some services to competitors.
Antitrust experts said that Mrs. Bingaman's activism ran headlong into sweeping changes in the national and global economies that have spurred greater competition, sometimes even as industries consolidated.
"She tried to swing the pendulum back, but I'm not sure how successful she was," said Robert Crandall, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
"She tried to be very aggressive, but found it difficult because of the mounting case law that's developed in a world of intensifying competition."
William F. Baxter, who was the Reagan Administration's antitrust chief for three years and who taught antitrust law to Mrs. Bingaman when she was a student at Stanford Law School, said Mrs. Bingaman had done a "very credible job" for the last three years, although "she had a fair amount to learn about antitrust and that resulted in less than optimal case selection" when she first took the post.
In the end, Mr. Baxter said, Mrs. Bingaman did not fundamentally change antitrust policy from where it was when President Bush left office.
"She rattled more cages and sounded gruffer," Mr. Baxter said. "But the cases came out about the same."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Surge Broadly, With Dow Up 65.84 Points
 Stocks surged broadly, as an improving inflation outlook sent long-term interest rates to the lowest level since May. 
 The Dow Jones industrials jumped 65.84 points, to 5,594.75, giving the average a three-day gain of more than 160 points. The S.& P. 500-stock index rose 10.07 points, to 650.02, and the Nasdaq composite climbed 18.26, to 1,098.85. [Page D6.]
 
Bond prices surged. The Treasury's 30-year issue climbed 115/32 to 8915/32 , pushing the yield down to 6.83 percent. [D13.]
 
House Passes Health Measure
The House overwhelmingly passed legislation to make health insurance portable from job to job and to curb exclusions based on pre-existing medical conditions. Senate passage is expected Friday, and President Clinton has promised to sign the bill. [A1.]
 
Antitrust Chief to Resign
Anne K. Bingaman said she would resign as the Justice Department's antitrust chief for "purely personal reasons" and return to the private sector. She leaves a record of aggressive enforcement efforts and mixed results. She did not disclose any specific plans but had previously been a law professor and antitrust litigator. [D2.]
 
G.M. Sales Off; Chrysler's Up
General Motors' sales fell by 2.3 percent in July from a year earlier while Chrysler reported an 18.8 percent surge, as more Americans bought its mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. [D4.]
 
Prudential Customers Cry Foul
Some former customers of Prudential Securities, almost three years after the firm admitted defrauding certain tax-shelter investors and agreed to repay them, are accusing the firm of cheating them again. The firm denies the charge. [D2.]
 
Slow Progress in Chip Talks
American and Japanese trade officials made slow progress in negotiations aimed at striking a deal on semiconductor trade, but a final agreement eluded them. [D2.]
 
Carnival and Pan Am Call Off Merger
Carnival Air Lines and Pan American World Airways called off their merger plans after disagreeing over the terms. [D6]
 
Pemex Defensive After Explosion
Executives of Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's petroleum monopoly, hoped to celebrate the company's 22 percent gain in pretax earnings, but at a news conference found themselves defending the company after an explosion at a major natural-gas complex last week. [D2.]
 
3 Steel Makers Raise Prices
Price increases of 3 to 5 percent were announced by three major steel companies, USX, LTV and AK Steel, for metal used in cars, trucks, appliances and home construction. But steel is now so small a part of the American economy that no inflationary results are seen. [D4.]
 
Time Magazine Settles Suit
Time magazine agreed to pay $262,000 in damages to a former Moscow bureau chief for The Washington Post, Dusko Doder, who it had said might have accepted money from the K.G.B., and apologized to him in High Court in London to settle a libel suit. [A8.]
 
Petersen Publishing Sought
Several publishers, including K-III Communications and Times Mirror, are said to be bidding for Petersen Publishing, whose magazines include Hot Rod and Sassy. [D16.]

HEADLINE: THE WELFARE BILL: A DEMOCRAT;
His Battle Now Lost, Moynihan Still Cries Out

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
After more than three decades of scholarly examination of American poverty and dependency, at a moment when the United States is fundamentally altering the approach to those problems that it has followed since the heady New Deal days of 1935, the gloriously garrulous Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan managed just two sentences on Wednesday.
"The President has made his decision," the New York Democrat said rather sourly about Bill Clinton. "Let us hope it is for the best." 
 These are grim times for the 67-year-old Senator, who sees his country utterly perplexed by the collapse of the family and the failure of the welfare system -- "as baffled," he said, "as England in 1880, trying to figure out why there were people standing in the streets of Manchester, jobless, and what in the world to do about it."
In Mr. Moynihan's eyes, the country is taking a wrong turn, driving off into a trackless wasteland just because the highway is full of potholes.
Not that he holds any brief for the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, which Congress and the President have now agreed to replace with a system of block grants to states, in the hope that they will find answers the Federal Government seemingly cannot. Far from it. But he doubts local government will do significantly better than national government, certainly not with less money (about $55 billion less over six years) rather than more.
"If you think things can't be worse," he said in an extended talk about the situation on Tuesday, "just you wait until there are a third of a million children in the streets. That's what you're talking about -- children on grates, because there is no money in the states and cities to care for them.
"It is a social risk that no sane person would take, and I mean that."
But lots of people have decided that it is worth taking, not least Mr. Clinton, and the Senator puts much of the blame on liberals, not conservatives.
"For years," Mr. Moynihan said, "whenever the critics said, correctly, that the welfare system was doing more harm than good, and suggested that it be rethought, its defenders screamed 'racism' and 'slavefare.' They did that until there was no public support left at all. Now they are stunned at what they're getting."
Mr. Moynihan has never been one to observe the partisan or ideological niceties. He worked in the Nixon Administration. He called for a period of "benign neglect" for racial issues at a time when oratory was hot. He questioned Mr. Clinton on health care. And today, on the Senate floor, he said things that few other Democrats and few other liberals would dare say.
Conservative social scientists argue against nostrums for changing society, he said, on the ground that no one knows enough. He cited James Q. Wilson of U.C.L.A., John DiIulio of Princeton and William Bennett, the Republican politician, among others, as having warned against the unforeseeable consequences of the new welfare plan. Some effects, he said, "will surely be loathsome."
"Typically liberals think otherwise, to the extent that liberals can be said to think at all," Mr. Moynihan told his colleagues. "The current batch in the White House, now busily assuring us that they were against this all along, are simply lying, albeit they probably don't know when they are lying. They have only the flimsiest grasp of social reality."
A Roman Catholic, Mr. Moynihan praised the nation's Catholic bishops for opposing the measure.
"They admittedly have an easier task with matters of this sort," he said. "When principles are at issue, they simply look them up. Too many liberals, alas, simply make them up."
He was not much less scalding in talking privately earlier in the week, especially about the other Democratic senators. He observed sarcastically that the only one up for re-election this fall, Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, voted against the bill. Liberals like John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and Tom Harkin of Iowa, he said, "hear the public-opinion polls."
"I don't want to sound apocalyptic," Mr. Moynihan said, "but the effect of this on New York could be something approaching an Apocalypse. The Mayor has been curiously passive, but he has sent me a letter estimating the new costs to New York City at about $900 million a year. The New York State Financial Control Board estimated in March that the city's revenues will grow by eight-tenths of 1 percent a year and its spending will grow by 2 percent -- without new welfare spending. Now this. It will be ruinous for us."
One of the first to warn of the consequences of illegitimacy, the Senator shares with many conservatives a sense of alarm at its increase.
"It has reached 50 percent -- half! -- of all births in New York City." he said. "In the Bronx, it is 66.5 percent, in Manhattan 54 percent. No society has ever dealt with this kind of thing. It has hit us like a cyclone, and in our confusion we are doing mad things. The premise of this legislation is that the behavior of certain adults can be changed by making the lives of their children as wretched as possible. This is a fearsome assumption.
"Almost certainly the country will not respond to the get-hold-of-yourself approach we are trying."
So is there no way out of the mess? Are his critics right in suggesting that Mr. Moynihan has given up?
"There are ways to try," he answered. "Wisconsin's plan is worth trying, and some others, but they cost more money, not less. Attending to this kind of social issue is the challenge to America in the next half-century.
"I came to this town in 1961 with the first group that thought it could solve unemployment. Nobody else thought we could do it. Well, it's happened, more or less; we have had full employment for the last five years. We can solve the welfare crisis, but it may take decades. In the meantime, our only hope is to save the children."

PUB-DATE: August 2, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 4947 words

HEADLINE: Clinton's Welfare Shift Ends Tortuous Journey

SERIES: THE CLINTON RECORD -- Sixth of seven articles: Welfare

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN and SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

 BODY:
Four years ago, candidate Bill Clinton issued a ringing promise to "end welfare as we know it," to "empower people with the education, training and child care they need" to escape the trap of dependency. As President, he proposed to increase welfare spending by $10 billion to accomplish those goals.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton stood at a lectern in the White House and said somberly that he would sign Republican welfare legislation that would cut nearly $55 billion in spending and give states vast new powers to remove people from welfare rolls. 
 The bill, he said, "has serious flaws." But, he added, "This is the best chance we will have for a long time to complete the work of ending welfare as we know it."
In endorsing the Republicans' bill, Mr. Clinton was acquiescing in the most sweeping reversal of domestic social policy since the New Deal -- and in a remarkable retreat from the vision of welfare that he had outlined in 1992. This decision marked the end of a tortuous four-year journey that, in many ways, is emblematic of the way the President has often defied the orthodoxies of his party.
Mr. Clinton had cast himself as a New Democrat with his own welfare plan, but its failure epitomized the missteps of his first two years. He decided to push his overhaul of health care above all, found himself derided as a big-spending old Democrat and wound up being unable to get either proposal passed, even in a Democratic Congress.
Then, after the Republicans gained control of Congress in the 1994 elections and began pressing their conservative social agenda, Mr. Clinton found himself increasingly tangled in a political paradox: He was seeking to take credit for a welfare revolution that he was simultaneously -- and not altogether successfully -- trying to rein in.
In Washington, Republicans and many Democrats were trying to take credit for welfare reform yesterday. But welfare reform did not really start in Washington: out in the states, it has been unfolding on Mr. Clinton's watch and with his sometimes reluctant approval, pushing the national welfare debate in directions that are tougher and arguably meaner than what he talked about in the 1992 campaign.
Long an absolute guarantee of cash benefits for the poor, welfare is already assuming a new shape, in which "recipients" are now "participants" or "clients." They visit "transitional assistance" agencies, where they sign "personal responsibility agreements" and are told to get jobs, or else.
From Boston to Austin, Tex., and Madison, Wis., to Sacramento, Calif., much of this charge is clearly being led by the states themselves, often by Republican governors, and many of those leaders insist that the White House has been too slow and insufficiently bold in confronting welfare reform. And in state after state, the idea of extensive job and skills training has been replaced by a blunter policy that can best be summed up this way: get a job, any job.
Moreover, many states have sought the authority to cut people off of welfare after two years even if they have not been able to find or keep a job, an approach that Mr. Clinton once resisted but is now encapsulated in the Republicans' bill.
The deep divisions in his Administration over how to reform welfare -- indeed, the shifts in Mr. Clinton's own mind -- have been evident in the tortuous negotiations with Congress over the welfare overhaul as well as in the waivers his Administration has granted to more than three dozen states to try new work-focused approaches to welfare.
Some of his allies on his original welfare proposal argue that President Clinton made a fundamental mistake in deciding to push for his health-care plan first. Had Mr. Clinton done welfare reform first, they say, he might have cemented his credentials as a New Democrat and even gained a foothold that might have brought him success on health care.
Perhaps he had that in mind on Wednesday when he spoke of the "duty to seize the opportunity" on welfare. Two years ago, Mr. Clinton's hopes on health care reform were dashed, in part, because he resisted negotiation on a compromise bill when an alternative measure might still have been possible.
But despite that failure, and despite his vetoes of the first two Republican bills, even some of his critics give him credit for establishing a national dialogue on welfare that put the issue on the political agenda and eventually resulted in an overhaul that was all but unimaginable during 12 years of Republican control of the White House.
"It's Nixon in China," said Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group in Washington. "If Clinton had been a Republican, the Democrats in Congress would have stopped these waivers in their tracks."
Measured statistically, the changes in the welfare system to date are small. From 1980 to 1993, when President Clinton took office, the welfare population had grown from 10.6 million to 14.1 million. It has since dipped to 12.8 million.
Federal and state spending for Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the principal welfare program, has stabilized at about $25 billion, which is equivalent to about 14 percent of Medicare spending or 9 percent of the Pentagon's budget. The Department of Health and Human Services says an average of 650,000 of 4.5 million welfare parents worked each month last year, 140,000 more than in 1992. Nonetheless, the face of welfare has changed markedly, and pressure on recipients to get a job is sweeping the system.
"The main focus here is jobs, jobs, jobs," said Mary L. Pike, a senior counselor in the Pensacola office of Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, where half of the area's welfare clients are routed into a state-mandated work program.
In view of Mr. Clinton's changing positions and of his letting the states take the initiative, many Republicans say it is absurd for him to assert that he has led the charge on welfare reform, especially after his vetoes of the two Republican bills.
"An element of political skill is to recognize a wave when you see it," said Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a state in the forefront of imposing work requirements on welfare recipients. "I don't think Bill Clinton created this wave. I think he rode it."
But, said Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, who was clearly half-hearted at best about the Republican legislation: "It's this partnership. They couldn't do it without us. We couldn't do it without them. So we are married by necessity to this transition."
In these negotiations, and in talks over the Congressional bills, Mr. Clinton also drew lines in the sand against some Republican proposals, then erased them. He had resisted pressure to give up some Federal prerogatives over basic welfare rules. Yet the new bill gives vast authority to the states to set their own rules after receiving lump grants from Washington.
At the same time, both in granting waivers and now in signing the overarching welfare overhaul, the President has begun to condone stricter criteria for letting people stay on welfare, and that means leaving more of the poor without aid.
"The critical thing is, there are really a fair number of people who are going to be cut off," said David T. Ellwood, academic dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, who was the official in charge of devising the Clinton plan until resigning a year ago.
"There's some unwillingness on both sides to confront the question of what to do about people who are generally willing to work and can't find a job."
 
The Timing
Election Politics Stall Proposal
The bell-ringing theme that Bill Clinton struck four years ago -- in urging that welfare be a means to a job -- captured a rising public indignation over the open-ended entitlement program and clearly helped to cast him as a New Democrat.
But rather than capitalize on that theme and make it one of the earliest priorities of his Administration, President Clinton instead chose to emphasize health-care reform. He suggested that pushing two sweeping proposals at the same time was too much, and that insuring affordable health care for all was a prerequisite to a meaningful change in the welfare system, anyway.
A number of experts now argue that the decision was a critical political mistake. They say Mr. Clinton should have shown his New Democrat stripes by ending the concept of welfare as an automatic, permanent entitlement before trying to tackle a health-care proposal that famously went nowhere as conservative critics painted it as a classic Old Democrat, big Government program.
By the time Mr. Clinton formally presented a proposal to Congress, in the summer of 1994, the issue had become bogged down in election-year politics and it did not even make it out of the Democratic-controlled Congress. And even Mr. Ellwood, the primary adviser on welfare reform, conceded recently in The American Prospect magazine, "We got hit by a freight train, in part, of course, because our own train moved too sluggishly."
And once the Republicans gained control of Congress in the 1994 elections, their welfare-reform bills would have cleared the way toward stricter time limits and so-called family caps that simply prevented women from collecting more benefits if they had more children, and would have included little of the money that Mr. Clinton had wanted to free up for education and training.
The Republicans sought tougher changes like cutting spending and shifting all welfare policy to the states by giving them block grants to spend as needed. To salvage some piece of his promise, Mr. Clinton hinted last fall that he might accept a compromise, but he was instantly savaged by the left.
Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, said at the time, "It is not plausible that Americans will stand by and watch hungry children starve because their mothers did not meet a two-year deadline."
So Mr. Clinton wound up twice vetoing welfare-reform bills, arguing that they were too extreme and and then getting savaged from the right.
"Bill Clinton has been a non-combatant on welfare reform," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, who is the chairman of the House Republican Conference. "He has preserved welfare as we know it."
Even as they acknowledge the 11th-hour nature of welfare reform at the national level, Clinton Administration officials insist that the President has moved ahead on several elements of his plan to raise more people out of poverty: raising the minimum wage, expanding a tax-credit for low-income workers, and stepping up ways to force parents, mostly fathers, to pay child support.
And while there have changes in the welfare system, neither Mr. Clinton nor any Congressional Republican seems to be enjoying much of an election-year bounce from the welfare issue, although that could of course change with the new national bill. A New York Times poll last month found that 19 percent of Americans agree that there has been "much welfare reform" and that 74 percent disagree.
Of people who have seen a change, only 25 percent give primary credit to the President, and 8 percent credit the Republican-controlled Congress, while 57 percent credit state governments.
 
The States
Rules Are Waived To Press Reform
With the continuing stalemate in Congress, it was behind the scenes, in negotiating with the states over waivers of Federal regulations, that President Clinton first joined the task of changing the system.
In agreements his Administration works out with the states, the President has shown more clearly than in any other way how far he is willing to go. And for the most part, Mr. Clinton was reluctant to agree to rules as tough as the states wanted to impose.
Karan Maxson, an administrator in the Illinois Public Aid Department who negotiates waivers with Washington, said, for example, that Illinois wanted to cut off a mother's welfare payment if after six months she still refused to help find her children's father so the state can pursue him for child support. Instead, Ms. Maxson said, Washington had asked that the checks be continued if the mother cooperated by offering some clues to the father's whereabouts, like a Social Security number.
Another issue is income that recipients do not divulge to case workers. "We're negotiating for a waiver to immediately eliminate assistance for not reporting earnings," Ms. Maxson said. "But the Feds have a concern. They're asking, 'What if the person is still not working?' "
An even bigger battleground is in Massachusetts, where Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican, is running for the Senate against the incumbent, John F. Kerry, a Democrat.
Last year, the Democrat-controlled Legislature passed a law reshaping the welfare system in Massachusetts. Its provisions include one restricting a family's welfare cash assistance to two years, even if the parent has not found work.
In cases of unusual hardship, said Joseph Galland, the Director of the Department of Transitional Assistance, the state would help. But Mr. Galland said the state wanted the right to decide to extend benefits, not let Washington pre-empt it, and he suggested that the state's criteria would be tougher.
"Only with a strict two-year time-limit," Mr. Galland said, "can welfare recipients break the pattern of moving on and off welfare. At some point, you have to intervene in that process and develop the sense that work is the only answer. We're saying you have to take responsibility for your life."
Negotiating the provisions of the state law consumed eight months last year and, according to Mr. Galland's log, 81 telephone conferences with Ms. Shalala's staff at Health and Human Services, 19 with the Agriculture Department, which issues Food Stamps, and 11 with the Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
The Administration approved all provisions but one -- the cut-off after two years. Gerald Whitburn, the Secretary for Health and Human Services in Massachusetts until June, when he resigned for a job in the private sector, said: "Shalala just jammed us. She just pre-empted the whole thing."
But Ms. Shalala explained her decision this way: "I think it was a pretty fundamental disagreement. And that is whether someone who played by the rules and tried desperately to find a job, whether he and his kids, or she and her kids, would be thrown out. Or whether there had to be protection."
Now, with the start of his re-election campaign, the issue of the two-year cutoff has popped up again, and the President has clearly yielded some ground. With that and his support of other stringent features of state plans, advocates of the poor have concluded that Mr. Clinton, while wanting to retain some Federal prerogatives over welfare, favors a tougher policy. That is all the more clear with his announcement on Wednesday.
"Before the Clinton Administration began granting states waivers," said Mark H. Greenberg, senior staff attorney for the Center for Law and Social Policy in Washington, "there was a recognition that efforts to expand the participation of parents in work activities had to be balanced with the need to assure a basic level of support for poor families. This principle has been abandoned in some recent waivers."
As she once understood Mr. Clinton on the issue, Heidi Hartmann, the director of the Institute of Women's Policy Research in Washington, said, "As long as a woman was poor and had minor children, the Government would create an opportunity for you to work." Now, Ms. Hartmann said, "there is a question of how much of the safety net he's willing to keep."
Yet some analysts who are more conservative read the President in much the same way. "Clinton is trying to be one half of a degree to the left of where Bob Dole is," said Mr. Besharov of the American Enterprise Institute. "He is going as far right as he has to deny Dole the issue. There's probably some line he can't cross with liberals, but they're giving him a lot of running room."
The real tests of political wills and the durability of welfare's new look are yet to come. No one knows for sure how the public will respond when time limits, now mostly a future threat, actually take effect and recipients are cut off. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, predicts that the legislation will prove to be "the most brutal act of social policy since Reconstruction." And no one knows what will happen in the economy's next recession, when tens of thousands of former welfare recipients lose their jobs.
 
The New Welfare
Jobs Get Priority Over Training
In Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign manifesto, Putting People First, he pledged to "empower people with the education, training and child care they need for up to two years so they can break the cycle of dependency." The goal, he said then, was to "make work pay" by preparing people for well-paid, high-skill jobs that would help them attain self-sufficiency.
The Clinton antidote to lifetime welfare seems to be taking hold in the machine shop of Pensacola Junior College. There, under a sign reading "L.T.A.," for lose that attitude, seven women operated engine lathes, milling machines and tool grinders. After completing a seven-month course, they will receive machinists' certificates -- tickets to factory jobs in the area that start at $12 an hour.
Of the 12 women who have enrolled in the course since it started last year, 3 finished and found good jobs and 2 dropped out.
Al Simmons, the instructor, summed up the job market for them by saying, "If you're a machinist and you're out of work, there's something wrong with you."
Sherry Huckaby, 32, working at a grinding wheel, has a daughter and receives a welfare check of $241 a month plus tuition, food stamps and Medicaid and other assistance.
"They don't give you an excuse for not making it," Ms. Huckaby said. "There's a bus pass and money for child care. There's really no excuse anymore."
Yet more and more, states are turning away from experiments like Florida's, born of Federal legislation six years ago to encourage welfare-to-work training. The prescription of training and education has collided with tight Federal and state budgets, resentment among taxpaying workers who try to get ahead without special aid, and a sense that any job, however menial, is a surer first step toward a lifetime of work.
So some welfare recipients are being pushed into short, sometimes one-day, classes in job hunting or up to two-month courses in refreshing basic skills, like reading and math. The states then send them to the job-placement case workers or the state employment service.
They make exceptions primarily for recipients who have not finished high school and whom they steer into courses leading to the equivalent of a high school diploma. Others recipients can get help with courses like those at Pensacola Junior College but only if they are also holding down a job.
LaDonna A. Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute, has studied recent changes that many states have made in their welfare programs.
"Welfare is very different today," Ms Pavetti said. "Work mandates are much stronger than they ever have been. And there's been a huge shift from job training and education to direct job placement."
The shift is particularly apparent in Indiana, which leads the nation with a 30 percent decline of welfare cases since Mr. Clinton became President. "We have shifted from education and training to work first," said Cheryl Sullivan, the Secretary for Family and Social Services in Indiana.
Like most states, Indiana is pouring money that might have paid for training into child care so parents can go to work. The Clinton Administration now urges getting a job soon, too.
"We are scared of keeping people out of the work force too long," Secretary Shalala said in an interview. "The important thing is to get people into work as quickly as possible and then sustain them in the job."
To encourage working, the states, with President Clinton's support, also punish recipients who do not show up for the crash courses and job-hunting help. In Indiana, which is typical of many states, a recipient loses her share of a welfare check for two months for the first infraction, for a year for the second and for three years for the third.
Jeannette Barlow of Indianapolis, who has a 12-year-old daughter and a 6-year-old son, said she had always worked until three or four years ago, when she began caring for her ailing mother.
Ms. Barlow, 35, said she had been collecting a welfare check of $288 a month. She has lost about $90 because her daughter moved in with her father, and then for May and June, she lost $90 and her Medicaid coverage as well, so only her son was covered.
"I guess it was about me not coming to classes," Ms. Barlow said of the second cut. Of the first, she said she felt that the state had been unfair because she still helps support her daughter, who visits on weekends.
"But the President established that they want to get people off welfare," she said. "They just want you to get a job. They don't even ask who's going to take care of your children."
By contrast, Jennifer Iverson of Salt Lake City came up against Utah's redoubled emphasis on work two years ago when her son, Chandler, was 5 months old.
"I got this caseworker," Ms. Iverson said, "and she wanted to know, like right away, 'What are your plans? What are your goals?' Her goals were to get me to go to work right away, go to school, all this stuff. I didn't want to leave the baby so early."
Today Ms. Iverson, 25, works nine hours a day four days a week as a receptionist and hygienist's assistant at a dental center and is at Salt Lake Community College two hours a day studying for a hygienist certificate while still receiving welfare benefits.
"I really felt pressured," Ms. Iverson said. But she added: "It's much better now. People need to be pushed."
 
The Jobs
Low Pay Prevents Self-Sufficiency
At a welfare office near the vast Robert Taylor Homes housing project on the South Side of Chicago, a waiting-room television monitor repeatedly plays a tape about the program that Illinois calls Work Pays. Fake dollar bills cover the walls, all with an inscription: "Earn money for your family."
Or else.
Bendetta Finley, 43, the mother of three and the grandmother of four who has been on and off welfare since 1991, gripped the paperwork that a caseworker handed her.
"I've got a sheet with 20 empty spaces on it," Miss Finley said. Each is a line to be signed by employers whom she asks for a job. Refuse to look for work, and the state will slash her welfare check.
As she waited on a hard plastic chair in the Illinois Department of Public Aid's Oakland office in Chicago, Miss Finley said she truly wanted a job.
"I have a high school diploma," she said. "I love to work. I'm not a lazy person."
Miss Finley has been a file clerk, a high-school recreation aide, a housekeeper, a food service worker and an assembly line worker in a sugar-packing plant. Most left her on welfare.
"I'm hoping for a guaranteed job," she said. "I hope it would be a good paying job from $6 to $8 an hour."
Miss Finley can look for more help than ever before. States offer many other carrots to drive people into jobs, like a year or two of free child care and even bus fare, work tools and uniforms. They let recipients keep more of their wages than they could a few years ago, when a dollar was clipped from each they earned.
Illinois, probably the most generous state in this respect, now cuts the check by $1 for every $3 three they earn until their earnings have lifted them to the point where they are earning enough to live on.
Still, Miss Finley could be disappointed. The jobs available to most welfare recipients leave them short of the goal of self-sufficiency that President Clinton set four years ago. Jobs in the inner city are scarce even when the economy thrives, and most are low-wage or part-time or both. So even people who do find jobs are still poor, often remaining eligible for public assistance.
Kathryn F. Worthen, the Oakland welfare office administrator, reports some real gains in recent months. By June this year, her case load had dropped to 6,754 households, from 7,836 households in June last year. And almost 13 percent of her cases, or 857 people, had paying jobs in June, compared with 512 and 6.5 percent a year earlier.
But all these new workers remain on welfare because of low earnings. Just 28 others found jobs with high enough wages to leave the welfare rolls in June. In addition, many new jobs evaporate as fast as they open. In June, Ms. Worthen said, 204 people started paid jobs.
"And," she said, "72 others reported that their earnings stopped." May was worse; 168 people took jobs and 80 lost them.
In a survey to which 24 of the 80 responded, Ms. Worthen said 9 reported that they were let go because the jobs were temporary or seasonal. Four quit because of child care problems, two were dismissed, and most others quit because of changes in their hours or the job left town.
Four years ago, Mr. Clinton proposed wider use of community service employment as a better-than-nothing, get-out-of-the-house alternative for work-ready people who could not find real jobs. But because the jobs pay nothing and the workers keep collecting their welfare benefits in lieu of pay, community service does nothing to reduce the Government's cost of welfare.
Nor do the jobs raise the spirits of the people who are steered into to them to meet government demands that they work.
"You're dealing with a client who's been in the system for years and years," said Geneva Seerattan, a job counselor in a branch of the Massachusetts employment service that has opened to expedite job placement.
"To begin with, they have no skills. They need paid training programs, but there are not enough training programs for them. The employers are getting you for nothing. They say they don't have the money to hire them."
The clients "are frustrated," Ms. Seerattan said, adding: "We feel it. I leave here frustrated. You hurt."
Still, one occupation is flourishing in the new world of welfare. So more mothers can go to work, the Federal Government and the states are paying the fast-growing cost for day care and baby-sitting. The result is a growing corps of mothers who go to work caring for the children of other mothers who go to work.
In the Somerville welfare office, Alta Dejesos, 33, on and off welfare for more than a decade, waited to pick up a child care voucher to give the woman who cares for her 3-year-old daughter, Jesica.
The voucher has freed Ms. Dejesos to start a $9-an-hour job in March as an aide at a day care center. To qualify, she said, she took a course for five hours a day in child care and worked as a community service volunteer three to four hours a day at the day care center. "I'm really happy," she said. "It's good to be on my own."
 
The Future
Some Issues Remain, But There Is Accord
Even though the President and the Congress have at last reached agreement on a welfare overhaul, many contentious issues remain unresolved. For one thing, Mr. Clinton flatly stated on Wednesday that he believed that parts of the new bill were deeply flawed, and he promised to fight for revisions to those sections.
He said that the roughly $24 billion in cuts in food stamps projected by Congress over the next six years were too deep and that the limits on food stamps for unemployed workers not raising children were also too harsh.
He also said the provisions blocking legal immigrants in the country from receiving an array of social services were unfair. He said the new rules "hurt legal immigrants in America, people who work hard for their families, pay taxes, serve in our military." He described the approach as "simply a budget-saving measure, and it is not right."
And despite the new authority that would be granted the states to make their own welfare rules, such powers are far from absolute. Over the next several months and, if he is re-elected, for much longer than that, the President and his top officials will still find themselves enmeshed in negotiations with the states over welfare rules. These talks will have echoes of those over the welfare waivers.
Still, for all the disagreements on these issues, there remains an interesting area of agreement, one that vividly shows just how much the national dialogue over welfare has moved in the past few years: the language they use.
Evoking Clintonian language, for instance, Gov. John Engler of Michigan, who is a Republican, said last fall in hailing his state's welfare overhaul, "This landmark day marks the end of welfare as we know it and the beginning of a new, empowered life for aid recipients."
Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, another Republican, talking about his own plan, said, "We are marking the end of welfare as we have known it and replacing it with an approach that emphasizes self-sufficiency."
And Beverly Hardy, a supervisor in a welfare office in Utah, said the President's statements on the issue were probably an important factor in her state's approval of a new work-based welfare program.
"I think he made it easier for politicians to buy off on welfare reform," Ms. Hardy said. "Given what politicians like Bill Clinton were saying nationally, everyone knew it was something that was coming."

HEADLINE: THE WELFARE BILL: A REPUBLICAN;
Kasich Tells Governors to Stop 'Bellyaching' About Measure

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Representative John R. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, today admonished governors who have complained about parts of the Republican-sponsored welfare plan "to stop bellyaching."
Mr. Kasich, an Ohio Republican, said states like New York, whose Constitution requires the government to care for the needy, should consider changing their laws. 
 In the debate leading up to the approval of the welfare bill, which ends the Federal guarantee of cash assistance to the poorest children and gives the states sweeping new powers, some state and local officials have stepped up their criticism of certain provisions in the bill. Republicans like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Pete Wilson of California were at the forefront of the criticism.
Both New York and California have large numbers of legal immigrants, and, among other things, the measure would bar benefits to non-citizens. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Wilson have complained that the provision denying welfare services to many legal immigrants was a last-minute addition by House Republicans that was prompted primarily by a desire to cut the budget.
But in a breakfast meeting with reporters today, Mr. Kasich noted that the New York Constitution's provision mandating "aid, care and support of the needy" was about as old as the Federal welfare guarantee that Republicans were now dismantling.
"That was about 60 years ago, too," he said. "It's time for folks to move. When my grandmother and grandfather came to America, they didn't come over here figuring out if they could get food stamps or not; they didn't come here to try to figure out how to get on the dole. That's just silly.
"It is not unexpected that Governors will say, 'Oh, woe is me, look how tough this is going to be.' But this bill was put together with the full knowledge and the full support of the Republican governors. I think the governors ought to just stop bellyaching because we gave them the great opportunity to participate in this and, frankly, I'm interested in them running their program and doing their job.
"Get on with it."
While President Clinton's decision to sign the welfare bill angered many liberals, it denied a major political weapon to his likely Republican opponent this fall, Bob Dole.
"It seems like no matter what happens, Clinton wins," Mr. Kasich said. "No matter what we do -- if we get something done, he wins; if we don't get something done, he wins."
But Mr. Kasich said that while the bill did not help Republicans so much among their own party members, "it scores a direct hit with the hearts and souls of Reagan Democrats, who we have been not relating to since the days of Ronald Reagan."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 6, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption with an article on Friday about welfare legislation misidentified two leading Republicans in some editions, and referred incorrectly to the focus of the gathering. In the photograph, Representative John Kasich of Ohio, not Representative William M. Thomas of California, was at far left. (Mr. Thomas was not in the picture.) Former Representative man Bob Michel of Illinois was misidentified as Mr. Kasich. The Republicans were applauding the health insurance legislation, not the welfare bill.
