HEADLINE: Trying to Take The Inner City Onto the Internet;
Power Through Cyberspace

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
The posters, a blend of cyberlingo and hip-hop-speak, beckon from phone booths in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant. They are often ripped down by day's end. But sometimes they last long enough to lure a would-be cybernaut to a new frontier.
"Brothas and Sistas," they blare. "Not tall enough for the N.B.A.? Too 'unique' to get signed to a record deal? Don't worry; there's another way to get outta the ghetto: the Internet." A phone number is given -- (212) 726-1063 -- and the name: Virtual Melanin Inc., "Representin' Bed-Stuy in Cyberspace." 
 McLean Greaves, the company's president, is a pied piper spreading this message, and he is happy if the phone rings.
"We're basically showing people that they have a voice," said Mr. Greaves, 29, who started his business, which creates Web sites for paying customers, in 1994 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. "Some kid from the Fort Greene projects could do the same thing with his friends. And we're going to show them the way to do that, through example."
Some say the information superhighway has been slow in getting to neighborhoods like Bedford-Stuyvesant, where people are often more consumed with survival than with cyberspace. But despite the barriers that poverty and a lack of computer knowledge can bring, there is a burgeoning movement, from Harlem to the South Bronx, to carry the Internet to poorer neighborhoods.
From a library computer lab in Flatbush to an Internet cafe in East Harlem to projects giving free public access to the World Wide Web, organizations, educators and entrepreneurs have a new message for the poor: there is power in cyberspace.
"It's crucial, because the Internet is a window to the world," said Georgina Falu, who is opening an Internet cafe in her East Harlem computer school and dreams of her neighborhood becoming what she calls "the Silicon Barrio." "We want to be in the mainstream. Above all, we're saying this is a revolution like the gold rush, and the Latino people have been behind in almost every aspect in terms of job opportunities and economic development. And my purpose is to give them a head start."
Sometimes, the new technology must be demystified and misperceptions erased. There are those who assume that computers are prohibitively expensive and not relevant to day-to-day living. Many of those seeking to share their knowledge of the Internet try to emphasize that with a few keystrokes, a bodega owner can tap into a marketing seminar without leaving his store; an elderly person can get medical advice without picking up a phone; an unemployed person can hunt for a job.
But the largest hurdle is access. Though many people may be eager to learn about the Internet, a significant number of homes in New York City's poorer communities do not have telephones, let alone computers. A study by the city's Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications found that in 1990, more than 1 in 5 homes in 8 of the city's 32 community districts had no telephone.
In East Harlem, more than 16 percent of the homes were without a telephone; in the community district that includes Bedford-Stuyvesant and Tompkins Park North, nearly 19 percent had none.
"One of our biggest concerns is, the world is passing a lot of poor communities by as far as computers and information," said Dennis M. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League, which plans to set up computers in each of its borough offices by October, giving the public free access to the World Wide Web and other services.
"The point is," Mr. Walcott said, "we have a responsibility as a society to make sure all of us are competing on equal footing. Whether it's education or jobs, it's important for all communities to know how to use computers in everyday life."
A group of nonprofit organizations calling itself the Linct Coalition, for Learning and Information Networks for Community Telecomputing, is working with the New York Urban League to develop a program in which computers will be given to low-income Harlem residents who complete training.
The Urban League and other organizations are trying to make access to the Internet available at community institutions, often without charge.
The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture provides free access to the Internet on four computers, and plans to hold information sessions for community groups. The Brooklyn Public Library's Flatbush branch, with a grant from the Microsoft Corporation, opened a computer lab in April that has attracted nearly 7,000 people who can explore the Internet and various software programs at no cost.
In October, the Harlem Partnership Center will begin free instruction on creating a Web page and on adding to its existing site, Harlem on the Web. And the Universal Business and Media School in East Harlem is opening its Internet cafe this month.
Unlike some of the cafes in downtown Manhattan, the East Harlem cyber-haunt will start small, with five computers. Customers can buy coffee, sandwiches and, for $5, an hour on the Internet. The goal is to ease neophytes into the new world by making the language of cyberspace relevant. Users will be immediately guided, for example, to a home page from which they can connect to information about everything from jobs to neighborhood events.
"They're going to see events in their community, special services in the community," said Dennis Vaque, the cafe's technical adviser. "Everything's going to be relevant to them."
Public access is necessary for now, said Ms. Falu, the computer school operator, but she said she believes that people will gradually become so intrigued they will find a way to go on line at home.
"What we need is for them to get comfortable with the computers," said Ms. Falu, who is host of a five-minute spot, "Today With Computers," every Friday on the Spanish-language radio station WADO-AM (1280).
"It's like the public telephone," she said. "If they need to make a call, they go outside and make it. And the same will happen with a computer. Everyone feels they need a car, right? So they get one, even if it's old. The time will come when they realize that the computer is so important they'll get the money together to get a little computer."
Mr. Greaves of Virtual Melanin agrees that familiarity nurtures curiosity. In addition to creating Web sites for clients, the company offers its own, Cafe los Negroes, a mixture of musings, poetry and pop culture from New York's ethnic underground. This summer, it is also covering the Entertainers Basketball Classic at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Park (155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard) in Harlem, cybercasting the fast breaks and celebrity sightings.
Frederick Marshall, 21, is one of those who became intrigued watching the Virtual Melanin crew tap out stories on their laptops on the sidelines. One Wednesday evening, after darting around the court with a digital camera, Mr. Marshall watched images he had photographed download into a portable computer, then flash onto a small screen.
"A lot of people don't own computers," said Mr. Marshall, a graduate of Graphic Arts High School who works for a small record company. "I don't own a computer. But when I do, I'll be on line. Because you can do anything on line."
During the Rucker tournament, the game's announcer took a few seconds away from his comic commentary to give a shout, telling the folks in the stands the company's Internet address, http:// www.losnegroes.com, and giving them a gentle nudge to check out the net. Though the games are a hotbed of posturing, with rap music blaring and "disses" flying as fast as the three-on-one breaks, seldom does a game go by without a couple of young people wandering by to check out Virtual Melanin's equipment and ask a question or two.
The Internet, Mr. Greaves said simply, is becoming hip.
"I'm hoping we can make the whole Poindexter thing cool," he said, using a slang word for nerd. "We're bringing it right to the street."

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Grate Sparks Subway Fire
A rusted Depression-era metal grate suspended above an East Side subway tunnel gave way and tumbled to the tracks, leading to electrical explosions and a fire that hampered service to much of Queens and Manhattan for nine hours and trapped dozens of riders in blinding smoke. Transit officials said the failure might point to a widespread problem with grates. The incident came less than 48 hours after a downpour flooded several stations and tunnels in Brooklyn and Queens, crippling service. [Page 21.]
 
Internet in the Inner City
There is a burgeoning movement, from Harlem to the South Bronx, to carry the Internet to poorer neighborhoods in New York City. From a library computer lab in Flatbush to an Internet cafe in East Harlem to projects giving free public access to the World Wide Web, organizations, educators and entrepreneurs have a new message for the poor: there is power in cyberspace. [21.]
 
Extra Money for Schools
After three years of steady budget cuts, more than half of the city's 32 community school districts will have slightly more money to spend this year than they did last year, according to preliminary budget figures issued by the Board of Education. The extra money for the districts, which operate the city's 848 elementary and junior high schools, comes largely as a result of personnel cutbacks at the central headquarters of the Board of Education, which Mayor Giuliani and others have long complained was filled with bureaucratic fat. [21.]
 
Ex-Head of Agency Admits Lying
To escape prosecution on a perjury charge, the former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation has admitted to lying about the improper purchase of $30,000 worth of office furniture, according to sources close to an investigation of the former head of the nonprofit agency. [23.]
 
Should Adelphi President Stay?
With Adelphi University's enrollment dropping sharply, its funds limited and its campus in turmoil, the head of a state review panel asked Adelphi's embattled president whether he can effectively continue in office. In response, the president, Peter Diamandopoulos, agreed that the controversies surrounding him must be resolved for Adelphi to move forward. But Dr. Diamandopoulos, who is 67, said he does not intend to quit. [22.]
 
Accused of Business as Usual
Seven months after its creation, the Nassau County Legislature is the focus of much debate. While its defenders say the Legislature is making a difference, its critics see it as a reincarnation of the old Nassau and its vaunted Republican Party. Some say its procedures at meetings are squelching public access, that legislators are exerting little oversight on county agencies and that they are failing to tackle Nassau's overriding problems, like high taxes and electric rates. [22.]
 
Lilco Rate Reduction Proposed
Citing "poor economic conditions on Long Island" linked to high electric costs, the staff of the State Public Service Commission proposed a 5.2 percent reduction in rates of the Long Island Lighting Company. Lilco immediately objected, saying the reduction would jeopardize service and reliability for its more than one million customers. [22.]
 
REGION
 
Piece of Cockpit Is Found
The seas calmed, the fog lifted and investigators searching the watery crash site of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 discovered a tantalizing piece of wreckage -- a section of the cockpit that they hope will lead them to other significant debris, as well as to an explanation for why the jumbo jet exploded in mid-air last month. The piece of the cockpit, described as the front window section, comes from the front third of the aircraft where the explosion is believed to have occurred and might help investigators explain what caused it. [21.]
 
At Lab, Pressure From All Sides
In laboratories at the J. Edgar Hoover Building in Washington, the scientific examination of wreckage from Flight 800 inches forward in a tense atmosphere. But the pressure from a world waiting for an explanation is not the only cause of anxiety at the lab. The lab's legendary reputation for scientific sleuthing has itself been under investigation. And some law enforcement officials say the pressure from the inquiry is contributing to an atmosphere of caution about declaring the T.W.A. crash a criminal act. [24.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Crude Weapons Seized at Jail
Hours after an inmate brawl during an outdoor basketball game, a cell-by-cell search of the New Jersey State Prison in Trenton found a substantial number of makeshift weapons. The search in the prison followed strip searches on Thursday night of 200 to 250 inmates involved in the fighting in the prison's recreation yard. In both searches, guards seized crude weapons that included spoons, pens and toothbrushes with sharpened tips. [24.]

HEADLINE: With a Stable Economy, Clinton Hopes for Credit

SERIES: THE CLINTON RECORD -- Last of seven articles: The Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
More than any other issue, the economy was Bill Clinton's ticket to the Presidency four years ago.
With the country struggling to climb out of a recession and many Americans of modest means convinced that George Bush was insensitive to their strains, Mr. Clinton campaigned as the champion of the "forgotten middle class." 
 Now the President is basing his re-election campaign on a substantially improved economy. And as the election draws close, he is trying to convince middle-class voters that he has not forgotten them.
In running for the Presidency against Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton mapped out a detailed scheme that included reducing the record budget deficit, cutting the taxes of middle-income families and, in keeping with the activist theme of his campaign, spending heavily on measures like job training, education and research that would help workers cope with the wrenching shifts of the information age. Only a month before his inauguration, at a televised conference in Little Rock, Ark., he called for "a national economic strategy" that would not only create jobs but also raise incomes, reduce inequality and restore hope.
Once in office, however, Mr. Clinton found that such contradictory promises and ambitious plans were impossible to fulfill. Time and again, he was forced into hard choices about economic policy. In almost every instance, he took the route favored by Wall Street, business executives and conventional economists, not the ones that ordinary people might have favored and that almost certainly would have been easier to defend politically.
To avoid a widening budget gap that he believed would increase interest rates and frighten the inflation-wary bondholders on Wall Street, President Clinton opted for painful deficit reduction that included higher taxes, mostly on the rich, and significant spending cuts. He scrapped plans for middle-class tax cuts and spending on "human capital," which had been advocated by his political advisers.
Working to open international markets, he allied himself with Republicans to win Congressional approval of two major free-trade pacts. This meant turning his back on the trade restrictions advocated by organized labor, one of the Democrats' strongest constituencies.
In the 1994 elections, though, many of the middle-income workers who had responded to Mr. Clinton's message in 1992 turned against the Democrats, giving the Republicans control of Congress. Mr. Clinton stopped trying to mold the economy and sought to regain his political footing by acting like a hockey goalie, deflecting Republican slapshots that would have upset Government programs popular with the middle class.
Repeatedly, even in the face of two Government shutdowns, Mr. Clinton vetoed Republican measures to cut taxes, limit social programs and emphasize business profits over environmental protection and consumer health and safety.
This hunkering down and insistence on preserving New Deal and Great Society programs like Social Security and Medicare proved to be far more popular than the more ambitious economic program of his first two years. He further enhanced his political standing by forcing the Republicans in Congress to accept an increase in the minimum wage.
But the President did not fundamentally veer from his traditional economic approach. Indeed, he adopted, at least on paper, the Republican philosophy of balancing the budget by early in the next century. So as he goes into the election, Mr. Clinton is in position to run both as a protector of the middle class and as a defender of fiscal responsibility.
Now, the critical early decisions on the Federal budget finally appear to be paying some dividends. The deficit is down sharply and the economy, by most measures, is generally healthy. But typical American workers are in no better shape than they were four years ago. Adjusted for inflation, wages are almost exactly the same as in 1992 and about 6 percent below average wages of the late 1980's.
Mr. Clinton touts his record on the economy as a strong reason why he should be re-elected. "What we have done," the President said in an interview, "is to put our economic house in order, restore growth and create opportunity."
Asked what he hoped to do in a second term, Mr. Clinton painted a glowing picture of today's economy, with its low inflation, low unemployment rate and many new jobs. But he acknowledged that many of those who "pay the taxes, raise the kids and play by the rules" had not necessarily shared in the upswing.
"There is still a lot of stagnation and insecurity in the picture," he said. "So what's missing in this picture? How are we going to give all Americans who are responsible the opportunity to succeed?"
 
The Gains
The Clinton Team Makes Its Case
"My absolute belief," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in an interview, "is that we would not have had a sustained recovery without the President's deficit-reduction program."
That is the heart of the Clinton Administration's case for its handling of the economy. But voters who hold the incumbent accountable when the economy is bad do not necessarily give the President credit when times are better.
For instance, things are going well for Jeff Siegfried, a 37-year-old manager of a Chevrolet dealership in Minneapolis. Sales of cars and sport utility vehicles are brisk. His income has climbed to roughly $80,000 in the last couple of years. "I'm comfortable now, and the economy is strong," he said. "But I don't think Clinton or his policies are the reason for that."
Even among people like Mr. Siegfried who said in a New York Times poll in June that the economy was healthy, only 36 percent said Mr. Clinton deserved credit for it.
Mr. Clinton's Republican opponents say the President has simply been lucky to hold office during a favorable stage of the business cycle. In contrast with the past, when the American economy was relatively isolated and United States policy was less subject to the hairtrigger reactions of market gunslingers, the immediate ups and downs of today's economy, most experts agree, are largely beyond the control of this or any other Administration.
Still, no one doubts that White House policy continues to play a role in determining the underlying health of the economy. Mr. Clinton's economic advisers hold that the deficit-reduction package the President tortuously pushed through Congress in 1993, a plan that included some spending cuts and one of the largest tax increases in history, convinced Wall Street that the Administration was serious about coming to grips with a deeply flawed budget he had inherited. That, the advisers maintain, helped pave the way for the easing of interest rates, rising stock prices and increasing business investment that followed.
Moreover, the White House worked hard to smooth relations with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who wields enormous influence over the day-to-day economy. When the economic pulse quickened in 1994 and 1995, the Fed raised interest rates by several notches. But the President and his advisers held their tongues, in sharp contrast with the repeated complaints about the Fed voiced by officials in the Reagan and Bush Administrations and by Democrats in Congress. This year, Mr. Clinton appointed Mr. Greenspan to a third four-year term as Fed chairman.
"The most important thing they did," said William A. Niskanen, an economist who is president of the Cato Institute, a libertarian research group, and who is a frequent critic of the Clinton Administration, "is that they didn't nag Greenspan."
The hands-off approach toward the Fed was a conscious one. "We decided early on that the financial markets could misinterpret criticism of the Fed," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a top Clinton economic policy adviser. "And the Fed itself might react in unpredictable ways."
Republicans have seized on stagnant wages and the relatively slow economic growth during much of Mr. Clinton's tenure to argue that the tax increases in the President's first budget stifled the economy.
"Clinton's high-tax, big-Government policies have sucked life out of the economy, eaten up American workers' pay and given money to the Government instead," said Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman. "Clinton's policies have created the middle-class squeeze."
Bob Dole and the economists working for him have adopted that tack and are poised to offer a broad income-tax cut as the centerpiece of the Republican candidate's economic program. But many experts, even those who often disagree with Mr. Clinton, give him fairly good marks on the economy. Wage stagnation and the widening gap in incomes, they note, began more than two decades ago and have persisted through Republican and Democratic Administrations alike.
"If you're looking for dramatic initiatives that turned America around, you're not going to find them," said Paul R. Krugman, a prominent professor at Stanford University. "But on the whole, has the policy been pretty sensible? The answer is yes."
 
Economic Pulse
Inflation Is Modest, But So Is Growth
"Our economy," Mr. Clinton declared at the outset of his State of the Union Message this year, "is the healthiest it has been in three decades."
By most measurements, the economy has indeed thrived since he entered the White House. Inflation has not been so consistently low for so long since the 1960's. More than 10 million additional jobs have been created. Yesterday, the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate in July had been 5.4 percent, down from 7.1 percent when Mr. Clinton took office. There has been no recession, and none is on the horizon. The Federal budget deficit has been cut in half. The stock market, despite some recent jitters, has broken through one ceiling after another.
The low interest rates not only generated a boom in business investment but put more money in the pockets of ordinary Americans.
In 1993 alone, six million homeowners, most of them solidly middle class, refinanced their mortgages because of the lower rates. Most of these families locked in rates two percentage points or so lower than their previous mortgages. On a standard 30-year fixed-rate mortgage of $100,000, for example, the monthly saving was $139 a month, or $1,668 a year.
"It's been a remarkable period of steady growth, low inflation and low unemployment," said Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board who is now a Wall Street investment banker.
For all those who have benefited from the advance of the economy, though, millions of Americans have not been able to take advantage of its strengths.
The pace of economic growth has been quite slow. While there are some signs of recent improvements, wages and family incomes have generally been flat. Some of the largest and most prominent companies have laid off workers by the thousands. The gap between the rich and poor has widened. And 26 million Americans, approximately 1 in 10, continue to receive food stamps, the same as when Mr. Clinton took office.
Moreover, times are changing fast, with corporate downsizing, the demise of some basic manufacturing industries, advances in communications, competition from abroad, the gyrating stock market and many other elements of a complex economy that could hardly have been imagined even a few years ago. Many people are feeling insecure, if not frightened, by what lies ahead for them and their children.
Late last year, a New York Times poll found that 49 percent of all Americans thought it was unlikely that today's youth would have a better life than their parents. In the Republican Presidential race earlier this year, Patrick J. Buchanan seized on that anxiety, and similar fears over wave after wave of corporate layoffs, to win the New Hampshire primary, briefly throwing the Dole campaign into turmoil.
Still, few blame Mr. Clinton for these anxious times, and, in more recent surveys, most of those polled say the overall economy looks healthy to them. In the recent New York Times poll, 60 percent said the economy was in good shape. By contrast, only 23 percent thought so in October 1992, an important factor in George Bush's loss of the Presidency.
 
Incomes
Many on the Sidelines In a Surging Economy
By far, the biggest winners in the last four years have been the richest Americans. A recent report by the Census Bureau, tracking the first two years of the Clinton Administration, found that the gap between the affluent and everyone else continued to widen -- even accelerating somewhat -- from 1992 through 1994.
Conventional wisdom dictates that a Democratic President who imposed higher tax rates on the wealthy would be anathema to Wall Street. But the bankers and traders in the securities industry have thrived in the Clinton years.
The stock market, measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, is up almost 75 percent since Mr. Clinton's inauguration. Employment in the securities industry has increased sharply.
The markets have been so strong since the budget law was enacted, Mr. Clinton said in the interview last month, "that nearly everyone in America who was in that higher-income group paying higher taxes has made more money out of the economy in the last four years than they paid in higher taxes."
David M. Jones, the chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a bond trading firm, is a Republican and no admirer of Mr. Clinton. But, like many others on Wall Street, he acknowledges that deficit reduction is partly responsible for strong markets.
As Wall Street has surged, the bankers and traders are spending some of their gains. Michael Hobbs, a builder in New Canaan, Conn., has certainly seen the effect. His company builds houses that typically cost $1 million to $5 million. He is doing about twice as much business as last year.
"When Wall Street does well," Mr. Hobbs said, "so do we."
But the runup in the stock market has not benefited just the rich. Forty percent of American families now own shares, often through mutual funds and retirement accounts. Since the end of 1992, the value of household stock holdings has increased by $1.6 trillion.
The other winners in today's job market are people like Shad Todd. He left Vassar College in 1993 to become a computer programmer. In September 1994, he was hired by Time Inc. to help build Internet software. Today, at 25, Mr. Todd heads a team of five programmers, and he earns more than $70,000 a year.
But for Michael Gandy, 44, an ex-Marine, a father of three and a registered Democrat in Monahans, Tex., things are much worse than they were four years ago. In 1992, after 12 years working as an oil-field equipment operator for Mobil Oil, he was laid off in one of the company's many rounds of cost-cutting.
At Mobil, Mr. Gandy made $40,000 to $60,000 annually. Today, he holds two jobs, one as a youth supervisor at a juvenile penitentiary, and the other as a security guard at department stores. He works 80 hours a week to earn $15,000 a year.
 
Taxes
Increases for Affluent And Help for the Poor
Within weeks of taking office, Mr. Clinton made the critical economic decision of his Administration, jettisoning campaign promises about tax cuts and new spending programs to concentrate on deficit reduction, including a tax increase.
Mr. Clinton's political advisers warned repeatedly of a political backlash. But the members of the President's economic team were persistent.
The President invariably sided with the economic team. In the end, the budget blueprint the President presented in 1993 included about $250 billion worth of tax increases over five years and approximately the same amount of spending cuts.
Every Republican in Congress voted against it. The final tallies were so close that if just one Democratic representative or senator who voted for the bill had switched sides, the bill would have been defeated. Never before had important legislation been adopted by such a narrow margin and without a single vote from the minority party.
Following the vote in the House, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia declared: "I believe this will lead to a recession next year. This is the Democrat machine's recession, and each one of them will be held personally accountable."
Mr. Gingrich was wrong about the recession, but right about accountability. Accused by their opponents of raising taxes, many Democrats who voted with the President lost their seats in 1994. That allowed Republicans to win control of Congress and allowed Mr. Gingrich to become Speaker of the House.
Republicans called it the biggest tax increase in history, an assertion that can be proved true or false, depending on the approach. The bulk of the new revenue came from increasing the income tax rates on the richest 1 percent of taxpayers. The maximum Federal income tax rate was raised to nearly 40 percent from 31 percent.
Low-income workers got a tax cut because of a more generous earned-income tax credit. Middle-income taxpayers had their taxes raised slightly through an increase of 4.3 cents a gallon in the gasoline tax and higher taxes on the Social Security benefits of retirees with incomes above $25,000.
 
Trade
Testing the Ties Binding Labor Allies
The North American Free Trade Agreement, the accord with Mexico and Canada that had been largely negotiated by the Bush Administration, also produced a monumental fight.
Labor leaders feared that Nafta would result in factory jobs migrating south of the border. Many vowed to abandon Mr. Clinton when he ran for re-election and to work against Democrats who backed the accord.
The overall effects of Nafta so far are hard to judge. By the end of June, the Labor Department reports, 78,000 workers had qualified for a Government program to help find new work for those who lost jobs because of the trade accord. At the same time, a deep recession in Mexico, which had nothing to do with the trade agreement, has meant that fewer jobs than the Administration anticipated have been created in industries here that do business with Mexico.
But Administration economists calculate that as many as 300,000 American jobs in export industries were saved that would otherwise have been lost because Mexico did not impose higher tariffs and other restrictions on American products, as Mexico did in 1982, the last time it had a financial crisis.
And three years after the vote on Nafta, the rift between the President and organized labor has largely dissipated. The unions were among the earliest and most generous supporters of his re-election. They are spending millions of dollars to support Democratic candidates in an advertising campaign that dovetails with the President's.
There is no mystery about why the unions warmed up to the President. After the Republicans won Congress, the unions had nowhere else to turn. "After 1994, his standing in terms of American workers became clearer because he literally became their last hope," said Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees.
Mr. Clinton burnished his standing with labor with his all-out support this year for a minimum-wage increase. In his first two years as President, Mr. Clinton did not publicly mention the minimum wage a single time.
But this year, as if he had been holding the matter in reserve for the election year, he made it his highest legislative priority. With polls showing that the public, by a margin of more than 4 to 1, supports an increase, the Republicans were forced to relent.
The House approved the legislation yesterday. The first stage of the minimum-wage increase will almost certainly go into effect on Oct. 1, five weeks before Election Day.
The Clinton Administration also worked with the Republican Congress to pass legislation that scrapped 60 years of telecommunications policy, abolished most Federal laws restricting telephone and cable television companies, and granted the states most regulatory power over the industry.
Like many of Mr. Clinton's other forays into economic policy, that generally reflected a deferral to the powerful business groups with a stake in the legislation. The focus of intense lobbying, the new telecommunications law will eventually affect the daily lives of almost every American and could prove to be a powerful job-creator in the future. But it never became a partisan political issue.
 
Second Term?
President Sticks To Limited Goals
Except for the minimum wage and the telecommunications bill, Mr. Clinton has basically played defense on economic matters in the last two years.
His veto of the Republicans' budget in 1995 -- and his refusal to blink in the face of Republican threats to force the Government to default on its debt -- led to two Government shutdowns, in late 1995 and early 1996. In the end, Mr. Clinton was forced to accept reduced spending in some areas but few permanent changes in Federal programs.
But the Republican onslaught did force Mr. Clinton to change his oratory, if not really his positions. He began 1995 with a budget that showed annual deficits of $200 billion or more through the turn of the century. By the end of 1995, he had produced a framework that he said would lead to a balanced budget by 2002.
In many ways, his outline for a balanced budget is similar to the Republicans'. Whether these budgets are realistic is another question. Their premise is that the basic expenses of running Government departments and agencies can be squeezed dry around the turn of the century. Many experts say neither the public nor future lawmakers will accept such severe austerity.
In his interview with The Times, Mr. Clinton promised that he would not ask for a tax increase in a second term if Congress adopted his balanced-budget approach. A tax increase in 1993 was an essential part of lowering the deficit then, he said, but now, "I don't see why we should have a tax increase."
But in contrast with his ambitious agenda four years ago, the President offers no comprehensive solutions this time. His "next set of initiatives," Mr. Clinton said, without making specific proposals, would pay more attention to education and measures to help families cope with the strains of working and rearing children at the same time.
Furthermore, Mr. Clinton has avoided confronting what many authorities believe is the most serious long-term fiscal problem facing the country: Soon after the baby-boomers begin to retire, in about 15 years, there will not be nearly enough money to pay for their Social Security and health care without fundamental changes in current policies or onerous taxes on younger workers.
So far, Mr. Clinton has not only resisted basic changes in Medicare, an enormously popular program, but has used his defense of the existing system to attack Republicans and bolster his own political position.
Mr. Clinton does not deny the problem. He just wants to put off dealing with the heart of it. The way to tackle it, he said, is to make small changes to keep the Medicare program solvent for another decade. That would provide time for a bipartisan commission to find solutions.
What is important, he added, stating one of the main themes meant to distinguish him from Republicans, is "to make sure that when it does, it's as fair to seniors as it is to others, and it's as fair to people on modest incomes as it is to people who aren't."
Like many other experts, Peter G. Peterson, the investment banker who was Commerce Secretary in the Nixon Administration and who has become something of a public scold on matters of fiscal responsibility, says Mr. Clinton is refusing to deal with a fundamental reality he will have to face head-on if he is re-elected to a second term that would take the nation into the 21st century.
Trying to balance the budget and maintain long-term economic stability without dealing with Medicare and Social Security, Mr. Peterson said, "is like trying to clean out your garage without removing the Winnebago."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Law Would Strengthen Beach Pollution Checks

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Thousands of times every year, stretches of American beach are closed to protect the public from disease-carrying organisms. But there are many coastal states that do not regularly monitor surf pollution, and millions of tourists may be unaware of whether it is safe to swim at any given time or place.
Now, Federal legislation has been proposed to improve the standards for checking water quality and warning people about possible dangers. Currently, the Federal Government does not monitor beach water or require the states to do so. 
 According to the Natural Resources Defense Council, an influential environmental group based in New York that does extensive research, lobbying and litigation, there were 3,522 beach closings and advisories last year at ocean, bay and Great Lakes beaches, up 50 percent from 1994.
The increase was mainly in Florida and California, states with long coastlines that had heavier rains than usual last year and thus more spills of untreated waste from storm-water drains and sewers. These overflows are the most common source of beach pollution.
Legislation introduced last month by Senator Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat of New Jersey, would require all states to meet rigorous nationwide standards that would have to be set by the Environmental Protection Agency for monitoring coastal waters and notifying the public when the water is unhealthy. For example, the standards might set limits on the frequency, duration, or concentration of pathogens in the water.
At present, states including California and Florida do much less than New Jersey, which because of its tough standards closes beaches so often that annual losses to the tourist economy approach $1 billion.
According to Mr. Lautenberg, for decades studies have shown "a definite relationship" between bacteria found in the water and illnesses among swimmers. Viruses, including intestinal infections and hepatitis, are believed to be the major cause of diseases associated with swimming, he said. And people who contract these illnesses at the beach can bring them home and spread them among family members.
In May, the Santa Monica Bay Restoration Project, a partnership of industry and state and local governments, found that people who swam near storm-water drains in the California bay were almost 50 percent more likely to experience fever, diarrhea and other ailments than those who swam farther from the pollution outlets.
"We found significant increases in risk for a broad range of health effects for people who swam in front of storm drains," said Dr. Robert W. Haile, an epidemiologist at the University of Southern California who directed the study. "These results have broad implications with regard to the health effects of swimming in waters contaminated by storm-water runoff, and underscore the need to clean up the sources of beach water pollution."
But there are great disputes over how best to control sources of the kind of runoff that eventually can pollute beaches. A House bill to revise and extend the Clean Water Act would have weakened parts of the existing law and would have done little to strengthen regulations affecting runoff, but the Senate never acted on it.
Some states already have comprehensive monitoring programs, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council. But the current recommendations from the E.P.A. are not strict enough, the group said, allowing 19 out of 1,000 people to get sick from swimming in "safe" water.
The environmental group praised New Jersey, Connecticut, Delaware, Indiana, and Illinois for having taken steps on their own. But others monitor infrequently or only in certain locations: California, Florida, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire, New York (for inadequate monitoring of its Great Lakes beaches), Ohio, Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, Texas, the Virgin Islands, Virginia and Wisconsin.
New Jersey has the most aggressive program, the council said. It includes a bacteria standard, a monitoring program and mandatory beach-closing requirements whenever the standard is violated, no matter what the source of the pollution.
But the environmental group said that such heavily visited beaches as Key West and Miami Beach in Florida, Myrtle Beach and the Outer Banks of the Carolinas, and Santa Barbara, Calif., are inadequately protected. Either there are no monitoring programs at all, the group said, or there are not adequate rules to close beaches or notify swimmers when monitoring turns up problems.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

ANNIVERSARY SAVINGS Loews Hotels is offering a 50 percent discount to Dec. 31 for guests turning 50 or marking a 50th wedding anniversary this year. The discount applies to the regular (rack) rate and not to any other programs, promotions or discounts. Guests need to notify the reservations agent that they wish to take advantage of the offer, and present proof of age or a marriage certificate at the front desk.
 
 Loews owns or operates 14 hotels and resorts in the United States, Canada and Monaco. Among them are the Regency in New York City, where the rack rates for a standard room are $220 to $285; the Loews L'Enfant Plaza in Washington ($210 to $235); the Loews Santa Monica Beach in California ($245 to $355), and the Loews Monte Carlo in Monaco ($280 to $350). Information and reservations: (800) 235-6397.
 
FALL SAILINGS Holland America Line is offering discounts of up to 45 percent on fall cruises in the Caribbean; if travelers use a Visa card to pay for the trip by Oct. 1, they can get an upgrade to the next cabin category. Five of the line's ships are participating: the Noordam, the Westerdam, the Nieuw Amsterdam, the Statendam and the Ryndam; sailings on the Veendam are excluded. Departures are from Tampa, Fort Lauderdale and New Orleans from late October to early or mid-December.
 
 Discounted fares begin at $598 a person for seven days and $1,218 a person for 10 days, based on two people sharing a cabin. Air fare is additional. Information: (800) 426-0327.
 
SWISS PACKAGES Swissair has an Air and Land Best Buys package starting at $1,012 a person that includes round-trip economy flights from New York to Zurich or Geneva, six nights at three- or four-star hotels, Continental or buffet breakfast, a week's car rental with unlimited mileage, local taxes and service charges. The $1,012 price is for travel on Monday to Thursday from Sept. 15 to Oct. 31; the lowest price is $1,272 until then.
 
 Travelers receive vouchers for their hotel stay and may choose from some 50 hotels throughout the country. The package must be purchased two weeks before departure. The air fare portion of the package is nonrefundable. Information or reservations through the tour operator, Swisspak: (800) 688-7947.
 
THAI SPA From now until Oct. 31, rates are reduced at the Banyan Tree Phuket spa on Phuket Island in southern Thailand from $290 to $180 for a garden villa and from $520 to $320 for a pool villa. (One caveat: This time of year can be very rainy in southern Thailand.) The spa has 98 villas built in traditional Thai style, an 18-hole golf course, a lap pool and free-form pool, three tennis courts, squash courts, sailing, wind surfing, canoeing and a gymnasium. There are also several restaurants.
 
 The rate covers only the room; spa services and facilities are additional. A Swedish massage is about $45; a manicure or pedicure, $10. Prices do not include a 10 percent service charge and 7 percent tax. For information or reservations: Heston Associates, (212) 732-4747; fax (212) 587-1580. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Prince Edward Island Idyll

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
IN early June, I sat in a field of daisies on the north side of Prince Edward Island, looking way below to the village of French River, cupped in rounded hills and almost perfectly reflected in a glistening finger of New London Bay. Nothing moved or marred the lovely picture, which deserved the legend "All's right with the world."
 With just a few exceptions (around the towns of Summerside, Cavendish and Charlottetown), every vista on the island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence could be captioned the same way. Fields, barns and homesteads -- quaint without artifice and fastidiously kept -- blanket the island from tip to tip, giving it the sobriquet "the million-acre farm." Its seacoasts are spliced by still tidal rivers, walled by red cliffs carpeted in grass to the very edge, or lined by deserts of dunes yielding to beaches scattered with shells and seaweed bouquets.
 Prince Edward Island has tourist attractions, to be sure -- small-scale fun parks for kids, craft shops, drive-in movies and a handful of sites connected with the beloved children's novel "Anne of Green Gables," by Lucy Maud Montgomery, which is set on the island. But the wisest visitors come for the countryside, on display at the shoulders of three major scenic routes (Lady Slipper Drive in the west, Kings Byway in the east, and Blue Heron Drive in between); a tracery of narrow, patched country lanes with long pleasurable curves; and even smaller, well-graded red dirt roads that strike out freely through the woods and over the fields. Driving these means noodling aimlessly, getting lost repeatedly, and finding your way home hours later than you planned, no less happy for the delay.
 Back at my desk in New York, I'd plotted a driving tour of the island on an excellent, free map sent to me by Prince Edward Island Visitor Services. It took me over the Northumberland Strait from Cape Tormentine on the coast of New Brunswick aboard a Marine Atlantic ferry ($21 for a car and one passenger), and then about 15 miles northwest to an inn in the leafy town of Summerside called the Silver Fox (where a single cost $54, including breakfast). From there I would roam in an easterly direction to Kings County and Lady Catherine's B & B (with a single for $30, including breakfast), about three miles outside Murray Harbour North, a favored basking place for seals. Then I'd meander toward Prince Edward Island National Park, stretching along the gulf side of the island for some 25 miles, where I reserved a cottage for two nights (at $43 each). And on my last night I'd bed down at another B & B, called the Doctor's Inn (with a single for $34, including breakfast), in the village of Tyne Valley, not far from Mal peque Bay, which has given its name to a variety of oyster I adore.
 Of course, I had to get to the eastern seaboard of Canada somehow. This proved to be no mean feat, partly because I wanted to stop in Quebec City first. Air Canada suggested a New York-Montreal-Quebec City, Quebec City-Montreal-Halifax-P.E.I. routing on the way out, and a P.E.I.-Halifax-Montreal-New York return for $540. Fatigued and impoverished by the very thought of it, I declined. Instead, I bought a round-trip ticket from Newark to Quebec City on a subsidiary of Air Canada called Air Alliance for $208, and booked an economy class rental car from Tilden Interrent at the Quebec City airport for $205 a week with unlimited miles.
 I was glad for those unlimited miles, because it's a 575-mile trip from Quebec City to Prince Edward Island, across New Brunswick's long tracts of dark forest bordered by "Attention Moose" signs. Along the way I stayed overnight in Dalhousie (where Lucy Maud Montgomery once taught school), in a Best Western motel right above a huge paper mill on Chaleur Bay; and then I got lost on the Acadian Coast of New Brunswick, among rivers with names like Bouctouche, Restigouche and Miramichi.
 Still, I reached Cape Tormentine in time to catch a 5 P.M. ferry, which made the crossing in 45 minutes. For me there is something thrilling about going to an island on a car ferry. But this trip was tinged with poignancy, too, because way to the west I could see the controversial Northumberland Strait Bridge under construction, with sections of road perched over the water, petering out to pylons, like an unfinished sentence trailed by an ellipsis. When completed next spring, this 17-mile link to the mainland will make the ferries obsolete. Some claim that it will also change the island's rural face and scare away the strait's lobsters. On the other hand, an islander I spoke with (who'd greeted me with a "Top of the morning to you") said that the crustaceans would soon come to cleave to the bridge's pilings.
 With the bridge almost half finished, I felt as if I'd arrived on the island at a special time. It was early in the tourist season -- the popular "Anne of Green Gables" musical (which runs all summer long at the Confederation Center of the Arts in Charlottetown) hadn't opened yet, there were no ranger-led activities scheduled in P.E.I. National Park, it was still too nippy to swim, and few cars were parked at the mom-and-pop motels lining the eastern approach to Summerside, on Route 11. But as I drove along, I quickly learned that spring has its own charms here -- above all, lupines in several shades of purple, sown in profusion by the breeze.
 A wild thunderstorm awaited me in Summerside, which I watched from the screened-in upstairs porch at the Silver Fox Inn, a pale gray house with twin gables. My small room in the rear had a white iron double bed, private bath, handsome Victorian bureau, and a window overlooking a picket fence. The house was built by a lawyer in 1892, but a silver fox breeder named Wilfred Leckey owned it in the early part of this century, when fox ranching became extremely lucrative on the island, with single pelts selling for as much as $20,000 and rich breeders erecting showplace houses in the pretty residential section of Summerside, back from the port.
 I dined that night in a booth at the Tearoom of the International Fox Museum and Hall of Fame, where a plate of chicken and shrimp satay, a glass of white wine and strawberry shortcake for dessert cost about $15. Afterward I explored the museum, full of cages, soft fox pelts and photos of the big-eyed creatures.
 A run the next morning through Summerside's slightly weary-looking downtown and unatmospheric waterfront persuaded me to make an early start -- in spite of the American woman at breakfast in the Silver Fox Inn who told me that she and her husband had discovered a new concept in vacationing during their weeklong stay on the island. "It's called relaxing," she said. "We sit in one place for long periods of time, just looking at the beautiful scenery."
 For the next four days I, too, sat in one spot -- behind the wheel of my rented car, watching one beautiful scene morph into the next. On my way to Murray Harbour North, I touched down in the provincial capital of Charlottetown, built by the British, who won the island from the French in the 1700's, just long enough to take the air in Victoria Park. But then it was on to Orwell Corner Historic Village (admission $2.25), a restored rural hamlet settled by Scottish and Irish families about 20 miles east of Charlottetown; the stalwart 60-foot lighthouse at lonely Point Prim; the beach at Panmure Island Provincial Park on the island's west coast, where I spotted a live starfish; and Terrace Heights, a waterside restaurant in Murray River for a fried clam dinner that cost $8.
 THAT night I fell asleep beneath a pink quilt in a small room at Lady Catherine's B & B, with a shared bathroom across the hall, slanted ceilings and a rocker. The pale yellow Victorian farmhouse with plenty of gingerbread and a porch swing is set so high on a hill that on a clear day you can see all the way across the strait to Nova Scotia.
 I did more shunpiking the next day, stopping at the Cardigan Craft Shop in the village of Cardigan just north of Montague to buy a hand-knit beret for $7.60; lunching on a juicy fried scallop sandwich at the Blue Fin Restaurant in Souris (for $4.20); sliding down the dunes that guard Greenwich Beach on the north side of St. Peters Bay; touring luxurious rooms in Dalvay-by-the-Sea, a grand hotel at the east edge of P.E.I. National Park built as a summer house in 1896. And still I pulled alongside unit No. 2 at Gulf View Cottages about a mile west of North Rustico well before sunset.
 There, 16 identical white cottages line the top of a hill overlooking the Gulf of St. Lawrence like a military regiment, with a barn and pastures behind them. If Marilla Cuthbert, the no-nonsense farm woman who adopts a freckle-faced orphan in "Anne of Green Gables," had decided to get into the lodging business, this is precisely the sort of cottage enclave she'd have built. My extremely serviceable unit had a deck with a picnic table and grill, sound pine-paneled walls, two simply furnished bedrooms (sleeping a total of six), a sparkling clean bath, a comfortable living room with a television set and the best-equipped kitchen I've ever seen in a rental cottage. The only concession to esthetics, however, was the view out the picture window -- of Rustico Beach and the village of North Rustico Harbor, with its own lobster fleet.
 I'd had lobsters on my mind ever since I arrived on the island, and finally ordered one at the Fisherman's Wharf Restaurant in North Rustico, which occupies a huge barn of a building with seating for 500 and a 60-foot salad bar serving (among many other things) all the boiled Island Blue mussels you can eat; the $18 supper also included clam chowder, dessert and a beverage, but I still had room for the bright red main event -- weighing in at a pound and deliciously fresh.
 The next day I toured one "Green Gables" site after another, starting with the prim Victorian post office in Cavendish where Lucy Maud Montgomery presided as postmistress. In the Green Gables House (also in Cavendish, admission $1.90) I saw the author's antique Empire typewriter; and in her New London birthplace (admission $1.50), her ivory silk wedding dress -- not to mention phalanxes of Anne Shirley dolls sold in gift shops nearby. None of this turned me into an Anne fan, I fear, but I came to respect the writer's kind heart and abiding love of nature.
 On my way to Tyne Valley the next day, I slurped down a dozen Malpeque oysters at Cabot's Reach Restaurant near the village of Malpeque (for about 75 cents each), and breezed through three idiosyncratic little museums, stopping first in Miscouche at the Acadian Museum (admission $2), which had instructive exhibits on the island's French heritage. French Acadian settlers began arriving on the island from the Bay of Fundy area around 1720, only to be deported when the French Fortress of Louisbourg on Cape Breton Island fell to the British in 1758; 2,000 of them were shipped to France, though some slowly trickled back. I saw boat models, rusty anchors and seamen's knots at the Green Park Shipbuilding Museum (admission $1.90), and learned, at the Potato Museum in O'Leary, that a plain baked spud has just 100 calories.
 At the end of the day, I pulled in wearily at the Doctor's Inn, built in the 1860's on a shady street in little Tyne Valley. My room, on the second floor, had a soft double bed and a lilac bush outside the window. There was a Victorian style tub in the shared bathroom down the hall and a yellow school bus parked by the large kitchen garden out back. Most of my dinner (which cost $19) -- cooked on a wood-burning stove and served by candlelight in the homey dining room -- came from there. It started with a spinach salad, followed by broiled scallops in a bed of asparagus, carrots and beet greens, and ended with coffee and rhubarb cream pie. By this time I'd been in Canada for about 10 days, and this was the best meal I'd had; in fact it was the best meal I've had in ages.
 Afterward, I collapsed into an armchair on the upstairs landing, with a glass of white wine left over from dinner. Happily, I'd already finished "Anne of Green Gables," and could at last crack open a murder mystery.
 
The bottom line
 
Getting There
 I spent an average of $80 a day while on Prince Edward Island, with $43 of that going toward accommodations. In five days on the island, I drove a total of about 500 miles. It's a 575-mile trip to Prince Edward Island from Quebec City. In all, I spent about $86 on gas.
 I bought a round-trip ticket on Air Alliance, a subsidiary of Air Canada, (800) 776-3000, from Newark to Quebec City for $159, and then drove to the Cape Tormentine Ferry in New Brunswick in an economy class car from Tilden Interrent, (800) 227-7368. This not only got me to Prince Edward Island but saved me from having to rent a car once there. However, those who prefer not to stop in Quebec City should call Air Canada, (800) 776-3000, which has flights from Newark to Halifax, where you can make a connection to Charlottetown on Prince Edward Island. When I contacted the airline in early June, the lowest round-trip fare from Newark to Charlottetown was $344, nonrefundable, with a Saturday night stayover.
 For information about Marine Atlantic Ferries, call (800) 341-7981; the company also runs ferry service from Maine to Nova Scotia, as does Scotia Prince, (800) 341-7540. N.F.L. Ferries, (902) 566-3838, operates ferry service from Caribou, Nova Scotia, to Wood Island on the southeast coast of Prince Edward Island. And for information about the Northumberland Strait Bridge, scheduled to open in May 1997, call (902) 437-7273. To reach Prince Edward Island Visitor Services, call (800) 463-4734.
 Prices are calculated at $1.31 Canadian to the U.S. dollar.
Where to Stay
 Silver Fox Inn, 61 Granville Street, Summerside, (902) 436-4033 or (800) 565-4033, has six rooms with private baths priced at $50 to $60 (including a Continental breakfast).
 Lady Catherine's B & B on the Kings Byway Scenic Drive (Highway 17) in Murray Harbor North, (902) 962-3426 or (800) 661-3426, has four comfortable bedrooms sharing two baths, ranging in price from $34 to $38, double occupancy (including breakfast) in the summertime.
 Gulf View Cottages, North Rustico, (902) 963-2052, has a children's playground, laundry, and 16 cottages with two bedrooms each, kitchens, grills, and private baths, priced at $70, double occupancy, from June 22 to Labor Day.
 The Doctor's Inn, Tyne Valley, (902) 831-3057, has two guest rooms with shared bath, for $42, double occupancy (including breakfast); dinner, by reservation only, costs $19 a person, including wine.
Where to Eat
 The Fox Tea Room at the Fox Museum and Hall of Fame, (902) 436-6707, is at 286 Fitzroy Street in Summerside; Terrace Heights, (902) 962-2465, is in Murray River, in Kings County; the Blue Fin Restaurant, (902) 687-3271, is at 10 Federal Avenue in Souris; Fisherman's Wharf Lobster Suppers, (902) 963-2669, can be found at the crossroads in North Rustico; Cabot's Reach Restaurant, (902) 836-5597, is west of Malpeque on Route 135. And I can recommend yet another lobster supper -- at St. Ann's Church, (902) 621-0635, just west of Stanley Bridge on the north side of the island.

HEADLINE: The View From: Village Creek, South Norwalk;
Keeping a Postwar Dream Alive

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
NO gatehouse or stone pillars mark the entrance, just a plain wooden sign announcing Village Creek. Three roads wind through the residential community in South Norwalk, shady streets with views of salt marshes and Long Island Sound, leading to houses all but hidden by ancient trees. A visitor notes the way the homes nestle into the land, the spare but elegant architecture recalling the 1950's, the added wings and porches that speak of growing families and changing needs.
It was indeed during the early 50's that Village Creek took shape, the dream of a small group of young couples -- the men all veterans of World War II and all of them ardent sailors -- seeking a peaceful place to raise a family. 
 Discouraged by the high price of shorefront houses, they decided, in the fall of 1948, to pool their resources, purchase a large parcel of land and subdivide it. They looked at sites from New York to New Haven and settled on 71 acres surrounded on three sides by water and salt meadows, a wooded, uninhabited peninsula belonging to the former Nash Engineering Company, which was eager to sell. They they rounded up friends, and friends of friends: a total of 30 families at first, each willing to put down cash, which was matched by the father of one of the young men -- a total of $75,000.
They were artists and architects, doctors, lawyers, educators. By November 1949, when the first meeting of the Village Creek Homeowners Association was held, 46 lots averaging one-third of an acre had been sold. Records show that the first road was almost completed and ready to be turned over to the City of Norwalk and that $3,000 was appropriated for improving the beach. The waterfront was, and remains, one of the community's major attractions, with every homeowner guaranteed the right to moor a boat.
"Those of us who started Village Creek had a special kind of a community in mind," reads the prospectus published in 1951. "We were looking for a good place in which to live and bring up our children, a community which would be in itself a model of democracy. We wanted a healthful place to live, waterfront, view . . . but above all else we wanted a community with a completely democratic character -- no discrimination because of race, color, creed or politics."
What they developed, explained Roger Willcox, one of the community's principal organizers, was a cooperative, integrated community that offended many at that time.
For 10 years, no real estate broker would show a Village Creek house to a white family, but the residents organized a committee that saw to it that homes were sold by word of mouth.
"Now, the integration factor is no longer unusual," said Mr. Willcox on a recent day, as he sat on his porch overlooking boats at their moorings and the Norwalk islands in the distance, "it's the harbor that is unusual. Now we are attracting families with boats and most of them are white. We make a constant effort to maintain the racial integrity of the community."
Such efforts sometimes lead to unusual situations, like the time during the 1960's when the Village Creek Homeowners Association tried to dissuade a prominent black couple from buying a house in a corner of the community where numerous black families already lived.
"We didn't want a ghetto within an integrated community," Mr. Willcox related. "The prospective buyers were offered several other properties that were available, but they insisted on that very one and brought charges against the association."
The ensuing legal maneuvers -- with the local N.A.A.C.P. weighing in on the side of Village Creek -- made the headlines as a rare case of reverse discrimination and consumed more than a year. During that time, several other homes changed hands, making the racial balance more equitable in the disputed area. The homeowners association eased its stance, the family bought the home they loved and they still live there.
A half-century after its founding, the racial balance remains much as it was in the beginning, with one-third of the community composed of nonwhite families, Asian as well as black and interracial.
Other controversies, unrelated to race, have dogged Village Creek over the years, including a six-year fight -- joined by residents of neighboring communities -- against Connecticut Light and Power over the plant they planned to build on Manresa Island. The power plant was eventually built -- its two blue buildings can be seen from many sites in Village Creek -- but the opposition was able to get pollution controls that were unheard-of in the 1960's.
In recent months, the combat has concerned a rock-crushing operation that a contractor wanted to install on Wilson Avenue, within sight and hearing of Village Creek Homes.
During a leisurely stroll through the community, the president of the homeowners association, Hu Lindsay, pointed across a scenic wetland to the site of a gravel operation, where the controversial machine was to be moved to crush used concrete and asphalt for later sale and re-use.
Opponents feared that dust, loud noise and additional truck traffic would degrade the quality of life for everyone, risking pollution of the surrounding salt marshes and marine life.
The fight was joined by neighbors from an extended area, Mr. Lindsay explained. Both sides had employed lawyers as well as experts in acoustics, traffic, pollution control and environmental matters and dozens of residents had spoken out at meetings of the Norwalk Planning and Zoning Commission.
"Village Creek has had a number of big battles," Mr. Willcox commented at the time. "And it did not come out second-best."
Last week, the Planning and Zoning Commission voted 4 to 2 to deny the application for the crushing machine and the community was able to return to its routine.
For all the controversies, present and past, Village Creek has remained a remarkably peaceful, stable community. The covenants that were established at the start are still in force. The three-person Architectural Control Committee remains the arbiter of all exterior changes, and any tree that stands four feet above ground cannot be cut down without permission. Residents volunteer to do common chores like painting the lifeguard stand and picnic tables every spring, and parties at Christmastime and the Fourth of July bring forth the best talents of neighborhood cooks.
Half the houses are still owned by the original 64 families or by their descendants, and in many cases the sons and daughters of founders have bought homes for themselves in the community.
"During the 1980's we thought we might be turning into an old folks' home," said Mr. Lindsay, "but suddenly, younger people started to move in. Now the age of our population runs from 4 months to 96 years."
A compelling picture of life in Village Creek is evoked by a group of letters from people who grew up there -- recollections published in 1985 on the occasion of the community's 35th anniversary.
Sailing is mentioned many times, as are swimming, caroling and "calling everyone by their first name." "The kindness of so many neighbors" is recalled, the feeling of "an extended family," the fact that "the adults were doing such interesting things, were such special people."
"I never had time to develop racial, cultural or economic prejudices," concludes one former resident. "I was too busy smiling and enjoying other people."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Why Cities Set Their Sights So High

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger 

 BODY:
THE WORLD'S TALLEST building is nearing completion in -- Kuala Lumpur? What kind of place is that for the highest skyscraper? Not that it will much matter, since an even taller tower is already under construction in Shanghai. And after that, who knows? Bangkok? Singapore? Taipei?
It's a long way from New York and Chicago, where most of the world's tallest buildings have been for almost all of the 20th century. Now these American cities lie quiet, not entirely devoid of new construction but almost so, and emphatically uninterested in building tall just for the sake of building tall. The mantle of Tall, Taller, Tallest has passed to the other side of the world. And if I can stake one claim for certain, it is that it will never return to this continent.
The reason for this is simple and tells a lot about the symbolic power the skyscraper continues to possess, even as it moves toward its second century. Buildings that are very tall -- buildings that are not merely high but awesomely high, buildings that grab statistics like "world's tallest" or "world's second tallest" -- are the product, by and large, of cultures that are in the first flush of excitement at moving onto the world stage. Such buildings are assertions of power, demands to be noticed, and there is a particular moment in the life cycle of a rising culture when those impulses are irresistible.
The moment comes after beginnings and before maturity. When a nation is relatively young and limited in its resources, it's obvious that the notion of putting up any kind of skyscraper, let alone of aspiring to build something that will knock a rival off its pedestal, is unthinkable. It's no accident that there were few tall building in Asia until recently, for while the cultures of Asia were ancient in one sense, they were relatively young so far as their position in the world economy was concerned, and they had other priorities than building to make themselves noticed.
But now, as the global economy shifts more and more toward the Pacific Rim, these countries hold a commanding position. They not only have money; they want to spend it in a way that will demonstrate their economic vigor.
How like New York and Chicago around the turn of the last century this is! The muscle-flexing represented by the Woolworth Building in New York, which at 792 feet was the world's tallest from 1913 to 1930, is not so different from what the people shaping Kuala Lumpur or Shanghai are after today. (Official rankings are kept by the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat at Lehigh University, by whose accounting the Woolworth has now fallen to No. 65 on the list of the tallest 100 in the world.)
When the Woolworth was new, there was a fresh, tough, bravado to it all. Make it bigger, bolder. Make it show the world that we are in charge, that we have arrived. Never mind that Benjamin Harrison was President in 1890, when Joseph Pulitzer built the World Building in Lower Manhattan, which at that time was the world's tallest; the spirit of the American skyscraper was the spirit of Teddy Roosevelt. (Not to mention of Pulitzer himself, who was determined to use great height as a means of showing off the might of his newspaper, The New York World.)
And on it went, from the Metropolitan Life Tower of 1909 (700 feet) to Woolworth -- a monument to the might of American business if ever there was one -- to the Chrysler Building (1,046 feet) and the Empire State Building (1,250 feet) in the early 1930's. And then on further, all the way to the twin towers of the World Trade Center (1,368 and 1,362 feet, respectively) in New York and the slightly taller Sears Tower in Chicago, which at 1,450 feet wrote the final chapter in the saga of American supremacy of height in the early 1970's.
NOW, SUCH BRAVADO belongs to the East, and I am not sure it is an entirely bad thing. No one in New York has talked about putting up the world's tallest building in more than a generation, except for Donald Trump, and in an odd way, his preoccupation with it during the 1980's merely proves the point that striving for great height is a sign of an arriviste culture, not of a mature one.
New York and Chicago had more or less lost interest by the 1980's, learning to be comfortable with their urban fabric as a totality and coming to think of this "world's tallest" business as little more than macho strutting. It took an anachronism like Mr. Trump, whose near obsession with the idea of putting up the tallest structure in the world made him resemble the swashbuckling builders of a much younger New York, to put the world's tallest building back on the agenda.
It's no accident, I think, that the skyscraper never became the obsession in Europe that it was in this country once, and has now become in Asia. True, Europe has plenty of tall buildings, and as we move toward a more global economy it will undoubtedly have more. But it has never had the world's tallest (forgetting, for the moment, the Eiffel Tower, really a spectacular work of engineering more than a building) and its urban inhabitants have never seemed to miss it.
Europe was a mature culture by the time the skyscraper became technologically possible in the late 19th century, its cities largely built up in solid patterns resistant to the large-scale intrusions that skyscrapers represented. And while Europe encouraged and celebrated engineering advances (long before the Eiffel Tower, there was the Crystal Palace and all of those extraordinary railroad bridges) its architects and builders did not seem to feel the need to express their supremacy by erecting buildings of great height. They were, by and large, confident that the urban fabric they had was sufficient.
Perhaps this was because Europe had already asserted itself in terms of building tall. The European equivalent to what the United States experienced in the late 19th and mid-20th centuries and what Asia is experiencing now, had already come in the Middle Ages, when Europe's cultures were new and strong and powerfully assertive as builders of cathedrals.
What was Beauvais Cathedral, after all, but a brazen attempt by height-obsessed French builders to erect the world's tallest tower (157 feet)? It fell down, twice, but the engineering hand was more sure elsewhere. And as a group the towers of the great cathedrals of Europe must surely be the most concerted attempt to express a powerful, unified societal vision through building tall that has ever occurred in human history.
What light does that shed on the current wave of skyscraper building in Asia? The makers of the world's tallest buildings of today are not motivated by the visions that drove the cathedral builders, of course, any more than the builders of American skyscrapers were. Yet there remains a sense of cultural pride behind their determination: each super-tall tower stands as a reminder that Asia's national economies are growing faster than any place else in the world and that Asia now holds the place in the world economy that the United States did for the last century.
Since height itself is the point, design is often secondary. It is American architects who are doing most of these new towers: Cesar Pelli in Kuala Lumpur, Kohn Pedersen Fox in Shanghai and many other American firms filling Asian cities with also-rans that are nearly as tall.
This being an age of internationalization, it's hard to see much that distinguishes these buildings, even the best of them, from what their architects might have done for a client in Dallas, Frankfurt or Johannesburg. The shapes are striking, and most of these megabuildings are not bad as works of design; continuing an obsession begun in the 1980's, there is an emphasis on giving each and every building its own, readily identifiable form. Make it a logo, not to be confused with anyone else's building.
But do Cesar Pelli's twin, rounded towers in Kuala Lumpur (1,483 feet) have anything to do with Malaysia, or with Asian cities at all? Will Kohn Pedersen Fox's even taller tower (by 26 feet), a twisted slab with a hole punched through the top, tell us anything about Shanghai?
For now, no. These buildings emerge more out of an international design language than out of anything specific to their place. But wait a bit: the same could once have been said of the Eiffel Tower, or of the Sears Tower, or even of that greatest of all symbols, the Empire State Building, which was really just a kind of generic stepped-back tower but eventually become a virtual trademark of New York. These newest skyscrapers may well do the same for their places, in time. We may not be seeing great architecture, but we are surely watching icons in the making.
