HEADLINE: Ticket Agents Now Helping Riders Use Machines

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
IRA S. LONDON of Northport walked up to the ticket machine at the Greenlawn railroad station and tried to insert a $10 bill. The machine would not take it.
"First you have to select the station," a ticket agent off to the side said. 
 "I know how to do it," Mr. London snapped as he searched for the right button.
Moments later, the machine spit out his ticket and change.
"I'm wondering, why are you here?" Mr. London asked the agent.
Commuters at six other Long Island Rail Road stations have also been asking the agents that question for more than two months.
The agents do not issue tickets and they no longer sell subway tokens, the way they once did.
Their sole job now is to help commuters figure out how to use the machines that the railroad wants to use to replace them.
A spokesman for the L.I.R.R., Sam Zambuto, said the line intended to install machines at 32 lightly used stations. Fourteen already have the machines.
Machines have replaced agents at 36 of the 134 stations.
The agents at the 32 stations were supposed to show commuters how to use the machines, before being eliminated in April in an economy move.
That plan ran awry when Nassau County and then three organizations for the disabled sued the line. The organizations contend that blind and visually impaired riders incur "irreparable harm" because of the absence of ticket clerks.
The lawyer for the groups, Dolores Fredrich, said in court papers that the Americans With Disabilities Act permits changing services only if such moves do not "affect the usability" of all or part of an existing service.
Lawyers from the L.I.R.R. said the change in staffing did not constitute an alteration in service, as the disabilities act defines such changes. In addition, the lawyers pointed out that the machines could be used in Braille and were "accessible to the visually impaired to the maximum extent feasible, which is all that is required by the A.D.A."
The L.I.R.R. said those passengers could buy tickets on the train without having to pay the $2 surcharge.
After a hearing, Judge Leonard D. Wexler of Federal District Court in Hauppauge issued a preliminary injunction on May 30. He directed the railroad to keep agents at an initial group of seven stations where the L.I.R.R. had closed ticket windows.
Judge Wexler ordered the railroad to reopen windows at a second group of seven stations.
A trial is scheduled to begin on Friday.
Mr. Zambuto said the judge gave the railroad a choice for the initial seven stations, to reopen their ticket windows from 6 A.M. until 1:30 P.M. or to assign agents to the platforms from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M.
The railroad took the second choice, and the agents at East Hampton Greenlawn, Lawrence, Locust Valley, Oakdale, St. James and Sea Cliff have been posted near the machines or have been sitting in the waiting room sipping coffee and reading.
The chairman of the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, Larry H. Silverman, said his council opposed most of the closings. The closings, Mr. Silverman added, could be averted if the Transportation Communications Union, which represents the 230 agents and their supervisors, agreed to permit a limited number of part-time workers during the rush hour.
Mr. Silverman said the union had resisted the proposal for part timers.
The general chairman of the union, Kenneth A. Lipton, said he had not ruled out part timers. The problem, Mr. Lipton added, is that after first suggesting 16 part-time workers, the railroad increased the number, to 46.
"There was no way I could agree to that," he said. "We are looking at the 16. And I'm also going to let them do away with 16 of my highest-paying positions. They include 9 cleaning foremen and 7 others."
Mr. Zambuto said using part timers was critical and that "at this time the unions have not agreed to use part-time employees."
At Greenlawn on a recent morning rush hour, Malcolm B. Sonsire of Greenlawn wondered aloud why the agent was coaxing him from behind as he went through the motions of pushing the buttons and inserting a $10 bill.
"What do you do here, work on your good looks?" he asked. "You stand here telling me how to work a man-made machine. Why are you here?"
Minutes later, Judith W. Wingate of Huntington asked for help as she tried to buy a ticket to Hunters Point.
"I asked him to help me," she said after the transaction. "Why not? He's here. My head is too old to deal with a machine. I'm technophobic."
As she glanced down at the change Ms. Wingate asked: "You ever seen a Susan B. Anthony? People are afraid it's a foreign coin and are reluctant to take it." The machine uses the Susan B. Anthony coin for dollars rather than bills.
Michael S. Brenner of Greenlawn said he, too, refused to use the machine because it did not work if he did not have the exact change.
"Our monthly ticket to Penn Station costs $181," Mr. Brenner said. "But you can't put in 10 20's, because the machine will return no more than $9.75 in change. And if you want to buy a one-way ticket, you can't use a 20, because a one-way to New York is $8.50. Also, I can't get tokens the way I used to from the ticket agent."
Mr. Brenner, who said he had been rider for nearly 20 years, said he would be willing to pay a little more if the ticket window remained open.
Daniel R. Dwydir of Greenlawn said he had been commuting for 30 years and had changed from buying his monthly tickets at Greenlawn to buying them at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. "I won't use the machine," he said. "I'm not going to put $181 into the machine and hope it works. I'm going to give my money to a human being."
As Joseph C. Morenly of Centerport inserted his money he said: "The one thing I hate is that it just takes bank debit cards and not credit cards like Visa. I think they would have a lot less problems if they had those machines."
A few minutes later Barbara D. Pickell of Greenlawn walked in, poured a cup of coffee and joined the conversation.
"It's terrible what they've done to this station by eliminating a person here," she said. "Now there is vandalism and no oversight. Not only is there vandalism to the station -- there used to be a nice library in here with books on the wall -- but to the cars in the parking lot. At least when a clerk was here there was someone to call the police."
As she sipped the coffee, Ms. Pickell said the vending machine was difficult to deal with and unpredictable.
"I'm not going to stick my debit card in there," she said. "There was a letter to the editor in the local newspaper recently from someone who said his card was charged but that he didn't get a ticket. I'm not going to go through the rigamarole of trying to get my money back because of a broken machine."
She said that on at least seven mornings in the last eight weeks "people have said the machine was broken."
Joseph M. Foresto of Greenlawn said that he had tried to use the machine but that "it wasn't cooperative."
"It wouldn't take a certain year's quarter," Mr. Foresto said. "I ended up having to buy a ticket on the train and paying a $2 penalty. I told the conductor that the machine didn't work, but it's not his fault. I understood he was just doing his job."
A train pulled in, and Jack Alkon, a driver for Greenlawn Taxi, pulled up.
"Last Saturday," Mr. Alkon said, "people were standing out here with that big heavy rain and getting soaked as they waited in line at the machine. And it's ridiculous to have a man here telling people how to work the machine."
Mr. Zambuto said that 15 of the 80 machines accepted credit cards for monthly or weekly purchases. He said the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the railroad's parent body, was reluctant to increase that number because of the service fees involved with using credit cards.
Mr. Zambuto added that the machines' reliability had been better than expected. On average, he added, machines break down after 12,000 transactions.
Mr. Zambuto acknowledged that conductors charged passengers $2 penalties if they did not have tickets.
Passengers who have complained that machines would not print tickets because of a lack of change have received $2 refunds, he said.
Budget deficits led the railroad to eliminate agents at 32 stations, Mr. Zambuto said. "These budget reductions were largely achieved through administrative reductions," he said. "In the prior five years there was an employee reduction of about 12 percent. So we need to look at other areas to achieve reductions."
He said eliminating the agents at the 32 stations would save $2.8 million a year.
Mr. Lipton of the union said that when the agents ended their three hours at the seven stations they travel to busy stations to help there. It is comical, he agreed, that the agents do nothing more than help customers use machines.
"They'll stand on their heads to get a day's pay," he added.
Mr. Lipton said figures compiled by union members showed steep declines in revenues at the seven stations with closed ticket windows. A comparison between April and May in 1995 and this year showed that sales dropped, from $490,283 to $134,149.
Mr. Zambuto said the railroad expected that and that the figures merely reflected a shift of sales to other stations or by mail.

HEADLINE: ENCOUNTERS;
A Link to Pre-War Japan Builds Bridges in the Arts

BYLINE: By ERIKA DUNCAN; Erika Duncan is a novelist and essayist who lives in Sag Harbor.

 BODY:
THERE is something intrinsically delightful about the sort of person who will say "This happened to me," instead of "I did this." It is as if the world in its bounty came and offered them whatever it was they had accomplished, instead of the other way about.
So it was with Beate Gordon, who at the age of 22 found herself one woman among 25 men, precipitously assigned by MacArthur to write the Japanese constitution still in use today. Single-handedly she wrote the women's rights clause, her face lighting up even now as she relates the story. 
 For 20 years the director of performing arts, films and lectures for the Asia Society in New York, Beate was one of the first people to bring Asian music, drama and dance to the United States, traveling to remote mountain shrines and tropical islands looking for traditional art.
She was the force behind bringing the Vietnamese Thang Long Water Puppet Theater first to Lincoln Center and now to Southampton College, where it is presenting its last three performances today.
Until a few years ago, around her 70th birthday, she thought nothing of going alone to remote hamlets in Borneo, watching dances of people who once were headhunters, riding over rapids in speed boats to get there or climbing stone steps in the mountains to witness performances in temples in bitter cold.
She watched fakirs climbing long poles on ladders of knives. She found in Australia Aborigine sand painters, and then, bringing them to this country, combed the beaches of Long Island for the proper color sand.
"I can't take pride in having discovered a lot of things really. I sort of had them thrust on me," she said in the same tone of voice as "It happened to me."
She grew up in Japan, from the formative ages of 5 to 15. By a series of coincidences her father, a Viennese concert pianist, had been lured to Japan by a composer who admired his work and given a post in the Imperial Academy at a time when few Westerners lived permanently in Japan.
Right before the war Beate was sent to school in the United States, where because so many Japanese-Americans were in detention camps, she found herself in demand as a translator and interpreter. She worked for the Office of War Information, even having her own radio show, a nostalgia program to try to convince the Japanese people to surrender, that was supposed to be the counterpart of Tokyo Rose.
She had wanted to return to see her parents, who as Jews in 1943 were sent to the resort town of Karuizawa, but she couldn't go back to Japan as a civilian, so she went as a researcher attached to the Army.
Now at 72, her face expands into a wideness in which you can feel that even her eyes are smiling, as she tells how "a month after I arrived, our general gathered us together and said, 'You are now a constitutional assembly, and under orders from General MacArthur, you will write a constitution for the Japanese Nation.'
"It was a project that was supposed to be top secret. Every draft that the Japanese government had come up with was almost like the Meiji Constitution, conservative and feudal and keeping the Emperor's power in place.
"When we received our assignments, there were only two men on our committee and me. They said, 'You're a woman, so why don't you write the women's rights.'
"I got into a jeep and asked the driver to take me to the nearest library to gather samples. This was top secret. Because we could not tell anybody about this and we didn't want anybody to become suspicious, I went to as many libraries as I could, getting one or two constitutions from each.
"I gathered up 10 or 12 constitutions from all over the world and became very popular because everybody wanted to look at my constitutions. I studied the women's rights very carefully, remembering what my mother had told me when I was a young girl in Japan and the speeches about women she had given in Vienna.
"I remembered from my childhood how when I would visit my friends, that while the mother was the mistress of her own house, controlling everything inside it, in the streets she would be expected to walk behind her husband. In the outside world she had no rights at all.
"I remembered friends being prepared for marriage. I knew that they would not be able to choose a husband and often wouldn't even know the husband beforehand. I had heard Japanese women who had traveled in Europe speaking about how difficult it was to be a woman in Japan."
As I watch her, I can see as if in double exposure the determination of the Beate of 50 years before. A little detail comes back to my mind, how she told me that her mother's first marriage had been arranged.
In addition to the fundamental rights to divorce, property, inheritance, domicile and choice of a spouse, she had found in the European constitutions many social welfare items, like help for nursing and expectant mothers and illegitimate children, and she had carefully included them.
When the men on the steering committee shaved her contribution down to only the fundamental rights, eliminating the social welfare clauses, because, they said, the United States constitution had no such thing, Beate started to cry. They told her not to worry, that the occupation was going to last for a long time, and they would see to it that these were implemented in the civil code. But Beate didn't believe them.
"Then when the constitution was finished, I thought this was to be the end of our work. It had taken one week. But when it was presented to General MacArthur and the Japanese government, I was asked to participate, not as a writer, but as an interpreter. The head of the interpreters was Lieutenant Gordon, whom I later married. It was again to be top secret and we were not allowed to leave the room.
"It started at 10 A.M. and I thought it would be over in a few hours. But the Japanese government put up a tremendous fight, starting with the Emperor's rights that had been curtained. I offered to help the Japanese with their language, to speed things up, and our colonel must have sensed that the Japanese side was becoming favorably inclined towards me, because at 2 A.M. when they finally got to the women's rights, he said: "Miss Sirota has her heart set on women's rights.Why don't we just pass them?' They were struck that the colonel would say such a thing, and they did pass them. Of course, no one knew that I had written them."
Beate stayed in Japan for another year before returning to the United States, working first in the political purge, similar to the German de-Nazification, and then in the economic purges. She joined the others involved in writing the constitution in refusing interviews, in the interest of not having their constitution thought of as imposed. And gradually the history was forgotten.
It wasn't until relatively recently, when the Japanese were asked to send troops to Bosnia and refused on constitutional grounds, that interest in the writing of the constitution began to be revived. Beate had become a bit of a heroine suddenly, and she was asked to write her autobiography.
Beate is talking on the telephone when I arrive. She has just lost a relative in Israel and she is talking first in French and then German, moving freely back and forth among the six languages she knows, so I am told to try out the hammock on the porch of this overly simple rented house, where the pine trees and the nearness to the sea remind her of vacations spent growing up in Japan.
When she ushers me in, her 4-year old grandson hides behind her, and she tells me that in Japan children are not considered to reach the age of reason until 7; therefore, she has nothing in this family retreat that any one of her three grandchildren might not be able to touch.
"In the Japan that I knew, even the most elegant house is not very different from other people's houses, only the richer people might have a border of brocade along their tatami mats, while a poor fisherman or farmer would have only a border of black."
And these sentences, as first introductions, seem to say a great deal about how she thinks and feels.
It would be one of those leisurely visits where food and drinks were served with a grace not quite familiar, where the various levels of interchange would move not chronologically but rather back and forth, from descriptions of the Vietnamese water puppets she was bringing to Southampton College this week to the tales of how, leaving the life of translation and interpretation behind, she "happened" to start the performance programs first for the Japan Society and then later for the Asia Society.
There are some people who speak in image, and Beate is one of those. She told me how in her programs at the Asia Society she instituted pre-performance demonstrations in which people sit on the floor very close to the performers.
She made a point of having elaborate program notes prepared by scholars -- this was a big part of her work. Before every performance she would give two or three minutes of light, telling the audience to please read their notes.
"You must forget what you have been taught about your own Western classics and open up your heart to the penetration of the music and the colors," she said. "Then you will see how close to you it is.
"But only the best performers can communicate to an audience that doesn't know their art. That is why I have traveled so extensively and been so careful to bring only what is very close to the well. It is like drinking from the well, getting the very pure things. Although I did bring over such 'modern' amalgamations as Butoh, I am mainly interested in bringing the originals.
"I realized a lot were museum pieces. But we do go to museums to see art that is very old and to learn from it. We don't know what Egyptian dance was like, but in Japan we do know what was present 1,000 years ago in the Imperial courts and the shrines. What a glorious thing to present to American composers and dancers, to see what has held for generations."
Then we spoke for a while of the difference between true assimilation and what she calls a fusion, what happens, for example, when whole cultures are inundated by rock and roll.
Her parents had been part of the Viennese intellectual and musical world, which persisted even in Japan when people like Heifetz and Rubenstein, Ruth Page and Chaliapin would come to their house, so that very early also, she said, she was exposed to the pure thing.
She was also taken to many Japanese performances and learned in the homes of her friends the purity of Origami paper folding -- how a single piece of paper could be used over and over -- and the philosophy of flower arrangements, why they had to be so different in summer and winter to convey opposing sensations of warm and cool.
These two arts, now thought of as characteristically Japanese, originally came from China, a country much richer in natural resources, she explained. But Japan, such a small island country, had to make do with very little:, three flowers to represent heaven earth and man; a single piece of paper that could be either a boat or a helmet or a Samurai warrior or a crane.
"All of these things were daily occurrences in the houses of my friends,"
She herself had wanted to be a dancer, and she took lessons in both Asian and Western dance. But when she was about 15 her mother told her that although she had beautiful hand movements, her technique in her legs and feet was not sufficient for her to become a first-rate dancer. Then her mother told her in graphic detail she will always remember about the life of a second-rate dancer, the sleezy hotels and the suffering.
So Beate went to America to college instead, becoming eventually a facilitator of the arts, which, in a way, was following her mother's footsteps.
"My American friends think my mother did a terrible thing to me, but I don't think so," Beata said as she told a story about a pupil of her father's who said, "I am going to play in the countryside, so therefore I don't have to practice, for the people will not know the difference."
"No," her father had said. "If you go to the country, you will have to play better to convince people who may not know the beauty of Western music."
"In our house," Beate said, "nothing second rate was allowed."
This idea, of needing to be the best possible in order to open the heart of the stranger, must have stayed in Beate's mind when, out of her first incarnation of working in radio and translation, she gradually began to work in the arts, the new work being both a coming together and a return.
In an hour or so Beate and I watched a videotape of the Vietnamese water puppets, but right now I want to pull together a few missing threads of her chronology.
Returning to the United States and marrying Lieut. Joseph Gordon, she had taken "a few boring jobs" before becoming the interpreter for Fusaye Ichikawa, "Japan's leading suffragette," who had come to the observe the Eisenhower elections and together they went all over the country talking to women's groups.
Then, after her daughter was born, she began to work with exchange students for the Japan Society, and noticed that the neediest among them were always in music and drama and dance. She could hardly bear to see the red hands of the violinists, who were forced to wash dishes every night, so she had organized a fund raising in which those students played.
Just by chance, Mrs. John Dewey happened to be in the audience, and the rest is history: the first $3,000 grant from the Japanese consulate; programs at first with Japanese performers who already happened to be traveling in the United States (therefore transportation didn't have to paid); later her own trips to Asia, the first Asian programs at Lincoln Center, the educational programs in the schools.
As the light fades, we sit in the livingroom of this unimposing rented house with its touchable objects. The little boy comes out and stands with us shyly, watching for the angels with whom he will dance, as the scene of the Vietnamese water puppets flashes on the video screen.
Beate's face glows as she describes how the puppeteers must stand chest deep in water in this art deriving from third century China and then disappearing, coming mysteriously to Vietnam, a water culture, where it has remained, as she describes the elaborate system of poles and strings of an astounding mechanical and esthetic sophistication.
I watch as the water and the colors reflected beneath and above it seem also to be caught in a symmetrical dance of shimmering ultramarines, bright magentas and violets, while dragons and fish, men and boats dive and dance. The little boy quickens at the sight of men herding water buffalo, stoical and whimsical at once, with pink perplexed faces and bodies both static and flexible on strings -- so serious in their play.
Slowly talking to her grandchild and me all at once, Beate's hands rise, quite beautiful in their gesture, as I think of the fact that her mother said even though she has beautiful hand movements she shouldn't try to be a dancer, even as the musicians are singing the words of a story I feel but I can't understand.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Threepenny' Gala, One-Woman Shows

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
SUMMER after summer, Lucille Lortel, the mistress of the White Barn and the queen of Off Broadway, insists: "I can't do it anymore." And then she does it one more time.
Why then should this summer be different? 
 The 48th season of the White Barn Theater and Museum in Westport, which began last night, was to have lasted one night only: Aug. 25.
And in the works is a gala honoring Kurt Weill, Lotte Lenya and Bertolt Brecht, with cast members of Ms. Lortel's 1955 revival of "The Threepenny Opera."
But other entertainers and other events "just came up," as Ms. Lortel put it. Now that single concert is to be the capstone of a month of seven lit-up nights, with cabaret shows of two performances each over three weekends.
Tonight at 8 the singer Juliette Koka offers a double bill: Jean Cocteau's "Sound of Silence" and excerpts from her new staged concert, "Juliette" in which she sings songs ranging from works by Edith Piaf and Noel Coward to those of Neil Sedaka and Richard Maltby Jr.
"Mostly Women II," a sampler of one-woman shows, is next up, Saturday and next Sunday.
"Willie's Ladies Sing the Blues," Carmen de Lavallade's meditation on the problems of Shakespearean heroines set to choreography by Geoffrey Holder, is to be followed by June Havoc, a memoirist of legend who spans the vaudeville days of Baby June, the marathon dances of the Depression and a grown-up life of considerable accomplishment as playwright and musical and dramatic actress.
Liliane Montevecchi is to effervesce as the third woman in a bountiful evening that is somehow expected to make room for Max Showalter, a one-man show unto himself.
Mr. Showalter will recall a 10-year film career (1950 to 1960) that did not allow him to appear as Max Showalter. "Darryl Zanuck told me, 'We just finished fighting the Germans. You can't use that name.' " the actor said.
And so Mr. Showalter made 34 films under the name Casey Adams. Clips from two of them -- "Niagara" (one of two he played in with Marilyn Monroe; "Bus Stop" was the other) and "Elmer Gantry" will be shown during Mr. Showalter's part of the program, which, be assured, will not run short of stories about screen stars, stage stars, composers -- and about how Mr. Showalter got his rightful name back.
The lyrics of Ira Gershwin will propel two performances on Aug. 17 and 18 in a program devised by Rex Reed. Such estimable cabaret performers as Mary Cleere Haran and Billy Stritch will interpret songs with music by Harold Arlen, Jerome Kern, Vernon Duke and Burton Lane. Not just George. And by Weill too.
Although "Threepenny Opera" is the centerpiece of the season's finale, the show on Aug. 25 is to include appearances by Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson in passages from "Brecht on Brecht," and by Melissa Errico, the singular sensation of New York's musical theater season just passed when she was Venus -- truly by critical acclamation, was Venus -- in the City Center/Encores concert staging of "One Touch of Venus," with music by Weill and lyrics by Ogden Nash.
Among the original cast members of the "Threepenny" production, in the Marc Blitzstein adaptation, that ran for more than six years at the Theater de Lys, now Ms. Lortel's namesake theater in Greenwich Village, Beatrice Arthur (as Lucy Brown) and Jo Sullivan Loesser (as Polly Peachum) will figure in the Weill/Lenya/Brecht occasion.
From her home in Brentwood, Calif., Ms. Arthur said: "Even after all these years, doing 'Threepenny' has to be the high spot of my professional life. It was the first time I got any recognition. I was unsure of myself and scared to death."
Ms. Arthur's stage roles in the original casts include Yente the Matchmaker ("Fiddler on the Roof") and Vera Charles ("Mame") before she became a television star.
Lenya, who played Pirate Jenny, "was my strongest influence," Ms. Arthur said. "She was mesmerizing. I learned economy from her -- and I felt omnipotence."
Ms. Arthur left the "Threepenny" cast to stand by for Tallulah Bankhead in a Philadelphia tryout of a recycled "Ziegfeld Follies" that never made it to Broadway.
"I've spent the major part of my adult life in that little box -- no more sit-coms for me," Ms. Arthur continued. "Now ply me with a stage offer. Coming back to this event is a way of celebrating Lenya -- and my own beginnings."
Since the debate over the exclusion of Off Broadway from Tony Awards consideration goes on, it is instructive to point out that Ms. Lortel's production of "Threepenny Opera" won a Tony. So did Lenya as featured musical actress. Scott Merrill, who played Mack the Knife, was a nominee in the musical featured-actor category. All for a production Off Broadway.
Ms. Lortel, a famously innovative producer who gave chances to Beckett and Albee, to Genet and Fugard early on, has even set a Tony Award precedent without knowing it.
About the current White Barn season, she said: "I'm tired, darling, but I can't resist the theater," hastening to name two productions -- "The Boys in the Band" and "The Tooth of Crime" -- coming up at the Lucille Lortel Theater, and a limited engagement of Ms. Montevecchi's new revue, in memory of Martin Kaufman, at the Kaufman Theater. All Off-Broadway.
All the season's shows are under the artistic supervision of Donald Saddler, the choreographer who credits Ms. Lortel with giving him his first directorial job: "Berlin to Broadway With Kurt Weill."
White Barn Theater, Newtown Turnpike, Westport. 227-3768. Tickets to most shows are $30 each but the Weill/Lenya/Brecht event costs $100 and includes the museum exhibition as well as a reception. The Weill/ Lenya/Brecht exhibition, curated by Mary Henderson, can be seen by appointment through October.

HEADLINE: A Tale of Federal Dollars at Work

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
TWO and a half years ago, when the Federal Government announced that 100 cities would receive $3 million Enterprise Community grants with which to create jobs in poor neighborhoods, Bridgeport and New Haven were among the recipients.
In New Haven, the grant appeared to draw the community together and strengthened neighborhood activism. 
 But in Bridgeport, there was factional bickering and a complete breakdown in the process, which resulted in the municipal government taking control away from neighborhood organizers.
Federal grants are often awarded with considerable publicity but seldom attract much follow-up attention unless questions of corruption arise, or disputes ensue over the grants' extension in Congress. How New Haven and Bridgeport dealt with the Enterprise Community money provides a glimpse into what happens -- or does not -- after such a grant.
People close to the decision-making processes in the two cities suggested that the seeds of New Haven's harmony and of Bridgeport's discord were present well before the grants were announced.
Bridgeport started off with power issues raised by neighborhood activists, who argued that authority over the grant was controlled by a few politicians and business leaders, instead of the neighborhoods. Although this dispute was quickly resolved, bitterness over it lingered. Bickering between factions competing for control eventually erupted into open war as they publicly attacked each other's motives.
New Haven, on the other hand, had already resolved these issues. The committee that was formed to set neighborhood priorities and allocate funds for them grew out of an established structure of neighborhood organizations created two years before to work with the police to address social problems that were hampering crime-fighting efforts. Neighborhood representatives to those organizations had gradually acquired the ability to work together and trust each other, qualities that were absent in Bridgeport.
The Enterprise Community grant originated in the Urban Marshall Plan, drafted by a Congressional caucus led by Representatives Christopher Shays of Stamford and Kweisi Mfume of Maryland, who later resigned from Congress to become president of the N.A.A.C.P. The legislation provided for 10 grants of $100 million each and 100 grants of $3 million.
"We wanted to prove that a real effort to attract busineses to a community would pay off tremendously," Mr. Shays said.
Bridgeport vigorously entered the competition for the grant set aside for cities of its size. Mr. Shays said its application was the first submitted to the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, and was supported by a coalition of the city's government, business community, social service institutions and neighborhood groups.
When it was eliminated from consideration for $100 million, and received $3 million instead, Bridgeport was forced to downsize its efforts. New Haven, which had applied for the smaller grant, had no such disappointment to face, and went straight to work.
The plans of the two cities were similar from the start, having been devised under the same Federal guidelines. They create programs for neighborhood improvements, education and job training, family-oriented and youth-oriented services, and economic development, including loans and technical assistance for entrepreneurs. The major difference was in implementation. In New Haven, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. said, planning and implementation of the grant was in the hands of the Enterprise Community Council, a 30-member board. Twenty of its members were selected from among representatives on neighborhood police district management teams, and the rest from the city government and several major businesses and institutions in the city.
Ten police district management teams were formed four years ago to help the police address issues like housing blight, dysfunctional families and substance abuse, which affect neighborhood crime rates. Already familiar with their neighborhoods' particular needs, the management team members were viewed as a valuable resource for connecting the Enterprise Community Council with the six neighborhoods targeted as beneficiaries of the grant.
"If you weren't active on a management team, you couldn't end up as a citywide representative," said Howard Gilreath, a member of the grant committee from the Newhallville neighborhood.
Mr. DeStefano said that in addition to managing the grant programs, the Enterprise Community Council has become "a platform for community-based planning and consensus."
"That's better than money, in many respects," he said. "I think money without a sense of ownership and participation by the community often doesn't work because it seeks to impose a paradigm on the community in a direction it doesn't want to go."
In contrast, the process in Bridgeport apparently began poorly and got steadily worse. The initial committee, formed to apply for the larger Empowerment Community grant, consisted of representatives from the city government, the business community and major institutions. When grass roots community organizations complained, they were included, but an atmosphere of resentment and suspicion remained.
"It started off with control issues from the very beginning," said Alma Maya, who wound up as one of three co-chairmen of the Community Collaborative of Bridgeport, which was to act in the same role as New Haven's Enterprise Community Council. With 50 members representing various interest groups, the ungainly group quickly broke into factions.
The group tried to retain a provision from the city's original $100 million grant application. Known as the Office of Neighborhoods, it proposed to spend nearly $1 million to hire a staff of community advocates and clerical help.
While this provision would have been a relatively small portion of the larger grant, it was a third of the smaller grant. H.U.D., which had to approve Bridgeport's downsized application, ruled that it was too much to spend on administration.
Three major factions formed. One, allied with Mayor Joseph P. Ganim and the business community, wanted to revise the application to eliminate the Office of Neighborhoods. Those wanting to retain the office divided into one faction, including Ms. Maya, which advocated legal action, and another faction opposed going to court.
The group's meetings became preoccupied with questions over who was a member, who had a right to vote, whether H.U.D. had a right to disapprove the Office of Neighborhoods, and whether the group was just an advisory body, subject to the authority of the Bridgeport Common Council.
Many of the Community Collaborative of Bridgeport's members felt their time was poorly spent arguing over procedural points and they stopped attending meetings.
"It became very frustrating because you'd sit at those meetings and argue," said Paul Timpanelli, executive director of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council.
When Mr. Ganim moved to reorganize the group, Ms. Maya's faction sued the city government. In June, a Superior Court judge dismissed their suit, and the Common Council authorized formation of a new committee, its 20 members to be appointed by the Mayor and to be known as the Bridgeport Enterprise Community Partnership.
Ms. Maya says the city government's action was illegal and that her group may sue in Federal Court to overturn it.
"The real issue is they don't want a threat to their power," she said.
For Mr. Ganim, however, the issue is $3 million in Federal funds, which H.U.D. threatened to give to another city if the Office of Neighborhoods remains in the application.
"This isn't some sort of power play," said Chris Duby, the Mayor's spokesman. The city is the fiduciary agent for the grant, and so the Mayor must look out for the interests of its taxpayers, he said.
Several theories have been proposed as to why Bridgeport's experience with this grant was so different from New Haven's.
"I believe it's all political," said Ms. Maya. She blamed Bridgeport's Democratic Party leadership, and Mr. Ganim in particular, for not wanting to share power.
Bridgeport's Assistant Chief Administrative Officer, Brian Williams, blamed Ms. Maya and her allies, some of whom have been dissident voices on other issues in the past, for stirring up trouble for its own sake. "I really believe that this group's mission is to embarrass the administration," he said.
Mr. Shays says he thinks there are people in Bridgeport who fear domination by the city's business establishment. "There are elements within Bridgeport, within community groups, that look at the business community as the enemy," he said. "I wish people would understand that you can't be pro-jobs and anti-business."
Mr. Timpanelli says that Bridgeport's problem is that it doesn't have a dominant industry or institution, such as the insurance industry in Hartford or Yale University in New Haven, to provide leadership. Another problem, he said, is that Bridgeport's neighborhoods are isolated from one another, which tends to blind them to their common interests.
Mr. DeStefano downplayed the role of Yale in his city's success. The university was a resource, but not a deciding factor, he said.
The real key to New Haven's success, in Mr. DeStefano's opinion, was "a lot of time spent up front getting people together working on the project."
Mr. Gilreath added: "The first thing we had to do on the committee was to establish trust between ourselves. We realized that we were all on the same page and it would benefit us more to work together than each on its own thing."

HEADLINE: Jolted

BYLINE: By Betsy Wade; Betsy Wade, who writes the Practical Traveler column of The New York Times, was a plaintiff in the 1970's sex-discrimination suit against The Times by women on the staff.

 BODY:

WHAT WOMEN WANT
By Patricia Ireland.
Illustrated. 308 pp. New York:
Dutton. $23.95.
Before reading "What Women Want," I knew virtually nothing about Patricia Ireland, the ninth president of the 250,000-member National Organization for Women. She has been a mainstay of the women's movement ever since she began doing pro bono legal work for the Dade County, Fla., chapter of NOW in 1978. But despite making vast legal contributions, suffering arrest, experiencing terror and despair during killings at abortion clinics and undergoing a painful evolution to a position of leadership, she has not been the magnet for media coverage that earlier NOW presidents were. 
 Well, I know her now, and although I have never belonged to her organization, if I did, I would vote for her -- or, more important, get out the vote for her -- any day. But this was not an easy decision to reach. Her political autobiography starts out with so many acknowledgments that I wondered if she had written any of the book herself.
One pines for a newspaper editor to order Ms. Ireland and her advisers to put the news on top. Late in her book we find what would have made a good starting place: her discussion of the dilemma that faces all who organize women -- whether to enfold or ignore the women whose politics, personal lives or long-term goals would not pass Pat Buchanan's God, mother and apple pie test.
"Looking back on the history of the modern feminist movement," she writes, "I'm confident that the industries that profit from discrimination against women and the politicians who are indebted to those industries would not have suddenly embraced the E.R.A. even if every lesbian had been purged from the ranks of the movement and shoved back into the closet nationwide. Somehow, too, I doubt that the U.S. Chamber of Commerce or the National Manufacturers Association would have encouraged George Bush to sign the Family and Medical Leave Act if we'd only been willing to turn our backs on young women's and poor women's right to abortion. But in my early years of activism, none of this was so clear to me."
How many times have friends and supporters been alienated while young activists grind their way through to this understanding? For Ms. Ireland, who has always been sensitive about discussing her sexuality (she acknowledges having both a husband and a female companion), it must have been excruciating to reach this point.
Ms. Ireland started, as most activists do, after an encounter with economic injustice of the kind that jolts a woman out of delusions about a job. In the late 1960's, having previously endured a flesh-market job screening, Ms. Ireland was working as a flight attendant for Pan American World Airways. Her husband, a student, needed expensive dental work. Pan Am told Ms. Ireland that her medical coverage did not provide for him, although male employees' wives were covered.
Ms. Ireland called the Dade County NOW branch, and she was urged to call the United States Labor Department. She did, and suddenly Pan Am saw it her way after it was called to the company's attention that President Lyndon Johnson's executive order requiring Federal contractors, Pan Am included, to have affirmative action programs had been extended to cover women employees in 1967. Still, Pan Am wiggled, saying dependents were covered only when the employee was the head of the household. These days even such grudging concessions seem like basic justice. But winning such changes was not simple, and they were won, as were the battles in the black civil rights movement, with huge sacrifices as well as wits.
"What Women Want" is the perfect gift for the young woman fresh out of, say, Princeton, who does not yet realize what Patricia Ireland, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Jane Roe won for her, and at what peril, because these gains may be lost.

HEADLINE: The Big Lie

BYLINE: By John Sutherland; John Sutherland is the Lord Northcliffe Professor of Modern English Literature at University College, London.

 BODY:

THE TRUE STORY OF THE NOVEL
By Margaret Anne Doody.
Illustrated. 580 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.:
Rutgers University Press. $44.95.
Margaret Anne Doody is not a critic who minces words. "One of the most successful literary lies," she has declared, "is the English claim to have invented the novel." Rarely have a writer's initials been more appropriate: Margaret Anne Doody is mad as hell about the lying English and their literary land grab, and she's not going to take it anymore. 
 The untruth that so vexes Ms. Doody will be familiar to anyone under 60 years of age who has taken a college course in the English novel. It began with Marxist critics who saw in the "realism" of the post-Renaissance novel a bourgeois resistance to aristocratic romance. The English bourgeoisie, as Marx notes in "The Communist Manifesto," was once a revolutionary class, and the early novel was one of its forms of protest against the old regime. Ian Watt's still hugely influential 1957 volume, "The Rise of the Novel: Studies in Defoe, Richardson and Fielding," solidified the "novel as recent English invention" thesis. Mr. Watt's foundation text was "Robinson Crusoe," the fable of modern homo economicus.
According to his theory, the novel rose, like capitalism and the Protestant ethic, in the mercantilist ethos and individualist consciousness of England in the early 18th century. Mr. Watt's sociohistorical argument was modified but not substantially contradicted by another celebrated work of criticism, Michael McKeon's "Origins of the English Novel, 1600-1740," which was published in 1987. Mr. McKeon had specific quarrels with Mr. Watt, but accepted that "the genesis of the novel lies in the great upheavals of secularization and reform that transformed early modern Europe." Similarly, feminists have fiercely contested the novel's paternity but not its place and date of birth -- Britain around the 18th century.
Ms. Doody offers two refutations: one brief, one long. Her brief refutation is the observation that university departments not devoted to English literature have never subscribed to the "lie." (Classicists, for example, have always assumed that there is a classical novel. And comparatists blithely use terms like le roman, der Roman and il romanzo, which do not distinguish between medieval romance and modern novel.) Ms. Doody's long refutation makes up the body of her immensely long book. She begins with a survey of prose fiction from its prehistoric origins to the present day. Delving past any archeological literary record, she speculates that "the novel grew among a motley collection of various peoples living in the Mediterranean basin." Its primeval origins were "probably Egyptian." But why stop there? Perhaps Cro-Magnon man, having slain his mammoth, curled up in a warm cave with a good story and a half-chewed bone.
The first surviving texts are Greek and Roman, by which time the novel is already old. Much space is devoted in "The True Story of the Novel" to summaries of the tiny corpus of extant classical works, from Chariton's "Chaireas and Kallirrhoe" (50 B.C.) to Apuleius' "Golden Ass" (A.D. 155). Ms. Doody's summarizing is vivacious and tailored to the needs of the "well-educated" modern reader who nonetheless has no Greek and little Latin -- let alone Chinese or Japanese. This is not a book for the intellectually timid. At every stage, Ms. Doody is at pains to identify the novel as an anti-civic form of writing: one that is temperamentally at odds with the establishment and drawn to the histories of women, slaves, rebels and the underclass. She is equally at pains to identify "modern" elements in antique texts. Intertextuality, self-reflexivity, hyper-realism, irony and post-colonial multiculturalism are all there from the beginning.
The second section of Ms. Doody's book deals with the circulation and progeny of the "ancient novel" in the period between the European Middle Ages and the 18th century. Her third and most ambitious section is a freewheeling examination of recurrent "tropes" and archetypal elements in novels as separate in time as Heliodorus' "Aethiopica," Jerome K. Jerome's "Three Men in a Boat" and Norman Mailer's "Ancient Evenings."
Having worked his way through Ms. Doody's treatise, the reader is led to ask (as she, oddly, doesn't) why the Anglo-American academic world has bought into the "lie" so enthusiastically. And if the reader accepts, as I largely do, Ms. Doody's refutation, how should teachers reform their syllabuses? They can usefully start by looking at the recent history of their own institutions. It is clear that the "English invented the novel" thesis coincided with two significant educational events. The first was the professionalization of literary criticism in the postwar period and the consequent rise of the English department as a font of critical authority. The second was the lamentable decline of classics (and, to a lesser extent, modern European languages) as school subjects. The English professor under 40 who can read Greek -- or even Latin and French -- with any fluency is now a rarity.
English departments like to see literature as contained within their own territorial and linguistic boundaries. It is very convenient for the instructor to assume that poetry starts with Chaucer, drama with Marlowe and the novel with Defoe. Ms. Doody willfully "rumples such tidiness" and charmingly pictures herself "leaping over a paddock fence and escaping into a larger space." To teach the novel conscientiously, a la Doody, one would begin with, say, Chariton, progress to Heliodorus, thence to Boccaccio and Cervantes, finishing up with Richardson (now in his proper belated place), Goethe, Flaubert, Virginia Woolf and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. In this ideal scheme, the patchwork of departmental turfs would dissolve into the open field of the comparative studies program -- exactly the kind of program, as it happens, that Ms. Doody herself runs at Vanderbilt University.
Anyone who has served on a college curriculum committee will be familiar with the depth-versus-breadth quarrel. Is it better for the student to know a lot about a little or a little about a lot? Over recent years, the pendulum has swung decisively toward specialization. Great-books courses and surveys of world literature have disappeared from undergraduate programs; the formerly broad range of qualifying examinations has been drastically narrowed for the doctoral student. In this vibrant book, Ms. Doody makes a case for the restoration of breadth to the teaching of literary history. She should be heeded.

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Zeal of a Convert

BYLINE: By Brent Staples; Brent Staples, the author of the memoir "Parallel Time: Growing Up in Black and White," writes editorials on politics and culture for The New York Times.

 BODY:

Up From Conservatism
Why the Right Is Wrong for America.
By Michael Lind.
295 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $23.
THE Republican culture wars transformed the party into a band of inquisitors, labeling homosexuals, feminists, multiculturalists, environmentalists, the urban poor and the pot-smoking 60's in their entirety as enemies of the state. The Gingrich Congress believed its own propaganda and produced an agenda that frightened and angered voters -- particularly women. For Bob Dole -- already cast as the Prince of Darkness -- this additional millstone could easily prove fatal. The party is scrambling for a moderate face, but the damage is already done. 
 In "Up From Conservatism," the political writer Michael Lind describes the culture wars as a succession of "moral panics," like those that brought the Salem witch hunts and the persecution of the Jews in Europe. The analogy is a good one, given that inquisitions are pursued in every era, nation and political philosophy. But Mr. Lind seems intent on a witch hunt of his own. First he conjures up a segregated, self-perpetuating caste -- called the overclass -- which he accuses of scuttling unions, dominating the economy and manipulating immigration to insure a cheap supply of nannies. Then he lays the blame for a host of cultural tensions at the door of mythmongering conservatives who have sold out to racists, eugenicists and right-wing religious "crackpots." The far right's diatribe has indeed been poisonous. But to blame the right wing alone for resurgent racism and hostility toward the poor is to miss powerful forces at work in the culture.
"Up From Conservatism" covers the origins of the modern conservative movement, from William F. Buckley Jr.'s "God and Man at Yale" in the 1950's through the Goldwater 60's and the rise of the Reaganauts in the 80's to the patently racist tracts of Charles Murray and Dinesh D'Souza in the 90's. The title, "Up From Conservatism," is a play on Mr. Buckley's "Up From Liberalism," itself a play on "Up From Slavery," the memoir of Booker T. Washington. The equation of conservatism and slavery conveys Mr. Lind's feelings toward his former colleagues and benefactors on the right. This book is billed as an intellectual history; it could properly be called an indictment.
Mr. Lind witnessed the growth of conservative radicalism from inside the movement. He worked for Mr. Buckley and was a fellow at the Heritage Foundation in the late 1980's, and in the early 90's was made executive editor of The National Interest, the quarterly published by that godfather of conservatism, Irving Kristol. But he grew disenchanted, and announced his defection in caustic articles on Pat Buchanan, the born-again populist, and Pat Robertson, the "energetic retailer of anti-Semitic libels," and in an essay called "The Death of Intellectual Conservatism," published in 1995 in the lefty journal Dissent. He has become a star of the intellectual set, moving from Harper's Magazine to The New Republic and most recently to The New Yorker. He is savaged by the right-wing zealots he deserted, pawed over by the left-wing zealots who covet him as a trophy. He has a pyrotechnic intelligence and a good ear for the moment. But "The Death of Intellectual Conservatism" was unremarkable. The charge that conservatives have become middlebrow, morally corrupt -- and had sacrificed "intellectual standards" -- could be applied to almost any political enterprise. Middlebrow moral corruption is the air in which we swim.
"Up From Conservatism" is a book of harsh predictions, among them: "For the foreseeable future . . . the honorable name of conservatism is likely to remain the property, in the United States, of shifting coalitions of libertarians, racists, medievalists, Protestant fundamentalists, supply-siders, flat-taxers, isolationists, gun fanatics, anti-Semites and eugenics theorists." American conservatism is "dead," he writes, partly because the Young Turks (like himself) have been appalled at the barbarism and fled into exile. My guess is that Republican conservatism is far from dead. It is awaiting the next version of Ronald Reagan -- a charismatic guy or gal who wins the White House by force of personality. When the economy is not in shambles, Presidential contests are decided by personal magnetism, not ideology. But Mr. Lind undervalues this dimension of politics and sees only isms and political labels. He cuts razor-thin distinctions among neoconservatives and neoliberals, center right and center left, left liberals and right liberals, paleoliberals and paleoconservatives, Astroturf conservatives and grass-roots conservatives, and on and on ad infinitum.
Michael Lind is distressed that conservatives have strayed from the gradualist tradition of his patron saint, Edmund Burke. But Burke set an exceedingly high standard. He chose principle over partisanship and is respected by liberals and conservatives alike. In times as rigid as ours, a man of his description would be accused of not making up his mind and be judged too boring for "The McLaughlin Group." The Kristol strain of conservatism owes its allegiance not to Burke but to the German-born political philosopher Leo Strauss, a cult figure who taught at the University of Chicago through the 1950's and 60's. Strauss held Burke in contempt. His own views were disturbingly elitist and antidemocratic. Strauss shocked his students when he told them that the Enlightenment -- by promoting egalitarianism and rationalism over religion -- had led directly to Hitler. There are high souls and low souls, he said, and it is dangerous to assume otherwise. Let the rabble get above themselves, and you ended up with brownshirts sacking the universities.
Irving Kristol is a Strauss fan, as is his son William, the editor of The Weekly Standard and former chief of staff for Dan Quayle. Mr. Lind glances over this connection; the book would have been richer had he lingered on it. He accuses the elder Kristol of selling out to hysteria by arguing "that the true enemy of America all along had been, not Communism, but liberalism." He makes a similar charge against the younger Kristol, for saying that The Standard was "pulling up the drawbridge against the peasants" and that "we conservatives are on the side of the lords and barons." Mr. Lind finds these remarks surprising. But they are pure Strauss -- indeed, Strauss at his most benign.
A chapter called "Three Conservative Hoaxes" is the clearest and most valuable part of this book. It shows how public policy myths germinate and grow unchallenged. The chapter deals with supply-side (voodoo) economics and the education crisis, but its best-argued section focuses on the myth of mass illegitimacy, which, along with the idea that welfare causes out-of-wedlock births, is driving virtually all welfare policy. Mr. Lind recognizes that illegitimacy is less than ideal, but cites Census Bureau data showing that "the rate of babies being born to unwed black teen-agers -- about 80 per 1,000 unmarried teen-agers -- remained virtually the same from 1920 through 1990" -- that is, from before the New Deal. The simple but dramatic fact: Declining birth rates among married couples have caused illegitimate births to account for a higher percentage of the total. In other words, there is no illegitimacy crisis.
He tracks the mythical crisis to a Wall Street Journal essay by Charles Murray and to Dan Quayle's Murphy Brown speech, which got the nation wringing its hands. Mr. Lind bears down again on Irving Kristol, the publisher of The National Interest and also the co-editor of The Public Interest, arguing that he should have used his influence to expose the lie.
Mr. Kristol is a power broker and tough guy -- but he is not the Antichrist. The illegitimacy data were there for anybody to see but remained largely undiscussed, mainly because pessimism about the poor suits the national mood. We can only guess at the reasons. But the ideas about the importance of social networks in Robert D. Putnam's 1994 essay "Bowling Alone" make good candidates: Americans visit one another's homes and join civic associations less than in any era on record. Alone at the end of the cul-de-sac, we watch murder, mayhem and assorted social pathologies on television. Bereft of community, we have become suspicious of immigrants, of shared social responsibility -- and even of human potential itself. Racist arguments like Charles Murray's conform to this mind-set: they offer "scientific" evidence that the poor are inferior and therefore a hopeless case. The press is culpable too, transmitting the idea with barely a skeptical question. Modern conservatives did not create the national mood; it emanates from well outside the Irving Kristol empire.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Grants That Aim to Use the Past to Help the Present

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE sprawling convention hall and Paramount Theater complex has anchored the boardwalk in Asbury Park since the 20's. But over time its fortunes along with those of the old resort city have changed, pushing it into disuse and disrepair.
Now Asbury Park is restoring the oceanfront complex. In the process, it hopes to spur revitalization of the nearby area and improve the city's economy. 
 What is happening in Asbury Park is happening to historic sites across New Jersey, thanks to state grants. Last month the New Jersey Historic Trust, a quasi-public agency within the state's Department of Environmental Protection, awarded $11 million in matching grants to 27 projects involving buildings owned by government agencies or nonprofit groups.
Some buildings are being returned to their original use or a variation of it, which is the case with the convention hall in Asbury Park and a lighthouse in Atlantic City. Others are being turned to new uses -- such as is the cases in Trenton and Paterson where old factories are becoming museums.
Many local officials view the grants as a tool not only to save a piece of the past but also to build community pride and renewal. They and advocates of historic preservation say restoration also promotes tourism, creates jobs and attracts new investment.
Underscoring such benefits are the preliminary findings of a study being done for the Historic Trust by the Center For Urban Policy Research at Rutgers.
The findings showed that every $1 million invested in preserving historic sites generated 25 jobs and $1.1 million in economic activity, and that when matched equally the impact was greater. Each dollar the trust grants a project attracts $9 from outside sources, said Harriet C. Hawkins, the trust's executive director.
Moreover, said Prof. David Listokin, who with Prof. Michael Lahr is conducting the Rutgers study, from a marketing perspective a historic building restored for re-use could give its owner an edge over a competitor in a nondescript building.
Professor Listokin said the dollars spent on historic preservation were "a pump primer," especially for cities. "But it has to be part of a package that all together gives the critical mass to build upon," he added.
Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington, said that New Jersey was among the few states to recognize "historic preservation and economic development are partners in community revitalization."
The recent grants bring to 152 the number of projects funded under the program -- capitalized by $60 million set aside under 1987, 1992 and 1995 bond issues. When completed the projects will represent an investment of $389 million in New Jersey historic resources, said Ms. Hawkins.
THE grants -- $20,000 to $1.25 million -- are used to restore, rehabilitate or improve buildings. The trust holds easements on the land under the buildings that prohibit them from being razed and insures public access for up to 20 years.
Eligible properties are those owned by a government agency or a nonprofit group and listed, or eligible for listing, on the National or State Registers of Historic Places.
Asbury Park's $1.25 million grant will go to the ongoing restoration of the convention hall and theater complex. Tommy Dorsey and Bruce Springsteen, a native of the area who lives in nearby Rumson, have performed at the Classical Revival style complex, designed with nautical details by the architectural firm of Warren & Wetmore, which also designed Manhattan's Grand Central Terminal.
Some $3.6 million in city and state funds have helped to renovate the theater, which is being used this summer for concerts. Alan Feit, Asbury Park's City Manager, calls the complex "the key component in the city's plan to revitalize the area."
Much of the rest of the property lining the boardwalk and two blocks inland is privately owned and mired in litigation. "We need the oceanfront back in our hands," Mr. Feit said, adding that the boardwalk project was one step in the rebuilding process.
In Trenton, a $1.25 million grant will bolster the redevelopment of 45 acres occupied by factories and mills built for the John A. Roebling Sons and American Steel and Wire companies, manufacturers of cables for bridges, elevators and trolleys. The site, near the State Capitol, is to be reborn as a residential, commercial and recreation hub.
The grant will be used to help renovate the former 52,000-square-foot, century-old Roebling machine shop into a museum-science center called the Invention Factory Science Center -- a job that is expected to cost $25 million, said Clifford W. Zink. He is the executive director of the nonprofit development corporation, formed in 1985 to guide the district's rebirth. It is also developing the museum-science center, considered the keystone of the redevelopment site.
The redevelopment district is already home to the Roebling Market, 202,000 square feet of retail space with a supermarket and office and light industrial space that opened in June. Plans are also being advanced to reshape parts of the site into housing for the elderly, an arts center and a hockey arena. "We're taking a resource from the 20th century and making it viable for the 21st century," said Mr. Zink.
City and Mercer County officials see the rebirth of the Roebling complex along with that of the city's riverfront and a neighborhood near its downtown as the "triangle of economic development" to push Trenton's revival.
In Paterson, a $359,000 grant will help restore the Colt Gun Mill, in the 119-acre federally landmarked Great Falls Historic District, not far from the downtown. The derelict building is on a seven-acre site considered the area's largest and most deteriorated. Stabilizing what remains of the Colt Gun Mill "is a first and important step" of a larger plan to restore all seven acres, said Frank Blesso, Paterson's redevelopment director.
THE city has designated a developer to reshape the site into up to 230 housing units as well as some retail and public uses, Mr. Blesso said, adding that discussions were under way to turn the Colt Mill into a museum showcasing the history of the Colt revolver or waterpower.
"This is a crucial parcel in the redevelopment of the district," he added, saying that such redevelopment would, in turn, spur more development in the rest of the city.
In Atlantic City a $1 million grant will be used to help finance the rehabilitation of the 141-year-old Absecon Lighthouse at the core of the struggling South Inlet neighborhood in the shadow of the casinos. The 170-foot structure, with 228 steps leading to an octagonal glass tower, was built in 1855 and served for decades as a sentry and tourist attraction for city.
Plans include making the stairway safe and restoring the interior watchdeck so the lighthouse, closed since the early 80's, can be reopened to the public by next summer. The lightkeeper's house also will be renovated for use as a museum, said Sara R. Cureton, director of the project for the Inlet Public/ Private Association, a nonprofit group that supports the revival of the inlet sections of Atlantic City.
"We adopted the lighthouse, which is an important survivor of the city's past as a key" to that effort, said Ms. Cureton, noting that it was expected to attract over 70,000 visitors a year.
The Historic Trust is the only agency in the state to provide funds for "bricks and mortar" preservation projects. But a survey of 351 publicly owned historic properties conducted by the trust in late 1989 found that $400 million was needed to improve those properties. "We have only begun to scratch the surface," said Ms. Hawkins, noting that the trust was nearing the last round of grants that can be financed from the bond issues.
To that end efforts are advancing to find other ways to finance preservation projects, like piggy-backing on existing state programs, as well as to secure a stable source of funding.
"The hope," Ms. Hawkins said, "is that the Rutgers study will document the importance of history to the economy."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 11; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 300 words

HEADLINE: ART;
For Love of the Waterside Landscape

BYLINE: By DIANE NOTTLE 

 BODY:
TODAY, high-speed arteries like the Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway dominate transporation in New Jersey, but in times past, people and goods moved through the state on the quieter, gentler capillaries of its rivers and canals. Although waterways lost their economic importance as barges gave way to tractor-trailers, they are reviving and thriving as backdrops for recreation, thanks to projects like the Delaware and Raritan Greenway.
Formed in the mid-1980's, the Greenway seeks to conserve open space in the 400-square-mile watershed of the Delaware and Raritan Canal State Park. Its members are not the only New Jerseyans who find peace and beauty on the canal banks. Any Sunday afternoon, visionaries armed with paintbrushes and cameras may be seen in the Greenway, preserving nature in their own way. 
 In "Reflections Along the Canal," the Gallery at Bristol-Myers Squibb in Lawrenceville is currently showing more than 60 works in very different styles by four of these artists: three painters, Dorothy Bissell of Pennigton, Sylvia Cummings Kokatnur and Lucy Graves McVicker of Montgomery Township, and a photographer, Clem Fiori of Montgomery Township. "Before any gallery presentation had been proposed, they were painting and photographing their 'reflections' of their precious canal for their own sensibilities," writes the gallery's curator, Pamela V. Sherin, in the exhibition catalogue. And no doubt they will continue exploring the affinity between art and environment long after the show closes on Sept. 2. DIANE NOTTLE
 The Gallery at Bristol-Myers Squibb, Route 206, Lawrenceville, three miles south of Princeton. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays to 7 P.M.; Saturdays and sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Free. Information: (609) 252-6275.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Suddenly, Main Street Gives Malls a Run for Their Money

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: WESTFIELD

 BODY:
Even before the Gap moved into a pristine brick building here, the shopping district had potential. It was compact, with quaint architecture and a mix of restaurants and stores. The rents were reasonable, especially compared with those in fancy shopping malls. Above all, the residents were affluent and eager to spend.
It made sense, then, for one of the nation's most popular retailers to open a store on East Broad Street in 1992, and for a Gap Kids to spring up a year later. Other national chains have followed, and Westfield is acquiring what most suburban towns only dream of: a business district that is thriving, with enough well-known stores to give New Jersey's ubiquitous malls some competition. 
 Westfield is among a handful of affluent towns that have successfully courted national retailers in recent years, using them to boost their local economies and make a name for their downtowns. The towns -- which also include Englewood, Morristown and Ridgewood -- have aggressively marketed themselves to such stores as the Gap and Ann Taylor, and lately, the chains are responding more frequently.
Retail executives say that downtown locations have become more appealing as mall space has grown more expensive. Meanwhile, they say, customers are tiring of malls and looking for an old-fashioned shopping experience.
"A lot of people don't want to go to the mall anymore," said Arthur Tropp, vice president for real estate at Williams-Sonoma, the kitchenware chain based in San Francisco. "The street locations are proving a viable alternative in an awful lot of cases."
Even though sales in streetfront shops tend to be lower than those in their mall counterparts, net profits can be just as high, because they have fewer expenses. In addition to charging up to $65 per square foot in rent, malls charge extra for maintenance, security and other shared services. In a downtown shopping district, businesses might pay an extra tax for such services, but the cost is much lower, said Michael Fabrizio, executive director of the Morristown Partnership.
"It costs far fewer dollars to do business in downtown Morristown than at the Short Hills mall," said Mr. Fabrizio, whose organization has recruited national retailers like Starbucks and Staples. "At the end of the day, the downtown businesses can shut off the lights, lock the doors and that's the end of their expenses."
Towns that do not have giant malls in their backyards stand the best chance of attracting national retailers, Mr. Fabrizio said. Morristown and Westfield were both far enough from malls for the Gap to come in, but Millburn, which has courted national chains for several years, has not been so lucky. The problem is the Mall at Short Hills, which lies within its borders.
"The corporate offices of the Gap already have a thumbtack on their map where Millburn is, because they're in the mall," said Tara Braddish, executive director of the Downtown Millburn Development Alliance.
To speed the arrival of all kinds of businesses, Morristown, Millburn and several other towns have started special-improvement districts, which are run by nonprofit organizations.
The organizations market the towns to various businesses, organize special events and provide maintenance and other services that are paid for by an extra property tax. Westfield has a Main Street program, similar to a special-improvement district, and Michele Picou, the director, has praised the town to national chains and real estate investors for three years.
A year ago, Federal Realty Investment Trust, a Maryland-based real estate trust that buys downtown properties for retail development, bought an 11,000-square-foot property on Central Avenue. It is leasing the space to a brokerage firm and a national restaurant chain, said Anthony Schilling, president of Relocation Realty here.
After the Gap came to town in 1992, Mr. Schilling said, Sam Goody, Kay-Bee Toys, Starbucks and Garden Botanika, a bath shop, followed. Limited Express is opening a store this fall, and Ann Taylor, Banana Republic and Nine West have expressed interest, he said.
But Ms. Picou and several other planners pointed out that a downtown full of national chains is not ideal. The nationals help bring in customers from out of town, they said, but locally owned businesses add a dimension to downtown shopping districts that is lacking in malls.
"If you don't keep the good mom-and-pops, you wind up replicating a mall," said Peter Beronio, director of community services for Englewood, whose sprawling shopping district has national and regional chains and a number of independently owned stores. "We want to offer something the malls can't, like a little ethnic market or a unique craft store."
Local businesses are also valuable because they are more likely than national retailers to get involved in community events, said Lawrence Houstoun Jr., principal of the Atlantic Group, an urban development consulting firm in Cranbury.
"The manager of a national chain store is not always going to be a good participant in the local community," he said.
Mr. Houstoun said that any downtown, no matter how bustling, would have a hard time attracting more than a handful of national chains. For one thing, parking is almost always limited, while malls can keep adding parking decks, he said. And downtown properties tend to be old and small, not the kind most chains want to invest in.
"Most downtown space was built between 1890 and 1920, and you have to combine or expand properties to get the nationals interested," he said "The space in the malls was built for today's retailers, and they can always rebuild if it doesn't fit."
New Jersey's shopping malls are still attracting scores of national retailers -- in fact, many are doubling in size to accommodate larger, showier stores. Some real-estate investors say they have not been entirely successful placing national chains in downtown locations.
Charles Garner, a vice president of Federal Realty Investment Trust, said the company has had more luck bringing national chains to Connecticut's downtowns than New Jersey's.
"There are great markets in New Jersey, but there are also a whole lot of shopping centers," Mr. Garner said. "That limits the nationals who will locate on the streets."
But David Newton, the vice president of Palmer Square, a centrally managed shopping district in downtown Princeton, said he thinks the demand for downtown shopping will keep growing.
"People are coming back downtown because of the tremendous ambience," Mr. Newton said. "They want efficiency, but they also want to feel part of a community."

HEADLINE: A Costly Loo

 BODY:
To the Editor: If you remember the "penny loo" in London, you can forget about it when you shop at Harrods. It now costs one British pound to use the Harrods Luxury Washrooms, as they are called. So make sure that you have a pound ready.
There are exceptions. If you have a Harrods charge account, if you eat in one of their restaurants, if you are disabled, an expectant mother, or a child under 12 accompanied by an adult, then you can use the toilet without charge. But all others must pay. 
 We recently shopped at Harrods and spent the equivalent of about $170, but when my wife wanted to use the restroom she still had to pay a pound.
Harrods' justification was that the charge was introduced after extensive refurbishing of the washrooms and in response to the long lines that were created by the lack of public facilities in Knightsbridge. My answer to that was that Harrods doesn't have enough loos.
Incidentally, the pound is $1.60, which represents quite a bit of inflation from the penny loo.
 
 STANLEY NEHMER
Silver Spring, Md.
