HEADLINE: The Baby Bulbs;
The End of the Last Great Monopoly

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
JUST as Americans were resigning themselves to the marketing schemes of the telephone companies, another industry is entering the competitive business of dinner-time phone pitches, discount rate packages and rebate checks. Brace yourselves for the electric utilities.
From the days of Edison's first bulb, people have had virtually no choice as to who would supply their power. But at the urging of big customers, mainly manufacturers, many states have begun unfettering electric companies in the hopes that a hearty dose of competition will achieve what government regulators could not -- namely, lower prices and improved service. 
 At least 41 states, including California, New York and Texas, have adopted or are considering plans that would in most cases end utilities' monopolies, encouraging start-up companies and robust competition. Already, the Federal Government has ordered companies to open their wires to competing power suppliers so they can transmit low-cost electricity across state lines.
In some places, electric companies, either on their own or through the prodding of state regulators, have initiated experiments allowing competitors to sell power within their market areas. Such programs are under way in New Hampshire and central Illinois, and another is about to begin in Orange and Rockland counties in New York.
In New York State, the Public Service Commission has issued a plan that would allow consumers to shop among competing electric companies in the next two years. It does not spell out precisely how deregulation will happen, but has ordered five of the state's seven electric companies to submit plans this fall outlining ways to create a wholesale power market by 1998 and to allow retail competition by 1999.
What has prompted all this ferment in one of the last great American monopolies? The century-old industry has always been a natural for monopolization because only a few companies could raise the capital needed to build power plants and transmission lines. Over time, larger companies gobbled up smaller ones, delivering what many economists thought were more efficient services.
But in recent years, lower fuel costs and new technologies have greatly reduced the cost of building and operating power plants, enabling small startup companies to produce power more cheaply than older utilities. And sophisticated buyers, aware of such developments, have begun demanding that they be allowed to purchase power from independent suppliers.

 
 
A Political Issue
 Though many power companies have resisted such demands, the high cost of power has become such a hot political issue in some regions -- particularly the Northeast and California -- that legislators and governors are rushing to deregulate the industry.
"Power will probably be cheaper," said Prof. William W. Hogan at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "But there will also be so much diversity in the way it is marketed that people will forget what it was like to have just one supplier."
As most regulators envision the new system, the existing network of high-voltage transmission lines would remain essentially unchanged, operated by state agencies or regulated companies. Those companies would be required to open their systems to competing suppliers, much the same way that local phone companies allow long distance carriers to use their lines, for a price.
Where deregulation would refashion the industry would be at the two ends of the chain. Now, utilities control the flow of electrons from start to finish, building the generating plants, operating the transmission lines and servicing the meters in every home. Under most states' plans, the process would be divided into three tiers involving three different sets of companies.
At one end would be the generating companies, which would compete to sell power on a spot market, much like a commodities exchange. At the other end, retail providers would buy power wholesale and market it to homeowners and businesses. In between would be the wire companies, which would charge wholesalers and retailers access fees to use their lines. Prices at the wholesale and retail levels would be set by market forces, not government regulators, except perhaps in areas that cannot attract competition. Free-market advocates say competition will force utilities to abandon or modernize inefficient power plants and cut prices for everyone. But critics have raised serious questions for legislators, who in many states will have the final say over how deregulation takes place.
"Unlike your phone, electricity is less optional," said Dan Scotto, a utility analyst for Bear Stearns. "So there are a lot of social issues that will have to be ferreted out. And that means there will be enormous political pitfalls."
Who, for instance, would pay for the costly long-term power contracts or the crushing debt from building nuclear power plants that many utilities are saddled with? Ratepayers now pick up those costs; in a deregulated system, who would pay: shareholders, ratepayers or taxpayers?
Would deregulation encourage the "dirtier" and cheaper power produced by coal-burning plants? Would big users like manufacturers and shopping malls reap all the benefits of competition while homeowners see rising rates? Would companies "redline" low-income neighborhoods?
"In a deregulated environment, many suppliers are going to try to avoid customers they perceive to be riskier," said Nancy Brockway, a utility analyst with the National Consumer Law Center, a Boston-based nonprofit group. "We've seen it in banking and insurance."
One thing seems certain: deregulation is likely to unleash the feverish fight for customers that the telecommunications industry witnessed after the breakup of AT&T.
New Hampshire offers a glimpse of the future. There, two dozen companies are participating in a pilot program to sell power to a small number of businesses and homeowners.

 
 
Have a Tree
 So far, the results could only warm a capitalist's heart. Companies are bombarding potential buyers with advertisements, solicitation calls and gifts. One offered $25 rebate checks to potential customers, only to see a competitor up the ante with a $50 offer. Suppliers have given out free showerheads, spruce trees and almanacs -- even to people who refused their business. Several companies are marketing environmentally "clean" power produced by hydroelectric plants. And one is planning to package electric service with credit card and long-distance telephone services.
Whether this all translates into lower prices remains an open question. "With telephone deregulation, we still are dealing with many issues 10 or 15 year later, and there still is no local competition," said Ashok Gupta, an energy specialist with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "The promise of competition can be held out for a long time. We're just starting down the path in electricity and it could be a long time before the promise is kept."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After 100 years, the lines are opening up. Above, the power network in Colstrip, Mont. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORDHAM;
Is Fordham Plaza Space Too Costly, or Politically Incorrect?

BYLINE: By ANDREA K. WALKER 

 BODY:
When 1 Fordham Plaza opened in 1986, it was the first new office complex in the Bronx in more than 25 years. It was supposed to have been at the forefront of economic rebirth in the borough and a catalyst for growth along Fordham Road. And, to demonstrate commitment to the Bronx, the city and state moved in agencies that occupied more than half of the office space.
Last Wednesday, the leases on that office space expired. Arguing that rents were exorbitant, the city and state have chosen to move the agencies out; the city offices will move to available municipal space that will be rent-free. 
 But several Bronx officials, including Borough President Fernando Ferrer, said they suspected political motives. Mr. Ferrer, a Democrat who is considered a potential rival to Mr. Giuliani in next year's election, said he saw the same intentions in the Mayor's cancellation of car-free Sundays on the Grand Concourse.
"In the beginning I rejected that," he said. "I didn't believe anyone could be that small. But with the disallowing of bicycles on the Grand Concourse, and all the other small nuances, I've come to that conclusion -- albeit reluctantly."
Jack Deacy, a spokesman for the Mayor, said Mr. Ferrer's conclusion was "ludicrous." "When you look at the economic issues," he said, "the city is doing the prudent thing by moving the agencies out of a private building where they're charging $30 a square foot into city-owned space where we're not paying anything."
The agencies that are moving out are the Bronx office of the City Planning Commission, the Police Department's crime scene unit and its Bronx internal affairs unit, and the state Department of Housing and Community Renewal. The agencies occupy 130,000 square feet, or close to half the space. The Inspector General's office of the city Health and Hospitals Corporations, which occupies 15,000 square feet, is also moving, to lower Manhattan. In all, more than 400 employees will go.
The state agencies will continue to pay rent in their new quarters. Chase Enterprises, which owns Fordham Plaza, offered to reduce the rent from $30 per square foot to $19.25, but state officials said that was still more than the agencies will pay at their new sites.
Robert Hinckley, a spokesman for the state Office of General Services, which negotiates leases for state agencies, said the Chase offers "have not equaled other proposals we have out there and have not met the need of the tenant agency." He said the state would consolidate four offices at 60 Broad Street in lower Manhattan for rent in the "high teens" and would save millions of dollars through utility reductions and tax abatements.
Some small business owners along Fordham Road fear the relocations will reduce the number of customers. "Most of the people there are my customers," said Steve Katchis, owner of Splendid Deli and Restaurant, a block from Fordham Plaza. "I will lose a lot of people and a lot of business, especially during lunchtime and breakfast."
Ernest Porco, senior vice president for Chase Enterprises, said downsizing trends will make it difficult to find new tenants. Fordham Plaza has only been filled for two years and this is the first year it has made a profit, he said. ANDREA K. WALKER

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Let the Credit Cards Compete

BYLINE: By CHARLES E. SCHUMER; Charles E. Schumer, a Democratic Representative for parts of Brooklyn and Queens, is a senior member of the House Banking and Financial Services and Judiciary Committees.

 BODY:
TODAY, if you call your bank and ask for an American Express or Discover credit card, you'll be told to go elsewhere -- but don't bother trying another bank. Virtually all the 6,500 banks nationwide that issue credit cards belong to the Visa or Mastercard associations, and the handful of big banks that control these groups have collaborated successfully to eliminate unwanted competition.
What is good for these huge banks is manifestly bad for millions of American consumers and for many not-so-big banks because the status quo means a wholly unfair and artificial limit on their choice of products and services. 
 American Express, Discover and other potential credit card companies want the chance to offer their products through banks. The current restrictions in the credit card arena contradict the principles of open markets and price competition that are the hallmarks of a capitalist economy.
Consumers see banks as primary providers of financial services, and banks are delighted to encourage one-stop shopping. However, today's constricted choice of credit cards, which are arguably the average American's most important retail credit tool, is hardly consistent with the image of a "financial supermarket" brimming with a broad selection of competing products.
And as consumers take advantage of the increasing conveniences available through their bank accounts -- from debit cards to home banking on the Internet -- the ultimate reach of this anticompetitive arrangement could be astonishing.
Visa banks, those that belong to the country's largest credit card association, years ago issued a bylaw forbidding members to offer American Express or Discover cards to their customers. Just last month, Mastercard instituted the same prohibition for its United States members. Visa and Mastercard banks are allowed to issue each other's cards, however, and both groups are also allowed to issue Diners Club cards. Apparently, all competitors are not created equal.
Wouldn't it seem strange if all electronics stores agreed to sell only two brands of TV's or if all car dealers carried only G.M. and Chrysler? Shouldn't proprietors be able to sell what they think their customers want? Why should we think differently of banks? Banks shouldn't be required to offer a particular card, of course, but they should be free to choose which cards to offer.
Tellingly, Mastercard took its action fast on the heels of a decision by the European Union in May that rebuffed Visa International's attempt to impose a similar exclusionary policy in Europe. The European Union warned that interference with the freedom of European banks to choose which cards to issue would be "unacceptable," causing Visa to withdraw its proposal.
Why should Americans have fewer choices than the French and British? Have we become less committed to free markets than our European cousins are?
A few big banks dominate the United States credit card market through their control of the Visa and Mastercard associations. Of the 6,500 banks that issue these cards, the 10 largest issuers account for nearly 60 percent of total outstanding card balances. This is clearly why the big banks have such a keen interest in perpetuating the dominance of these two brands. The less competition there is, the less pressure there is to offer better fees, interest rates and features, and the more profitable is the franchise for these controlling banks.
As technology improves the ability to integrate more financial services, the value of this oligopolistic franchise is enhanced, and the ability to unfairly dominate an immense field of services escalates.
For example, consumers who want to use the increasingly popular debit cards may find themselves with few options to Visa or Mastercard products with exclusive access to the big Cirrus and Plus automated teller-machine networks the two associations own.
These anticompetitive conditions clearly violate the principles underpinning our antitrust laws and cry out for corrective action. In a very encouraging development, the Justice Department announced in June an antitrust inquiry into the "competitive issues involving the prohibition of certain joint ventures in the credit card industry." Mastercard's policy decision, occurring two weeks after this announcement, makes such an investigation even more urgent.
If we restore fair and healthy competition to the credit card market, everybody will benefit. American banks will be more competitive with each other and will continue as the best on the globe. American consumers will enjoy the greatest possible freedom of choice at the lowest possible cost, and it is against this standard that market conditions must be judged.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Jonathan Fried, Sharon Greenberger

 BODY:
Sharon Lee Greenberger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norton Greenberger of Mission Hills, Kan., is to be married today to Jonathan Louis Fried, a son of Janice C. Fried of Brooklyn and Justice Bernard J. Fried of Manhattan. Rabbi Morris Margolies is to perform the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in Kansas City, Mo.
The couple graduated from Wesleyan University. 
 Ms. Greenberger, 30, will keep her name. She is the president of the New York Information Technology District, a nonprofit economic-development organization in New York. She received a master's degree in city planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and was a Henry Luce Foundation Scholar in Seoul, South Korea. Her father is the chairman of the department of medicine at the University of Kansas Medical Center in Kansas City, Kan.
Mr. Fried, 29, is to be a third-year law student at New York University this fall. The bridegroom's mother is a saleswoman at Heights Berkeley, a real-estate agency in Brooklyn. His father is an Acting Justice of New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The bridegroom's stepmother is Judge Nina Gershon of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.

HEADLINE: Columbus Circle Folly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Herbert Muschamp's analysis of the "white elephant" at 2 Columbus Circle (appraisal, July 31) does not mention that the circle has the most repulsive conglomeration of architectural atrocities ever to inhabit a public plaza with the possible exception of Boston's Government Center. 
 What should be done with the site? It is too late for Columbus Circle to aspire to the 19th-century symmetry of a Parisian place or square. But if the Huntington Hartford and Edward Durell Stone folly is to be razed, it would create an opportunity for a vest-pocket park with a waterfall, trees and benches.
Columbus Circle could be made into a park-in-the-round with grass and shade trees replacing the dreadful macadam, and traffic could be diverted with tunnels under it connecting Eighth Avenue with Central Park West and upper and lower Broadway. Such a scenario would permit development of urban sanctuaries for New York's assaulted citizens.
 
HALTON ADLER MANN
San Francisco, July 31, 1996

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
After July's Shock: Foreign Stocks?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRUSH 

 BODY:
AFTER a scary July in the stock market, many American investors may be looking abroad this summer for more than just a nice vacation.
The greater interest might not be such a bad thing. There are several compelling reasons to go abroad that investors, spellbound by the domestic market's previously stellar performance, may have forgotten. 
 Some reasons are the stuff of many a client lecture by financial planners. Investing in foreign markets -- experts suggest a minimum period of three to five years -- both reduces risk and adds some zip to returns, for example. True, many overseas markets are volatile and any sudden selloff here will hurt other exchanges, too. But despite all the talk about globalization, economies and stock markets throughout the world are typically out of sync. That means when the American market is troubled, others may be thriving.
Moreover, about two-thirds of the world's stock-market value resides abroad; investing only or mostly at home means missing out on some good stocks. And many foreign economies, and thus their stock markets, simply grow faster than ours do.
But there are reasons of the moment to try foreign markets, too. Many of them are cheap, for example, despite some recent run-ups. In Europe, the markets in Ireland, Finland, Denmark, Sweden, Spain and Poland have attractively low price-earnings ratios, said John Mullin, a researcher with Smith Barney's Global Asset Allocation Group. Some of these countries, like Ireland and Poland, are turning in close to 5 percent annual growth as well.
Europe seems like a good investment in other ways. Spurred by globalization and competition, companies there are just now setting out on the cost cutting that has raised earnings and share prices for American companies.
"I've followed the German market very closely for 10 years and until last year, I never heard the words 'shareholder value,' " said Leah Zell, a co-manager of Acorn International, a small-cap fund. Now, she added, that's all she hears.
The Maastricht treaty on European unification may help investors, too. To comply with the treaty's budget guidelines and for other reasons, Germany, Italy and other countries are selling state companies and partly privatizing public pension plans. To do so, they need better equities markets -- and that means stronger shareholder rights.
The Continent's economic trends are favorable as well, fund managers say. "Europe is very early in the economic cycle and valuations are very low," Edith Thouin, director of European Equities for Zurich Kemper Investments in London, said. "It is overweight in our international funds."
Europe isn't the only place to find cheap stock markets and economic growth. "The emerging markets today are growing at at least twice the rate for the developed economies, or about 6 percent a year," said Josephine Jimenez, senior portfolio manager of Montgomery Emerging Markets. "We expect that to be the long-term growth rate as well."
In this risky area of international investing, Ms. Jimenez prefers countries that are lifting trade barriers, controlling inflation and the like. Such steps, she says, will put more money in consumers' pockets.
What will the consumers be buying? "About half of the 4.5 billion people in the developing countries are under the age of 19," said Ms. Jimenez, whose fund owns stock in about 200 companies in 30 countries. Thus, she said, "certain sectors are bound to grow very quickly, such as housing and consumer goods like home appliances."
Regionally, Ms. Jimenez's fund is heavy in Latin America and Europe. She likes Brazil because of its large population, natural resources, steady progress in revamping its economy and the low price-earnings ratio of its stock market. China and Mexico also have cheaply priced markets and good growth prospects, she said.
Of course, good foreign investments can also be found where the macroeconomic picture is not sparkling. Britain is not high on Ms. Thouin's list of hot venues, but she does like Dixons Group P.L.C., a leading British retailer. One big reason: Dixons' purchase of PC World, the largest seller of PC's in Britain, where only about 10 percent of households own computers compared with about 30 percent in the United States.
For investors shopping overseas, which diversified mutual funds look good? One fund recommended by both Thurman Smith, editor of Equity Fund Outlook in Boston, and Ken Gregory, editor of the No Load Fund Analyst in San Francisco, is Janus Overseas. Started in 1994, the fund has earned 15.02 percent this year through July 31. The fund's manager, Helen Young Hayes, also runs the Janus Worldwide fund, which as of June 30 had produced a five-year average annual return of 21.13 percent.
Both newsletter editors also like Harbor International Growth, another young fund, which has returned 11.79 through July 31.
Thomas Saler, author of "All About Global Investing" (John Wiley & Sons), likes T. Rowe Price International Stock and Vanguard International Growth. Both funds have operating expenses of less than 1.8 percent and have outperformed Morgan Stanley's Europe Australia Far East (or EAFE) index during the last 10 years.
Americans can also internationalize their assets by buying individual foreign stocks traded here as American depository receipts. Mexico's Grupo Radio Centro, for instance, has a 37 percent share of Mexico City's radio market and carries very little debt. Ms. Zell likes the company because insiders own 40 percent of it and the A.D.R.'s, which closed on Friday at $6.875, are far less than their level of about $19 before the Mexican stock market crash 20 months ago.
Some analysts also like Gucci, the Italian luxury-goods producer, which closed Friday at $64.50. Ms. Hayes expects the company to have annual earnings growth of 25 percent for the next three years, both because its new management team has revitalized the brand and overhauled distribution, and because high-end goods tend to be immune to economic cycles. Gerald Moran, who manages the Scudder Global Discovery fund, expects Gucci's aggressive move into Japan to produce results soon.
Another promising A.D.R. is that of Rentokil Group, a British provider of pest control, landscaping, washroom maintenance and other business services. Ms. Hayes expects 20 percent earnings growth from Rentokil, which recently bought BET, another business-services provider. Rentokil, which closed Friday at $62.125, should be able to improve BET's margins, Ms. Hayes said.
As investors consider these possibilities, they should recall that foreign investing has a danger domestic investors never court: currency risk. But here too, the present looks attractive. The dollar is now trading at high values against many currencies, making it a good time to buy foreign assets.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Much Ado About Budgeting

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the scene in "Hamlet" in which Polonius, the old-fogey adviser, gives a windy lecture to his departing son, Laertes? "Neither a borrower nor a lender be," he counsels at one point; it's the sole financial tip in the speech, and it's probably sufficient, given the more pressing problems of the young adults at Elsinore.
Today's 20-somethings may have it easier than Hamlet's crowd; at least most of them aren't up on the roof meeting with ghosts and contemplating regicide. But scary economic limitations have supposedly left them dazed and confused. They see a tough job market or, if they are working, the specters of downsizing and downward mobility. Or so goes the conventional wisdom. 
 Like the prince in Shakespeare's play, Americans in their 20's and early 30's have acquired a reputation for being indecisive, aimless -- whiny, even. And unlike Polonius's son, they don't listen politely to parental bromides. Try telling a Generation X-er who survives on credit cards that "borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry."
Not everyone in this cohort is brooding, of course. In fact, in some MTV surveys, as we will see a little later on, the Gen-Xers seem to defy the stereotype. But hey, capitalism is tough; it's dog-eat-dog. What's a puppy to do?
Two books aimed at this age group could help. "Get a Financial Life: Personal Finance in Your 20's and 30's" (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $11)," by Beth Kobliner, is a highly readable and substantial guide to the grown-up realms of money and business. And for information with an attitude, there's "Now What?! A Guide to Jobs, Money, and the Real World" (MTV Books/Pocket Books, $12) by J. D. Heiman.
Ms. Kobliner, a writer for Money magazine who is as young as her target audience, doesn't strain to establish her generational credentials. Her idea of a slacker's confession is that she didn't start saving for retirement until she was 26. But "Get a Financial Life" knows what youth is wrestling with -- for example, those sumo-sized debts incurred in the college years.
The author adjusts her preferred financial ratios accordingly. Ideally, personal debt, not counting a mortgage, shouldn't exceed 20 percent of annual take-home pay, she writes, but "of course, anyone with student loans probably fails the debt-rule test." She suggests ways of paying down debt more quickly -- there's still pain, but less of it, thanks to smart planning and maybe the judicious use of a low-interest credit card.
Backed up by bibliographies, source lists and useful phone numbers, this book could be tucked into one of those ubiquitous backpacks to guide novices through the thickets of apartment rentals, mortgage applications, taxes and more. Its strength is in explaining both the principles and the practicalities involved in each chunk of the landscape. Banks: best used only for checking and for their teller machines. Auto accident coverage: did you know that students with good grades can get significantly reduced premiums? Investments: for first-timers, money-market mutual funds are best; the author explains why. Retirement: the 401(k) is an "amazing deal," she confides.
And Ms. Kobliner passes my personal test when it comes to life insurance. "The purpose of life insurance is simple," she says firmly. "If you die, it protects the people who rely on your income." So use that 20-something skepticism to resist the sales pitches that try to convince you otherwise.
In "Now What?!" the MTV book written by J. D. Heiman, the landscape shifts a bit. Here, style rules. There are cartoons, jumbled typography, and lots of references to the heroes of popular culture this generation likes to worship self-mockingly: the Brady Bunch, for example. At times, all this gets in the way of the content (which is pretty substantial, actually), and the author comes off like a nerdy teacher trying to be hip. Downsized corporations are characterized as "Kate Moss-like," for example. Sometimes, though, the tone is just right. At work, the author says, "dress for the job you want to have, be clean and cover your navel."
Interestingly, this MTV book assumes quite a harsh tone when discussing credit-card debt, calling it a "horrendous monkey on the back of young America." The book covers budgets, insurance, taxes, job-hunting, working and housing and along the way wanders into spheres not covered by the Kobliner book: how to handle E-mail at work, for example. "Catty comments can end up in the wrong hands with a slip of your finger," the author notes.
And he addresses the problems of balancing values and work. Wall Street is conservative, he cautions; be sure you can handle that before suiting up.
Much of the fun, and some of the failings, of this book comes from its attitude that its audience is no doubt clueless when it comes to the weird financial world it is explaining. Yet the author cites MTV surveys of young people that clash with this image. Asked to name an "appealing" job, for example, more than half of 800 respondents put owning a business at the top of the list. Talk about a willingness to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune.

HEADLINE: Revamping Welfare, Rebuilding Lives

BYLINE: By Steve Goldsmith; Steve Goldsmith, Mayor of Indianapolis, is the Republican nominee for Governor of Indiana.

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
Last week's historic action to dismantle the Federal welfare system could not have come too soon. A program that began with the best of intentions -- providing help for families who lost their primary source of income through no fault of their own -- has contributed to the breakdown of the family and stymied efforts at urban revitalization. The new law provides the best chance in decades to improve the lot of cities and the people who live in them.
But while the first critical step has been taken, it is only a first step. The next is even more important. 
 The authority now leaving Washington must pass through the state governments and continue down to the local level. Replacing a bloated, unresponsive Federal bureaucracy with bloated, unresponsive state bureaucracies will not do much to help the urban poor. Communities must have the authority to break up the welfare bureaucracy and incorporate welfare into local attempts to rebuild families and revitalize neighborhoods.
From my perspective as Mayor of America's 12th-largest city, the problem with welfare is not that it costs too much. Most of my constituents would not complain if the dollars spent on welfare created happy, healthy families and quickly returned people to the work force. But the inescapable truth is that welfare has done neither, and America's cities have paid the price.
How can they begin to reap the benefits of the new era in welfare? Here are four ways.
* Cities can integrate public assistance with a program that encourages responsible fatherhood. Under the existing welfare program, intact families are punished by the system, and the government takes the place of the father. In my state, a mother qualifies for welfare only if she does not marry her children's father, and a teen-age mother qualifies only if she leaves home. When we collect child support from deadbeat dads, the money does not go to the mother -- it goes to the government, which then turns around and writes a welfare check to the mother.
The long-term consequences of failing to rebuild families will be fatal for cities. David Blankenhorn, author of "Fatherless America," got it right when he wrote, "Unless we reverse the trend of fatherlessness, no other set of accomplishments . . . will succeed in arresting the decline of child welfare and the spread of male violence."
In Indianapolis, we have brought together representatives of the city, including law enforcement, schools and the health department, to create an initiative called Rebuilding Families. We intend to reverse the old incentives by tying benefits to positive behavior -- work, education, marriage -- and toughening the consequences for young fathers who dodge their responsibilities.
Yes, this may cost more in the short term. But the long-term benefit of encouraging family formation far outweighs any short-term increase in the cost of administering welfare.
* Cities can transform welfare into a jobs program. Economic revitalization of troubled neighborhoods is virtually impossible when their residents don't take available jobs. One reason is that welfare often pays more than work, when you take benefits into account. Another is that people on welfare often lack the incentive and the skills to take and hold jobs.
In Indianapolis, a nonprofit organization called Eastside Community Investments helps residents develop what its president, Dennis West, calls "marketable character." It gives its clients what most employers say they want most: the ability to show up for work on time and a willingness to learn.
* Cities can dismantle the welfare bureaucracy. Recently I met with a group of 30 welfare recipients enrolled in an innovative job-training program in New York City. I asked them if their welfare caseworkers had helped them find jobs. One woman said yes; the other 29 laughed out loud.
The current welfare system is like most government agencies. It traps good people in a bad system. Instead of judging the performance of welfare caseworkers by the number of people they successfully place in the work force, government judges them on how many paperwork errors they make.
Instead of paying welfare workers to hand out checks, we must pay organizations for finding people jobs. We need a competitive, performance-based system with many providers.
Long before there was such a thing as Aid to Families With Dependent Children, voluntary charities were helping the poor, the elderly and the sick. These traditional institutions have been weakened by government's drive to acquire a monopoly on the business of helping people, but they are still our best hope. They should be given a chance to compete for contracts to deliver services to the needy.
* Cities can be flexible. No one has figured out how to solve the problems associated with welfare because there is no one solution. The much-touted "two years and out" provision of the new welfare law may sound impressive, but it does not address the immense variety of problems experienced by those who apply for government assistance. For able-bodied welfare recipients, two years is too long. For the disabled, it may not be long enough.
With welfare controlled at the local level, delivered by a variety of competing organizations whose workers are focused on the goal of getting recipients into long-term jobs, we can have a system with the flexibility and heart.
But if local governments are not given the authority to change the system, then all we will have accomplished is a cruel continuation of the old one -- trapping people in a bad system for two years, and then kicking them out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The World;
Free Trade? Don't Sell Us That.

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
NOT so long ago, Rosa Molina felt she was doing pretty well in life. But now, like many Mexicans, she feels as if she's been mugged by a 19-month economic crisis. Her once-sunny outlook has withered to a brooding cynicism.
Ms. Molina's monthly salary as a stitcher in a garment factory rose during the early 1990's to about $700 a month, and she even began thinking about buying a modest house. Then, in December 1994, the Government devalued the peso by 40 percent and soon Ms. Molina was laid off. A single mother in her 20's, she searched for work for six months before pleading her way into another factory -- at $160 a month. 
 "Now they pay me whatever they want," Ms. Molina says bitterly, pulling her 3-year-old son close to her skirt during an interview in Mexico City's central plaza. In recent months, she has been nursing her anger over Mexico's economic calamity. Like many of her compatriots, she suspects that Mexico's association with the United States and Canada in the North American Free Trade Agreement is one cause of her downward slide. Meanwhile, she has followed with fury the reports that Raul Salinas, the brother of the former President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, amassed more than $120 million during his brother's tenure and that his partners included some of Mexico's wealthiest oligarchs.
"It's frightening, because all this thievery is just sinking our country further," Ms. Molina said.
In other words, disgust with corruption and with Nafta are intertwined in her mind: Like many Mexicans, ever cynical about their officials, she is skeptical of any deals they make.
Opinion polls show that Ms. Molina's bruised perceptions about her country's economy, the job market and how Nafta and political graft may be hurting both are shared by many Mexicans. And it matters little to them that Mexican and American officials and economists believe something quite different: that the country has begun a robust recovery, that the scandals are having little effect on the marketplace, and that Nafta has in fact helped Mexico.

 
 
The Case for Nafta
 Experts, for example, make a convincing case that Mexico's misery has been caused not by Nafta but by the Government's clumsy devaluation of the peso in December 1994 and by the subsequent recession. In that context, the trade treaty, which was preceded by reforms opening Mexico to foreign investment, seems almost certainly to have saved Mexico from meltdown. When the crisis came, the Clinton Administration assembled a $50 billion package of emergency loans, offered by the United States and other governments, which stabilized the peso, partly because Nafta had irrevocably tied Mexico's economy to the United States. (Mexico eventually borrowed $12.5 billion from the United States, about three-quarters of which it has repaid.)
From the first months of the crisis early last year, tire, auto and other manufacturers, vegetable farmers and other stricken Mexicans took advantage of the peso devaluation and the reduced trade barriers to greatly increase northbound exports; Mexico has enjoyed hefty trade surpluses with the United States ever since. (During the first four months of this year, the surplus was $2.6 billion.) The surging exports have helped create new jobs to replace some of those lost. So it is clear that most Mexicans would be in far worse shape today without Nafta.
But that isn't how many Mexicans see it, among them truckers and other businessmen who complain that the treaty has threatened them with overwhelming American competition. A national sounding taken in June by the Mexico City newspaper Reforma found that 67 percent of Mexicans believed that the Government was having little or no success with the free-trade treaty. That marks a considerable shift from 1993, before the treaty took effect, when Mexicans were vastly more hopeful than Americans or Canadians about the pact.Today citizens in all three countries view the treaty with suspicion.
Mexican views have grown gloomier on other topics as well. Reforma's June poll found that 86 percent of Mexicans believe that the economy has either not improved, or has actually worsened, since the dust settled after the crash last year; 64 percent expect it to remain mired at its current level or deteriorate further in 1997.

 
 
Grumpiness Reigns
 It is also a common view that wanton looting of the public treasury by the last Government helped plunge the country into crisis, and 8 out of 10 Mexicans believe that the current President, Ernesto Zedillo, is making "little or no progress at all" against corruption, the poll indicates. "The Mexican people were far more optimistic during the last presidency," said Rafael Gimenez, Reforma's 31-year-old chief pollster. "Now they're grumpy and unhappy."
The contrast between these dispirited public sentiments and the views voiced by officials here and in Washington could hardly be more dramatic. Mr. Zedillo and Treasury Secretary Guillermo Ortiz have repeatedly said Mexico's economy is showing signs of mounting vigor, although Mr. Ortiz acknowledged that "it will be at least a few years before we're able to reach the levels of consumption that we had before the crisis."
In an interview, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, James Jones, insisted that the corruption scandals were not slowing growth, especially as measured by investment. Direct foreign investment -- money spent to build factories or otherwise expand businesses, as opposed to indirect investments in the money markets -- dropped to $5.5 billion in 1995 from a peak of $8 billion in 1994, but is rebounding and is likely to hit $10 billion this year, Mr. Jones said. "The ongoing investigation of Raul Salinas does not appear to have affected foreign direct investment," he said.
On this issue there is considerable debate, however. "In several recent cases the effects of the political scandals have been straightforward," said Jonathan Heath, an economist in Mexico City. Last month a string of Mexico's most eminent businessmen acknowledged that they had conducted murky financial transactions, still under investigation, with Raul Salinas, who is in jail here on murder and illegal enrichment charges. Shortly thereafter, Mexico's stock market took a huge tumble, and several of the companies hurt most were those led by Mr. Salinas's newly revealed partners, Mr. Heath said.
"There's been an increase in investors' perception of risk, derived from the scandals and other things, which cause people to ask how events in Mexico will all turn out," Mr. Heath said.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

THE SOCIAL COMPACT
Ending Welfare as We Know It
The New Deal, that 60-year-old foundation of modern government, quaked when the Democratic President agreed to a bill sailing through the Republican Congress that would end Washington's guarantee of cash assistance for the poor. President Clinton signed off on the bill, which will affect tens of millions of people, including one-fifth of the families in America with children. "The current system is broken," he said, and half the Democrats in the House agreed, with a sense of resignation, while almost all the Republicans went along enthusiastically. The Senate followed, by a lopsided vote of 78 to 21. Under the new system, states will manage their own programs with their own rules. The intention is to get the head of every family working within two years, or the family loses benefits.

REPUBLICAN UPLIFT
Gump's Last Fan
Bob Dole's campaign for Director in Chief, or First Critic, took him to Hollywood for the sequel to his lacerating address of last year, when he accused film makers of producing a "nightmare of depravity." This time he took a different tack, saying that the marketplace rewards movies that "raise our vision of life instead of dragging us down." "Schindler's List," "Apollo 13" and "Forrest Gump" were on his list of personal faves.

WHAT CORRECTION?
Clipping Right Along
The economy boomed in the spring, clipping along at a 4.2 percent annual growth rate, but now seems to have slowed to a pace that Wall Street finds very comfortable. The second-quarter's growth in gross domestic product was the fastest in two years, the Commerce Department said, and came on top of slight inflation. But last month, executives who make buying decisions reported weaker demand. And job creation slowed in July, sending the unemployment rate a bit higher. The bond and stock markets liked those signs that the Fed would not have to quiet the economy by raising interest rates. The Dow industrials ended the week at 5,679.83, up 206.77 points, marking a substantial recovery from the market's jitters of mid-July.

BLACK COLLEGES
Graduating to the Big Leagues
Talk about gardening. Bill Cosby tilled the soil, and Johnnetta Cole has brought in the harvest. Dr. Cole heads Spelman College, a historically black women's college in Atlanta that in a coup has raised $114 million. That puts it in a fund-raising league with Bryn Mawr and Mount Holyoke. Camille and Bill Cosby started the ball rolling when they gave $20 million; since then, foundations have anted up $27 million and corporations and alumnae $15 million. When meeting with businessmen, Dr. Cole is known to give them stoles of kente cloth, the multicolored weaving from West Africa, and just might happen to bring along a tax lawyer specializing in gift giving.

STAR-SPANGLED COLOMBO
Imperial Hollywood
Mr. Dole might not be far off when he points out the prowess of Entertainment Americana. For good clean, middle-brow fun, what could be more Americana than "The Rockford Files," "Colombo" and "Miami Vice." They may be cold at home, but they're hot overseas. Hollywood, in this case the production company MCA, is thrilled. MCA sold broadcast rights to those and other television shows and movies for $1.5 billion -- and that's just for the German rights. MCA is also getting a cool billion for some pay-TV rights in Germany.

RETAIL THERAPY
Another Spring for House & Garden
Conde Nast killed House & Garden after a mere 92 years in business, but the magazine can't seem to stay dead. Its return issue is a giant -- it has 207 pages of ads -- but it still begs the question of the revival's survival, because the category of shelter magazines is mighty crowded. But advertisers are convinced that baby boomers are as zealous about their houses and gardens as they are about their 401(k)'s. "It's like hero worship," says Mario Buatta, a designer. "They are looking in the windows of houses where they would never be invited." For tone, the new issue deconstructs the crystal chandelier, and Cynthia Ozick rhapsodizes about the ladle.

PHONE FIGHT
Bells Protect and Defend
The time is arriving for local phone companies to open up their monopolies to the long-distance carriers. The F.C.C. issued elaborate rules -- that is, if you consider 500 pages of rules elaborate -- determining how the Bell companies must open their networks to competition later this year. Bell stocks had been suffering in trepidation for months, but with the rules finally out, the stocks bounced back, and some analysts predict that in the long run, the Bells might retain their local dominance.

 FREE MARKETS
Subsidies Under the Glare
The conservative winds coursing through Washington are rattling other capitals of the welfare state, like Bonn. And now even Tel Aviv is trembling, to the alarm of Histadrut, the labor federation that represents almost half of all Israeli workers. With a Newtish regard for the free market, the new Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, wants to trim back the state's central economic role. He plans to cut the vast network of subsidies to families and state businesses and to bring on competition in areas like bus routes and oil refineries. One commentator, Hanah Kim, loudly said that Mr. Netanyahu was "striking the death chord of social solidarity in Israel," and the debate has only just begun.
 
MUTUAL FUNDS
After Magellan, More Navigating
Jeffrey Vinik hasn't taken long to let his bruises heal from his wild ride at Fidelity Investments's Magellan Fund. He left there two months ago after turning the giant fund in a cautious direction a bit prematurely. Now he is said to be in talks with George Soros about managing some of the billions under his care.

HEADLINE: Vision Things;
Democrats Are Fat, Happy and Adrift . . .

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOT since, well, the election of Bill Clinton in 1992 have Democrats sounded so triumphant. If Mr. Clinton maintains his lead in the polls, they note with a touch of braggadocio, he will be the first Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt to be elected to a second full term. Party leaders no longer dismiss out of hand talk that maybe, just maybe, Democrats will retake Congress in November.
To top it off, many prominent Democrats were even willing last week to put aside the policy consequences of Mr. Clinton's decision to sign the Republican welfare bill -- and to repudiate a guarantee that had been a legacy of the party for 60 years. For now, they are satisfied that they have snatched another crucial issue from Mr. Dole. 
 But the expectations for a lovefest later this month at the party's convention in Chicago may obscure the fact that the world's oldest continuing political party is suffering from an identity crisis. It is wracked by ideological divisions and starved for fresh ideas, lurching between securing its liberal base and luring support from the right.
Perhaps the only reason the Democrats look so formidable right now is that their standard bearer has proved more agile than Mr. Dole at taking ownership of the Republicans' own ideas. And the relatively high poll ratings of one man -- the President -- have apparently given his party a false sense of security.
"The smugness of Democrats these days has to do with the fact that we have a better horse," said Ted Mondale, a state Senator in Minnesota whose father, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, is Ambassador to Japan. "I don't think there's a clear definition about what Democrats are all about. People just don't think we're relevant."
Former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, whose "new ideas" credo helped him come close to knocking off Mr. Mondale in the 1984 Democratic primaries, said that from education to the military to technology, his party still has not fashioned themes for the post-cold-war era. "The party is intellectually adrift," he said. "The Democratic Party has got less than a decade to really become a progressive reform party with some new domestic and international focus -- or there will be a new independent party in America."
And former Gov. Richard Lamm of Colorado, a longtime Democrat who is seeking the nomination of Ross Perot's Reform Party, declared last month: "Neither the Republicans nor the Democrats want to deal with our most pressing issues. They have hit the snooze alarm and they've gone back to sleep."
White House officials argue that Mr. Clinton can claim a significant record: raising the minimum wage, revamping welfare and putting together a modest yet important package providing continued health insurance for people who move from job to job.
Maybe Mr. Clinton deserves praise for finding common ground with the party that controls Congress. And something might be said for old ideas. After all, new ideas are not always good ideas; the President's last bold initiative was comprehensive health care.
But the liberal Democrats in Congress -- torn between yielding to Mr. Clinton's ever more moderate tendencies and remembering that their party's moderate ranks were thinned in the 1994 rout -- have had no more success at agenda setting. After years of simply bashing Speaker Newt Gingrich, Democrats have unveiled a campaign blueprint calling for new toughness on welfare but also containing the usual nostrums like preserving Medicare and Social Security.
The platform mimics the Republican anti-government pitch, while suggesting that Republicans are too extreme. "That is what today's Democratic Party offers," the document says. "The end of the era of big government, a final rejection of the misguided call to leave our citizens to fend for themselves -- and bold leadership into the future."
To be fair, Democrats have long been a party of coalitions and contention. And Republicans also can be said to be bereft of new ideas. In grandly announcing a new economic plan tomorrow, for instance, Mr. Dole risks being accused of serving warmed-over Reaganomics. But at least it is clear what Republicans stand for: lower taxes, less government regulation and the notion that people can make it on their own.
Democrats have other troubles. Defeats and retirements have nearly wiped out the party in the South. Fewer younger voters everywhere are registering as Democrats. And despite high expectations for Vice President Al Gore, there is a scarcity of promising young leaders. That is why, when Democrats talk about finding a young, dynamic politician to deliver the convention's keynote address, only one name, Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, comes up regularly.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, general chairman of the Democratic Party, insists that reports of fissures in the party are exaggerated. "We've seen tremendous unity in this party," he said. "Maybe some people find unity within the Democratic Party to be something of an oxymoron. But it's one of the reasons we're doing as well as we are."
Others argue that the Democratic Party will eventually have to resolve an identity crisis. "If Bill Clinton had a Democratic Congress," said John R. Petrocik, a political scientist at the University of California at Los Angeles, "they'd be at war with each other for the kinds of things he's proposing."
If anything, the internal debate is over degrees of conservatism: No longer are Democrats debating the need for welfare reform, just the extent of it. No longer are Democrats disputing the merits of a balanced budget, only the mechanics. And no longer are Democrats mocking the calls for restoring family values.
There's nothing like success to silence the critics. Last summer, Representative Dave Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, was furious about Mr. Clinton's budget-balancing plan, and said, "If you don't like the President's position on a particular issue, you simply need to wait a few weeks."
But now Mr. Obey concedes that "we're certainly riding far better than we thought." He argues that the Democrats do stand for something: "To use Government as a backdrop to make sure that certain norms of justice are met -- that means protecting workers and their right to be dealt with honestly in the work place, and protecting their pensions from unfair ripoffs."

 
 
What's the Alternative?
 Even leaders of Americans for Democratic Action, a bastion of liberalism, are willing to forgive Mr. Clinton for his welfare decision, for the moment. "If Dole becomes President, it will only strengthen the more radical conservatives," said Jack Sheinkman, the A.D.A. president. "If we re-elect Clinton, I feel we will be moving in an entirely different direction."
One sign of the ferment just below the surface among Democrats is the relationship between Mr. Clinton's most influential political advisers: Harold M. Ickes, an unapologetic liberal, and Dick Morris, who devoted years to working for Republicans. The two men have never particularly liked each other and certainly have not respected each other's politics. But at meetings with Mr. Clinton, they sit as if they were on the same side. They are -- at least until November.

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: VISION THINGS;
. . . As Dole Seeks a Verb

BYLINE: KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE day last March, as Bob Dole was nailing down the Republican Presidential nomination, he bounded up the steps to his airplane and turned to wave. There was no crowd below, just a couple of aides and a stray reporter. A playful Mr. Dole waved anyway and bellowed: "And if elected . . . ."
Then he went blank. His caricature over, Mr. Dole dropped his arm, turned and stepped inside his cabin. 
 Unlike most politicians, Mr. Dole, a lifelong legislator, is not comfortable making promises. But with his party's national convention next week and the election only three months away, he is being forced now to make a number of commitments that will define his candidacy as clearly as anything he has said or done so far.
Tomorrow, he is to unveil his long-awaited economic plan. At week's end, he is to announce his choice of a running mate. In between, his party is to hammer its platform into place. And next week, he is to give the most important speech of the campaign.
"People have been waiting for him to say something that would give himself a larger definition than Senate majority leader," said Richard Fenno, a political scientist at the University of Rochester.
This week's "declarative statements" should give the campaign a new momentum going into the convention, said John Buckley, Mr. Dole's director of communications. The Dole advisers have long hoped the convention would be the campaign's turning point -- when a bold economic plan, an inspired choice for a running mate and a well-crafted, well-delivered acceptance speech could help Mr. Dole trim President Clinton's 20-point lead in the polls.
But committing himself and laying his cards on the table are antithetical to Mr. Dole's nature.
As a legislator, and certainly as Senate majority leader, Mr. Dole's job was not to make promises but to make deals. The Senator's task was to follow agendas, not set them. Opening negotiations with 99 other individual egos by announcing an end goal would virtually guarantee failure. "He never makes promises until he can count the votes," said Burdett Loomis, a political scientist at the University of Kansas. "It's his legislative soul."
Mr. Dole has also shied from making promises because in a sense they are irrelevant. His candidacy was premised on character and leadership. His experience was his promise.
Mr. Buckley said that when he asked Mr. Dole recently what he was most proud of in his 35 years in Congress, Mr. Dole answered: "I kept my word." Mr. Buckley added, "Dole, in his laconic, sincere, rough-hewn way does not make promises that he doesn't intend to deliver," something Mr. Buckley hopes to contrast with what he describes as President Clinton's ease in making promises and his difficulty keeping them.
But over all, Mr. Dole's tendency to withhold has not helped. When he was first feeling his way along the campaign trail, the most definitive pledge he could muster was this: "I will not take you over a cliff."
Some advisers feared that Mr. Dole's reluctance to tell voters what he would do as President reinforced the idea that he had no reason for running -- except that it was his turn after toiling so long for the party.
"Politics is about making promises and struggling to keep them," one adviser said. Another Republican close to the campaign said: "Promises are central to why you are running. That's why his campaign has seemed so empty -- he never made any."
Mr. Dole has attempted to compensate for his lack of promises by using phrases like "in a Dole Administration" or "when I'm in the White House" to describe what might be different if he ran the country. But he still avoids specifics. Complaining about the Endangered Species Act recently in California, he said: "I know all this is very important, the fairy shrimp and the kangaroo rat and other things, but people are important too. You're important, and you will be important in a Dole Administration." The audience cheered.
Sometimes, in a particularly deft act of circularity, Mr. Dole will make a promise, but only about promises: "We need a President who will tell you something and then deliver on it," he said last month. "That will be my promise to California."
This is in vivid contrast to Mr. Clinton, who by this stage in 1992 had made so many detailed proposals on so many fronts that his aides worried he was raising expectations too high. (The quantity of Mr. Clinton's promises prompted President Bush to note that Mr. Clinton had more solutions than there were problems.)
Instead, Mr. Dole tends to give a nod toward already existing legislation. But even in speaking favorably of, say, school vouchers, or of a plan to deny public education to the children of illegal immigrants, Mr. Dole avoids making a specific pledge. As a result, there is little in his campaign that bears his personal imprint, and voters tell pollsters they are fuzzy about what he stands for.
Now, 16 months into his formal candidacy, it may be time for Mr. Dole to start making commitments.
Statements like the one he gave last week when he emerged from the movie "Independence Day" -- "We won, the end, leadership, America, good over evil" -- are not likely to move a nation.
If Mr. Dole is going to be more effective, he needs to start using verbs, says Roderick P. Hart, a professor of communication and government at the University of Texas. Verbs establish "the language of leadership," Mr. Hart says, allowing someone to say, "Follow me over the hill, men." Once Mr. Dole commits to where he wants to go, then he can use verbs to ask the nation to join him.
"What is a promise," Mr. Hart asks, "but a verb?"

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
So, You Want to Hold an Olympics

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE between the constant carping of 30,000 journalists from around the world, bus drivers afraid to drive their buses on the freeway and the pipe bomb at Centennial Park, the same thought occurred to a lot of Atlantans early last week -- what have we got ourselves into?
But as the Olympics lumbers to a close much like a soap opera with overwrought twists and turns but a triumphant ending, cities around the country are salivating at the thought of being in Atlanta's shoes. 
 Their reasons vary from ego to economics but they often come down to this: at a time when taxpayers are tight with their money and great civic empire builders have gone the way of the Olympic star without a product to endorse, the Olympics has become for cities the biggest single economic event on the planet.

 
 
Move Over, Izzy
 "The Olympics have replaced the World Fair as the new gimmick of city building," said Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. New York is one of the cities where there has been substantial talk of bidding for the 2008 Summer Olympics.
"We haven't had a major new highway or park in New York since Robert Moses," Mr. Moss said. "The Olympics would be the 21st-century equivalent of Robert Moses, the one way you can mobilize support for massive public investment" (which is what Mr. Moses last did with the 1964-65 World's Fair as his vehicle).
Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani is forming a group of city officials and business leaders to consider bringing the 2008 Olympics to New York City. Daniel Doctoroff, a financier who has begun efforts to stir up interest, said: "Seeing what they did in Atlanta and transposing New York on the event," he said, "I'm even more convinced New York would be the perfect host for the Olympics."
Expressions of interest have also surfaced in Boston, Chicago and other cities. A Houston businessman, Jim (Mattress Mac) McIngvale, best known for late-night TV ads, was here hosting a splashy party to drum up interest in a Texas Olympics in 2008, much to the dismay of the officially designated Houston International Sports Committee, which is hoping eventually to land the Olympics.
Of course, much of what potential Olympic hosts saw in Atlanta wasn't so encouraging. Early in the Games, reporters from around the world lampooned the city as tacky, incompetent and in over its head, although the criticisms softened over time. The pipe bomb incident, which is still unsolved, was a chilly hint of the kind of large-scale terrorism that can occur at such a venue.
But experts say the Olympics offers at least three huge inducements.
One is the economic payoff -- from $4 billion to $5 billion in Atlanta -- of the single biggest single tourist event in the world.
The second is an unparalleled opportunity to draw attention to the host city.
The third is the ability to mobilize public support for rebuilding roads and bridges, building new stadiums and housing, and rethinking urban planning in a way that is otherwise almost impossible in today's fractured, financially constricted cities.

 
 
Never Again
 The problem with the vision of the Olympics as a grand engine of true urban renewal is that it relies on a game plan devised in Los Angeles in 1984 and refined by Atlanta in 1996 of having the Games totally supported by private funds. (Actually, federal, state and local contributions for security and other needs surpassed a half billion dollars).
That plan resulted in so much commercialism in Atlanta that the International Olympic Committee has said it will never again approve a privately financed Olympiad without at least a government guarantee of the financing. Public monies would lessen the need to sell so many sponsorships.
"We have probably seen our last summer Olympics in the U.S. for a very long time," said John MacAloon, a University of Chicago anthropologist who studies the Olympics.
But such doubts do not bother potential American bidders. Mr. Doctoroff of New York City said there are many avenues of "creative" financing that could allow a city to host the Games without resorting to rampant commercialism. And, given New York City's status as the world's media capital, the city could raise more money from fewer sponsors, he said.
"I think America is too important to the Olympic movement to bar it from hosting future Olympics," he said.

HEADLINE: Burundi in Crisis;
America Sits and Watches

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: BUJUMBURA, Burundi

 BODY:
ONE of the many diplomats now struggling to end the chaos in Burundi says that a former Burundian minister sincerely believes that an American aircraft carrier is cruising Lake Tanganyika, ready to invade. When he's told that there's no way to sail a carrier into a lake in the central African highlands, he answers: "They brought it in by helicopter."
Burundi's citizens see plots everywhere, and with reason. Leadership there has been transferred by democratic elections only once, substantially fewer times than by assassination. 
 But how the United States came to figure in the national paranoia is an interesting question.
Burundi, a poor, landlocked, French-speaking country the size of Connecticut, is hardly central to United States policy. There are no historical ties -- Burundi was colonized by Germany and Belgium -- and no minerals or sea lanes. Until last week, American interest was mostly humanitarian.
As in Rwanda and eastern Zaire, the two main ethnic groups, the Hutus and the Tutsis, are in a death struggle, sparing no one, not even women and children.

 
 
A Chilling Statistic
 About 150,000 Burundians have been killed over the last three years -- on average, 100 per day. A former American ambassador came up with a chilling lens for that statistic: given the relative size of its population to that of the United States, Burundi is suffering the mortal equivalent of the Oklahoma City bombing (where 168 died) every hour.
In the last two weeks, the United States has been thrust into the center of Burundian politics. On July 23, the President, Sylvestre Ntibantunganya (pronounced en-tee-bahn-toon-GAN-yuh) arrived at the American embassy asking for protection.
A Hutu leading a weak coalition government, he had denounced his own Tutsi-dominated national army for killing dozens of civilians. Then, at a funeral for 340 Tutsis who were massacred by Hutu rebels at a tea plantation, a furious crowd had pelted him with rocks and cow dung while soldiers watched impassively. He fled in his helicopter. Fearing he would be murdered like his two predecessors, he asked the brand-new American ambassador, Morris Hughes, if he could come in. He's still at the embassy. "Look, we're not going to push him out the door," one official said. "It's important to have assurances of his safety, and I don't know that we've got them."
After two days of denials, the army, led by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, admitted that it had taken over the government. The new President, it turned out, got his military training in Belgium and Germany but his political training in America, and was well known to a few Americans, including former President Jimmy Carter.
Major Buyoya first took power during a 1987 coup. But by June 1993, he had written a charter of human rights and set up an election, pushing Burundi into its brief moment of democracy. He lost gracefully to a Hutu candidate, Melchior Ndadaye (pronounce enn-duh-DIE-yay), despite winning "a respectable number of Hutu votes," an official said. Four months later, though, Mr. Ndadaye was killed by soldiers. Hutu politicians are sure Mr. Buyoya was involved, but international observers are skeptical, especially since he didn't take power.
Instead, he set up the Foundation for Peace, Unity and Democracy, which included Hutus and Tutsis. Helped by as much as $145,000 from the U.S. Agency for International Development, money earmarked for fostering democracy, Major Buyoya visited the Carter Center at Emory University in Atlanta, was an observer at the South African elections and designed studies of Burundi's refugee problem and justice system. "Frankly, all his proposals were good," said Vincent Farley, diplomat in residence at the Carter Center.
Now American officials seem mildly embarrassed that one of their pupils has ridden a coup to power, but they consistently say the alternatives were worse. Ethnic bloodshed was increasing, Mr. Ntibantunganya's Government was impotent, and Mr. Buyoya's Tutsi military rivals -- who are by no means out of the picture even now -- are far more bloodthirsty than Mr. Buyoya.

 
 
The Larger Nightmare
 But most important, State Department officials want not to be the leader in righting the world's Burundi policy. They sat by quietly as the Organization for African Unity denounced the coup and as the presidents of nearby African nations called for economic sanctions.
The larger nightmare to ward off, of course, is an explosion of killings on the scale of those in Rwanda.
American officials, soured by their experience in Somalia, have said they would, at most, transport and feed another country's troops. They have reason to be reluctant. The hilly, malarious land would be even harder to invade than Somalia (another country where new instability is feared after the slaying of Mohammed Farah Aidid). There's only one jet airport, and it's a long way to the coast. The Burundian army is well-armed and xenophobic, and the Tutsis have warrior legends to live up to. Meanwhile, the Hutu rebels have said they, too, will shoot at foreign troops.
Even if someone were to call for an American peace enforcement mission, the prospects look as likely as a flying aircraft carrier.

HEADLINE: Greek Lawyer Pleased To Defend Serb Leader

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Aug. 2

 BODY:
When criminal lawyers are asked how they can represent unsavory clients, they often say that everyone has the right to counsel.
But Alexandros Lykourezos, one of this country's most prominent and flamboyant lawyers, does not resort to that cliche when asked about his work for one of the most wanted men in the world today -- Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander, who has been indicted on charges of crimes against humanity and genocide. 
 "I like him," Mr. Lykourezos said, explaining why he has taken up General Mladic's cause. "I consider him a friend" -- so much so that the lawyer, who would not discuss the international war crimes tribunal's indictment against General Mladic, said he was representing him pro bono. While evasive about what he was doing for General Mladic, he did say that he had traveled to Bosnia to meet him.
Mr. Lykourezos acknowledges that it may be hard for Westerners to understand his association with such a notorious suspect. Indeed, he said, he is censured by friends in London, Paris and New York. But not in Greece, where there is much sympathy for Serbia and the Bosnian Serbs.
"The reaction has been only positive here, totally positive," said Mr. Lykourezos. The lawyer, who is 62 and has wild, collar-length gray hair, spoke as he sat at his highly polished mahogany desk in khaki slacks with penny loafers and no socks.
"It is difficult for anybody outside Greece to understand rationally," Mr. Lykourezos said about Greece's relationship with Serbia.
It stems from Greece's hostile relationship with Turkey, which is also often hard for outsiders to fathom, Mr. Lykourezos added. The animosity is rooted in centuries past, to the days of the Ottoman Empire, when both the Serbs and the Greeks chafed under rule from Istanbul, which Mr. Lykourezos calls Constantinople, the Greek name for the city.
These days, though both are NATO members, Greece and Turkey have been on the brink of war, most recently earlier this year over a small, rocky island. The Greeks and the Serbs are also Orthodox Christians and see themselves fighting to hold the line against Islam in Europe.
In recent NATO debates, Greece has strongly opposed any military operation to seize General Mladic, or other people indicted on charges of war crimes, and it did not like the idea of forcing Radovan Karadzic to resign from the leadership of the main Bosnian Serb political party as a condition for the party to be allowed to take part in elections.
During the Bosnian war, Greek companies shipped oil to the Bosnian Serbs and to Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia, in violation of the United Nations economic embargo. Greek arms merchants got weapons to the Serbian forces, in violation of the arms embargo.
When the Bosnian Serbs attacked the United Nations "safe area" of Srebrenica last summer, Greek mercenaries fought with them and raised the blue and white Greek flag triumphantly when the enclave fell. Several thousand Muslim men were massacred, and General Mladic has been indicted on charges related to the killings.
But the fall of Srebrenica and the massacres went virtually unreported by Greek journalists. Indeed, Bosnian Serbian atrocities throughout the war were ignored by the Greek press, leaving most Greeks as ill-informed about the war as the Serbian people themselves.
A couple of months after the fall of Srebrenica, Mr. Lykourezos went on television to raise money for Serbian refugees. More than $400,000 poured in, he said.
Does all this mean that General Mladic or Dr. Karadzic might find asylum in Greece?
While avoiding a direct answer, Mr. Lykourezos noted that while France, Italy and Germany had passed laws to insure that anyone indicted on charges of war crimes who was found on their territory would be arrested and extradited to The Hague, some countries -- including Greece -- had not.
Even though international arrest warrants have been issued for General Mladic and others who have been indicted, some countries must pass domestic laws to provide for compliance with them.
Recently, representatives from the war crimes tribunal came here to ask the Government to adopt laws that would insure full cooperation with the court, Mr. Lykourezos said. He said he thought Parliament would take up the issue when it returned in September from its summer recess.
But given the attitude of the Greek people, it might be difficult to get such laws enacted, he said.
