HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Nation's new welfare law is really reform on a shoestring

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
To Congressional Republicans, the new welfare law is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to replace a 60-year-old system that does not work. To Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the new approach is "a social risk no sane person would take." So which is it? To many welfare experts outside the political rough and tumble, it appears to be both.
Americans are fed up with chronic welfare dependence, yet their elected representatives refused to come up with the money to assure a humane transition to a world in which nearly every able-bodied adult must work. The political resolution to that conflict is welfare reform on the cheap. "It's a big gamble," concludes Sheila Zedlewski, director of the Urban Institute's Income and Benefits Policy Center. 
 In the last few years, -- a decade after Ronald Reagan denounced "welfare queens" -- seemingly irreconcilable views about welfare began to converge. New-fashioned liberals, led by Senator Moynihan, distanced themselves from those on the traditional left who thought welfare ought to be a no-questions-asked minimum income for families. Meanwhile, conservatives softened their rhetoric about public assistance as a subsidy to what they saw as laziness and immoral behavior.
"Workfare" became the new mantra and policy specialists began to explore the practical ramifications of using real jobs as the lever to end dependence. Something like a centrist consensus developed, one concluding that many long-term welfare recipients need expensive training, child care, health insurance and even a job guarantee to break the cycle of circumstance and habit.
The closest thing to a serious proposal to match this informed view was probably the legislative package that President Clinton originally presented in 1994. It would have forced many young parents to work, and allotted an extra $2 billion a year to help the states pay for it. It was stillborn, a victim of the higher priority the Administration gave to its failed national health care initiative and the divided response among liberals to the workfare approach. Instead, the Administration encouraged states to try their own experiments.
Still, as Congress rushed to prove it was not gridlocked -- and the President rushed to deny the Republicans an explosive election issue -- welfare has been ended as we knew it. But rather than spending a little more money now to wean millions off welfare, the new law, according to estimates by the Urban Institute, will actually cut the budget for the major assistance programs by $15 billion annually (roughly one-fifth) when it is fully put into effect in 2002. Much of the savings will come from denying benefits to immigrants, trimming food stamps for childless, nonworking adults and cutting off welfare payments after five years.
There are escape valves, notably the states' option to extend benefits beyond five years for 20 percent of the caseload. An extra $5 billion will be available over the next five years to cover emergencies. And there will even be a modest cash windfall for many states in the first year, since Federal block grants will be based on 1994 caseloads, which were generally greater than those currently in place. Note, too, that states will also be required to maintain their own spending on welfare at at least three-quarters of the 1994 level.
But there is no escaping the fact that this is welfare reform on a shoestring. Ms. Zedlewski points out that disabled parents and children already constitute one-fifth of the welfare caseload, making it improbable that states will be able to use Federal dollars to extend monthly checks to other needy recipients after the five-year cutoff. And Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, scoffs at the value of the "maintenance of state effort" provisions, since the required outlays are not indexed to inflation and the law has plenty of loopholes in defining welfare services.
Conservatives are betting that when push comes to shove most welfare recipients will clean up their acts and earn a living. That, however, does not square with the findings of Sandra and Sheldon Danziger, researchers at the University of Michigan, who found that tough work requirements pushed just one-third of Michigan's welfare recipients into jobs. Nor does it seem plausible if the booming American economy heads south. "All bets are off during a recession," Mr. Danziger noted, when even dead-end minimum wage jobs become scarce.
Ms. Zedlewski of the Urban Institute expects huge variations from state to state and city to city. "Some will follow the Wisconsin example and spend more of their own money" to buffer the transition, she predicted. Others will look the other way, leaving the poor and jobless to lean on their extended families or on private charity.
Presumably, states and localities will respond to the most dolorous consequences -- Senator Moynihan's vision of "children sleeping on grates" -- with whatever it takes to avoid personal disaster. Or perhaps one presumes too much. "If you asked New Yorkers in 1975 whether people would tolerate thousands of homeless in the streets," Mr. Danziger reminds, "they would have laughed."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
N.A.S.D. and Government
Are Seen in Deal on Abuses
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers are expected to announce a $100 million agreement today to end abuses on the Nasdaq stock market, people with knowledge of the deal said. The agreement came after marathon talks that included the chief executives of top Wall Street firms. [Page D2.]
 
Growth Slackens Slightly
A Federal Reserve survey found that economic growth slackened a bit in early summer as consumers spent cautiously for most big-ticket items. Wage pressures remained in check despite what appeared to be a further tightening of the job market.
This combination of less exuberant business activity and continued subdued inflation is just what policy makers and financial markets have been hoping for. [D4.]

New Approach to U.S. Auto Market
Daewoo, the South Korean manufacturer, plans to enter the United States auto market by opening 200 to 500 company-owned sales outlets. The plans by Daewoo, South Korea's fourth-largest conglomerate, go against current practice. First, most car makers sell their cars and trucks to independent dealers. And second, Daewoo plans to focus on students, professors and their families -- a novel approach. [D4.]

Dow Average Closes Above 5,700
The Dow Jones industrial average ended above 5,700 for the first time in a month, gaining 22.56 points, to 5,718.67, as vigorous buying in semiconductor stocks, inspired by Merrill Lynch's upgrading of Micron Technology, spilled over to the broader market. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 12.24 points, to 1,141.11. [D8.]
 
Disappointing demand at the Treasury's auction of new 10-year notes depressed prices in the credit markets and sent the yield on the 30-year bond up slightly to 6.77 percent. [D18.]
 
Apple Drops Plans for Upgrade
Apple Computer has scrapped plans for a major upgrade of its flagship Macintosh operating system software next year, jeopardizing what remains of its technological lead over Microsoft's Windows system. [D2.]

Roadblock Removed to Iraqi Oil Sale
The United States removed the last major roadblock to the sale of Iraqi oil to pay for civilian needs, but the oil was not expected to reach the market for another month. [A9.]
 
Freeport and Arcadian to Merge
Freeport-McMoran, the mining and mineral giant, announced plans for a complicated merger with Arcadian, a fertilizer producer, exchanging stock worth $1 billion. If the public owners of Freeport-McMoran's 51.6 percent owned fertilizer partnership decide to exchange their stakes, the new company would have a market value of $3 billion. [D4.]
 
401(k) Rules Are Tightened
The Labor Department, seeking to halt abuse of workers' retirement funds, required companies to invest employees' money in 401(k) plans promptly. [D8.]
 
F.D.A. Gets Tough With Pfizer
The Food and Drug Administration ordered Pfizer to stop making unauthorized claims for Zoloft, its widely used antidepressant. [D19.]
 
Profits Fall at Turner Broadcasting
Turner Broadcasting System said second-quarter earnings fell 47.9 percent because of weak results at its film unit. [D7.]

When They Call, People Tremble
When Fran and Barry Weissler, the producers of "Grease" on Broadway, call their ad agencies, the members of the creative teams tremble. The producers demand a lot from their agencies, and the success of "Grease" shows why. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: SENATE RACES;
Abortion Opponents Prevail In 3 Republican Primaries

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 7

 BODY:
After campaigns that reinforced the Republican divide over abortion, voters in Georgia, Michigan and Kansas on Tuesday chose opponents of abortion rights over supporters of abortion rights in Republican primaries for the United States Senate.
Democrats said today that the very conservatism that appealed to voters in Republican primaries would handicap Tuesday's victors in the general election in November. That is especially true, they said, in a year when voters may be anxious about the conservative partisanship that was often a hallmark of the Republican-led Congress. 
 "I think it probably bodes well," said Steve J. Jarding, a spokesman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. "At some point you start to see where this ideological split has an impact."
But Republican strategists countered that history shows that abortion opponents are perfectly capable of winning general elections as long as they also demonstrate broad appeal with their positions on economic policy and on other social issues.
And even as Bob Dole's Presidential campaign is fighting the perception that the Republican Party is increasingly captive to anti-abortion activists, some strategists suggested that the results in Georgia, Michigan and Kansas were driven by factors other than abortion.
"Each of these races was determined by specific and unique circumstances that had little to do with the issue of abortion," said Gordon Hensley, a spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee. He pointed to advantages in fund raising and name recognition enjoyed by the winners, and to an exceedingly low turnout of voters in several states.
Tuesday's results were similar to those in other states that have selected conservative Republicans over more moderate challengers.
In the Illinois Senate primary this spring, for example, Republicans selected Al Salvi, a little-known state legislator who opposes gun control and abortion rights, over Lieut. Gov. Bob Kustra, a more moderate candidate who was backed by the party establishment. Mr. Salvi, who opposes abortion even in cases of rape and incest, is now considered an underdog in his race against Representative Richard J. Durbin, a Democrat who supports abortion rights.
And in Oregon late last year, Republican voters chose Gordon Smith, the conservative president of the State Senate and a staunch abortion opponent, over primary challengers that included Norma Paulus, the state school superintendent who is a supporter of abortion rights. Mr. Smith then lost a general election in January to Representative Ron Wyden, a liberal who became the first Democrat to represent Oregon in the Senate in 34 years.
In Tuesday's voting, perhaps the most clear-cut referendum on the abortion issue came in Georgia, where Guy Millner, a business executive who opposes abortion, defeated Johnny Isakson, a former legislator who took unusual steps to advertise his support for abortion rights.
Mr. Millner and Mr. Isakson acknowledged that there were few other differences between them on substantive issues. And Mr. Isakson chose to accentuate that difference by broadcasting television commercials that cited his stand on abortion.
The two men faced each other in a runoff after neither won a majority in a six-man primary on July 16. With most of the campaign conducted while Georgia was preoccupied with the Summer Olympic Games, Tuesday's turnout was estimated at an exceedingly low 13 percent.
That apathy may have heightened the influence of Christian conservatives who consider abortion a litmus test issue. Mr. Millner, who won 53 percent of the vote to 47 percent for Mr. Isakson, will face Max Cleland, a Democrat who was head of the Veterans Administration under President Jimmy Carter. The winner will succeed Senator Sam Nunn, a Democrat who is retiring.
Mr. Isakson said in an interview today that he believed his use of the abortion issue to position his campaign toward the political center had helped make the race close. And a University of Georgia political scientist, Charles S. Bullock, said Mr. Isakson's centrism would have made him a stronger general election candidate than Mr. Millner.
"Guy Millner's position on abortion means that he has at least one foot nailed to the floor," Mr. Bullock added. "He can't move on the abortion issue, and in Georgia in a general election that's a losing issue."
Abortion also played a significant role in the television advertising broadcast by Ronna Romney, a former Detroit radio talk show hostess and staunch abortion opponent who won the Republican primary in Michigan. She defeated Jim Nicholson, a businessman, by 52 percent to 48 percent, and will face Senator Carl Levin, a three-term Democrat.
In Kansas, Senator Sheila Frahm, a Republican who was appointed in June to replace Mr. Dole, lost to Representative Sam Brownback by 55 percent to 42 percent. Ms. Frahm, who began the campaign with a large lead in public opinion polls, is a supporter of abortion rights. Mr. Brownback, an abortion opponent, will face Jill Docking, a Democratic stockbroker who defeated former Gov. Joan Finney by a nearly 3-to-1 margin.
Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas easily defeated three opponents to win the Republican nomination to fill the seat being vacated by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum. And Jim Ryun, the famed Olympic miler, finished ahead of two rivals to win the Republican nomination for Mr. Brownback's House seat.

HEADLINE: Fed Finds Growth Is in Check as Labor Supply Tightens

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Economic growth slackened a bit in early summer as consumers spent cautiously for most big-ticket items, a survey by the Federal Reserve of business people around the country found today.
Wage pressures, meanwhile, remained largely in check despite what appeared to be a further tightening of the job market, with some employers in nearly all areas now suffering from an inability to find workers.
This combination of less exuberant business activity and continued subdued inflation is just what policy makers and financial markets have been hoping for, and today's survey, known as the beige book, did not significantly alter the outlook, as it confirmed recent job figures and other data. 
 The findings "suggest the Fed will hold policy steady" at the Aug. 20 meeting for which the anecdotal soundings were taken, said Joseph Liro, an economist with CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York.
Nonetheless, the mounting labor scarcity is causing some uneasiness that what has so far been a modest uptick in compensation for workers, the main cost for most businesses, will at some point become sizable enough to demand a response in the form of higher short-term interest rates, perhaps at the Fed's Sept. 24 or Nov. 13 meetings.
Indeed, the Fed's San Francisco district reported today that "wage inflation pressures are evident" in parts of its seven-state territory, with service industries like computers and telecommunications particularly hard hit.
Besides shortages of programmers and systems engineers, the Fed reported that retailers, who employ many entry-level workers, in the Puget Sound area had had "difficulties in recruiting qualified employees at existing wages, given increased job availability in other industries."
Moreover, the Richmond district was told that producers of industrial machinery and equipment were finding themselves constrained by the lack of skilled labor.
In the Chicago area, some employers had to make benefits packages more generous to attract and keep workers, notably in the construction industry.
The Fed also reported that the amount of consumer installment debt grew at an 8.7 percent annual pace in June, as borrowing for automobiles boomed while credit-card, or revolving, debt grew at a markedly diminished pace.
The overall rise compared with 5.9 percent growth in May, but it was the third straight month in which the rate of increase was less than 10 percent after an extended period of increases in or near double digits.
Outstanding credit card debt advanced at a 7.6 percent clip, less than half the 15.6 percent jump in May and the first single-digit increase this year after five rises averaging 16.9 percent.
This indicator has proved a useful gauge of business conditions, even though it is reported with a significant time lag, does not isolate new borrowings or repayments and reflects an increasing tendency of consumers to use credit cards as convenient methods of payments and not necessarily because of a desire or need to borrow.
As for the beige book survey, named for the color of its cover, the Fed summarized the economy as having "continued to expand in June and July, though in some areas the pace of growth has moderated" since the previous survey, which was published on June 19.
On that occasion, the conclusion was that "economic activity continued to advance at a moderate pace" in May and the first 10 days of June.
Today's report, prepared at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and based on information collected through July 29, added: "A number of districts report tight labor markets, especially for entry-level workers; however, wage pressures remained subdued. Retail sales slowed in most districts, particularly for non-auto durables."
Among individual districts, Boston reported a strong rebound in commercial real estate, particularly in the Greater Boston area; New York continued to enjoy a boom in tourism that has pushed New York City rates of hotel occupancy to a 17-year high, and Richmond found heavy demand for secretarial help, skilled warehouse and production people and workers who know computers.
"We are scraping bottom for labor in our area," a South Carolina home builder told the Richmond bank.
The Atlanta district reported that heavy spending near Olympic sites adversely affected some traditional tourist destinations, though many Florida cities benefited from a surge in travel by Atlantans who left that city during the Games.
Chicago reported a late-spring rebound in factory employment to be "short-lived," while labor shortages among professional and technical workers persisted along with "particularly severe" shortages in construction.
And in the St. Louis district, there were reports of a tight labor market in "all parts," with high turnover rates even for those offering relatively high starting pay and benefits.
Scarcity of skilled and entry-level workers has spread in some cases to semiskilled labor, the bank added, and poultry processers in western Kentucky were relying increasingly on foreign labor.
The labor market appears to be tightest in the Upper Midwest, where the Minneapolis bank reported help-wanted signs "omnipresent in most urban areas."
Last week the Labor Department reported that South Dakota had the nation's lowest unemployment rate in June, 2.8 percent, followed by Nebraska, Iowa and North Dakota.
The lowest jobless rate for any of the 272 metropolitan areas was in Sioux Falls, S.D., at 1.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Vetoes a Bill to Make City Contractors Raise Wages

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday vetoed a bill that would have required some city contractors to pay higher minimum wages to their employees, calling the measure irresponsible because it would add to the city's costs while also hurting minimum-wage workers.
"This bill, while purporting to help low-wage employees, would in reality do little to provide long-term economic betterment even for the narrow class of workers covered by its provisions," Mr. Giuliani wrote in his veto message. 
 The City Council, which approved the bill with 41 votes earlier this month, is almost sure to override the veto, for which only 34 votes are needed. The veto is Mr. Giuliani's seventh since taking office in 1994. The Council has overridden him four times and negotiated new legislation in the two other cases.
The bill, which would have raised the city's contracting costs by $16 million a year, would have required city contractors in four areas -- security, cleaning, food service and temporary office work -- to pay workers what is known as the "prevailing wage," or the standard wage that private-sector workers receive for similar work. Council officials have estimated that the bill would have affected 3,500 workers, raising the wages of unarmed security guards to $7.25 an hour, food workers to $9 an hour, temporary office workers to $11.25 an hour and janitors to $14 an hour.
The Mayor contended that the higher wages would encourage companies to stop hiring the relatively unskilled workers they now use for city contracts. "The legislation could leave entry-level workers with fewer opportunities than ever before," Mr. Giuliani said. He also said the bill would increase costs for the city and "raises obstacles to firms wishing to do business with us."
Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the Council, called the Mayor's veto "a vote against common sense and fairness," and said an override was likely "unless we can resolve the differences we have."
Colleen A. Roche, the Mayor's press secretary, said yesterday that if the Council overrode the veto, the administration would go to court to strike down the law.
Mr. Vallone said that the bill, which is far less sweeping than an earlier proposal to set a minimum wage of $12.10 an hour for all city contracts, sought to correct inequities in areas not covered by the state prevailing-wage law. The Mayor's philosophy, however, is to decrease the level of government involvement in the private sector.

HEADLINE: Questions Raised on Development Zones

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Nearly a decade ago, New York began an ambitious program to spur economic growth in distressed communities across the state by offering businesses tax breaks and other handsome incentives to move into those communities.
But a new audit released by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall raises questions about the state's handling of the program and whether the program has actually helped revive poor communities, including four in New York City. 
 The report, released Tuesday, provides the first significant analysis to bolster the arguments of critics who have long questioned the benefits of setting up special areas, called economic development zones, to lure businesses -- and new jobs -- to poor neighborhoods. The critics say the approach has simply transferred jobs from one community to another.
"It does not increase the size of the pie," said Frank J. Mauro, the director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-financed economic research group. "The state is basically subsidizing the relocation of businesses from one site to another, and the businesses aren't being held accountable to create jobs."
The audit found that the state agency administering the program had grossly overestimated the number of jobs created in a sampling of development zones. It also found that the agency, the Department of Economic Development, had virtually no way of determining what the state spent on the program or whether the state was reaping any benefits.
In one instance, state auditors found that only 163 jobs were created in a development zone in the Port Morris section of the Bronx in 1993, far fewer than the 4,421 jobs reported by the program's local administrators. In another case, in East New York, Brooklyn, program administrators claimed that 4,127 new jobs had been created in the same year, but state auditors identified only 147.
And in a third case, the administrators recorded 3,798 new jobs in a zone in South Jamaica, Queens; the auditors could account for only 423.
The Comptroller's office said that many of the inconsistencies resulted from poor record keeping, inadequate monitoring of hiring practices and a failure to remove companies from the program even after local officials had reported that the companies had failed to meet eligibility requirements. Mr. McCall also attributed some of the problem to arcane state and Federal labor laws that deny agency officials access to records like employment figures that businesses file with the state's Department of Labor each year.
Nevertheless, Mr. McCall said the development zones offered "an opportunity to reinvigorate communities," and he urged state officials to monitor the program more effectively. "Without a system to measure the program's benefits," he said, "this money and the opportunity to create jobs may be needlessly wasted."
But Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the State Commissioner for Economic Development, Charles A. Gargano, questioned the timing of the report, given that the agency this week is going to begin looking for an outside consultant to monitor the program. She also disputed some figures in the audit and said the audit had failed to look at some of the more effective development zones.
"This is a good economic development program," she said. "We're working on making it more efficient with better oversight."
New York has been running the economic development zone program since 1987. The zones generally cover a two-square-mile area, providing local businesses with investment tax credits, wage tax credits, reductions in utility rates and tax relief for construction materials. There are now 40 economic development zones throughout the state, including the 4 in New York City, all created under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. McCall's report did not deal with Federal empowerment zones like the one recently created to benefit distressed areas of upper Manhattan and the Bronx.
Supporters of the local enterprise zones contend that they are powerful tools for encouraging economic development in impoverished areas.
The program was expanded from 19 zones to 40 during the 1994 gubernatorial race, though Governor Cuomo denied that the expansion was timed to help his re-election effort. Still, Gov. George E. Pataki, who was then campaigning against Mr. Cuomo, accused him of using such programs for pork-barrel spending in Democratic districts.
In his report, Mr. McCall noted that the agency had yet to evaluate the program's effectiveness, even though state law required the administration to have done so. He also said that many businesses may have improperly received tax breaks because they failed to file certain reports required in the program.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Will Dole Fight?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Before Bob Dole could take on Bill Clinton, he first had to take control of the Republican Party in convention assembled.
His early attempt to reach a temperate compromise on abortion with the Buchananites he so decisively defeated in the primaries had failed. The one-issue extremists wouldn't take "Yes, but" for an answer; they demanded a convention victory that, as in 1992, would insure another election defeat. 
 If you cannot take charge of your convention, you will have a hard time taking charge of the country. When an intolerant faction tried to dictate the party platform, it was up to the nominee to make certain that the party's more inclusive rank and file was respected and its views officially recorded. Last night Dole prevailed on the platform chairman, Henry Hyde, to include inclusive views.
By calling the Buchanan bluff, Dole not only saved the party's soul but gained it electoral strength. But if Dole had been unwilling to lead, the irony would have been in the fire: a minority of pro-lifers who could not abide the word "tolerance" would have dragged along a reluctant Christian Coalition to again deliver the White House to Clinton's pro-choice extremists.
My hope that Dole would not weakly submit was based on a clue to an internal struggle revealed in his economic plan this week. He does not take humiliation kindly.
As Senate leader early this year, Dole showed lonely courage in going up against the media moguls' lobby. The broadcasters are eager to avoid costly free-enterprise auctions and instead want -- as a gift -- slices of the spectrum worth what may be $70 billion of the public's airwaves.
No sooner was Dole out the Senate door than the new majority leader, Trent Lott, in cahoots with Speaker Newt Gingrich, reversed Dole's instruction to the F.C.C. and arranged a whopping giveaway to the media lobby, unhindered by Clinton.
But in Dole's new tax-cut proposal, to offset revenue losses, is his conservative estimate of $34 billion from "spectrum auctions." That serves notice that a President Dole would fight the Media-Political Complex for the public's money.
Senator Lott denies providing welfare to station owners, assuring me "there will be spectrum auctions in the future," though he doubts they will generate the amount Dole envisions. But Dole's refusal to go along with the auction-delaying deal is just the sort of break-all-the-china scrap that should be the hallmark of his anti-establishment campaign.
He has also taken on the contingency-fee bar, Clinton's most lavish contributors, to curb the punitive lawsuits that bankrupt small companies and drive up consumer prices.
Such engagement -- scrappiness in good causes -- is the route to upset victory. As campaigners from the Roosevelts to Truman to Nixon proved, you gotta have villains.
Extremists on both ends of the abortion spectrum are villains.
Media plutocrats intimidating politicians to get a lucrative spot on the spectrum for nothing are villains.
Trial lawyers buying White House protection to maintain their stranglehold on the legal system are villains.
Complacent Pentagon bureaucrats who leave America defenseless against missiles from terrorist states are villains.
And a President who frightens old folks with false tales of "cuts" in their Medicare protection also callously plays the villain.
What running mate can best help the candidate carry the good fight against this fearsome farrago?
He ought to have a hard-driving partner who needs no introduction and presents no problem. The governors being bruited about are national strangers, and Colin Powell is posing as Ethelred the Unready. The names I hear are Senators John McCain and Connie Mack, former Illinois Congressman and Defense Secretary Don Rumsfeld, and empower-players Bill Bennett and Jack Kemp.
Each is what Nixon used to call "un homme serieux." McCain, a prisoner-of-war hero gaining national stature on defense issues, is a big-tent pro-lifer, upbeat and attractive on television, and closest to Dole. His main political drawback is an unexpected candor, but as Dole told a friend recently, "You spend five years in a box and you're entitled to speak your mind."

NEW YORK
 
Plot to Divert Wealth Is Seen
When New York City's largest trash hauler was indicted last year on charges that it had Mafia ties, a monitor was appointed to make sure the owners did not divert the company's wealth before a trial. Now, prosecutors say that the company, V. Ponte & Sons, tried to sell the business and funnel the proceeds through subsidiaries to its chief owner, Angelo Ponte. But the Manhattan District Attorney's office has blocked the sale, which could be for as much as $70 million. [Page B1.]
 
Literary Edge of Web World
If San Francisco is home to techies who dream up the codes that make the World Wide Web work, New York City is becoming the new home for those who create the pictures, the stories, the advertising copy that makes someone actually want to call up a home page or buy a CD-ROM. In short, the human face on the new-media world is largely that of the same artistic literary type who has always come to New York. [B1.]
 
Fraud by Few May Hurt Many
The new welfare bill will reduce financing for a program that benefits handicapped children. While the cut reflects Congress's efforts to save money, it is also a response to fraud by parents who coached their children to feign mental disorders so they could collect payments under the program. Now the question is whether, in pursuit of fraud, the Government will deny help to those who really need it. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
Questions on Enterprise Zones
An audit released by the State Comptroller raises questions about the handling of a program intended to spur economic growth in distressed communities. The report bolsters the arguments of critics who have questioned the benefits of setting up economic development zonesto lure businesses to poor areas. The critics say the approach has simply transferred jobs from one community to another. [B3.]
 
More Complaints on Metrocard
Older riders are complaining that getting the half-fare Metrocards to which people over 65 are entitled, requires too many steps, too long a wait and forces them to go into the subways even if they only ride buses. A Metropolitan Transportation Authority official said he agreed with most of the complaints, but offered little hope that the situation would improve. [B3.]

A detective who is accused in the racial beating of a black man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub on May 26 has resigned, effective immediately, from the New York City Police Department. Constantine Chronis is the focus of a departmental hearing currently looking into the beating of Shane L. Daniels, 21, of Riverhead, L.I., who was left in a coma by the attack. [B3.]
 
Searching for a Sniper
Scores of detectives and police officers went door to door through housing projects in Brooklyn in an intense manhunt for the sniper who shot a detective in Brownsville. The detective, who was saved by his bulletproof vest, left the hospital and returned to the scene of the shooting to aid in the investigation. [B4.]
 
Man Arraigned in Assault
John J. Royster, the Bronx drifter who the police say confessed to the beatings in June of four women, one of whom died, was arraigned in Westchester County Court in the rape and assault of one victim, a Yonkers woman. [B6.]
 
A Musical Milestone
For more than two decades, the New York City Housing Authority Symphony has been giving free concerts at public housing developments. They introduce audiences who might not make it to Carnegie Hall to live performances of classical music and jazz, and in particular they showcase black musicians long underrepresented in the concert halls. Next month, in celebration of its 25th anniversary, the orchestra will perform at Alice Tully Hall. The Arts. [C13.]

Recovery of 35 Bodies Unlikely
Divers off Long Island have not recovered any bodies from the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 in the last 48 hours, and investigators said they would not be surprised if no more remains were discovered. That would leave 35 bodies unaccounted for, out of the 230 people aboard the jetliner. [B1.]
Medical examiners have so far found no evidence of an explosive device on the bodies recovered in the T.W.A. crash. [B5.]

Northeast Utilities' hostility toward employees who raised safety concerns at its Millstone Point nuclear plants contributed to the breakdown in standards that eventually led to their shutdown by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a commission panel said. [B7.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Removes Bar on Sale Of Oil to Aid Iraqi Civilians

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The United States today removed the last major roadblock to the sale of Iraqi oil to pay for emergency civilian needs, and United Nations officials said they hoped to put the plan into effect within a few weeks.
But diplomats cautioned that it might be a month or more before oil actually reached the market and food, medicine and other goods began arriving in Iraq to relieve the hardships caused by six years of international sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. 
 After the Clinton Administration decision, some technical steps are still necessary -- and the experience of recent months shows that unexpected problems can arise. But if all goes according to plan, oil-contract overseers can now be named, monitors can be stationed at pumping and pipeline stations in Iraq and Turkey and a contract for surveillance of imports by a neutral company can be signed.
"We do believe that the important part here is to get humanitarian assistance to the people in Iraq," Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative, said today after informing the Security Council of Washington's decision.
Tono Eitel, Germany's representative and the chairman of the Council's Iraqi sanctions committee, called the announcement "a welcome development" and said he hoped to move the plan out of his committee within days. Last week Mr. Eitel expressed his frustration at what he saw as American stalling over demands that procedures be tightened.
Iraq's envoy at the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, said he foresaw no more obstacles. "This should have happened a couple of weeks ago," he said of Washington's decision.
Iraq was offered this plan in April 1995, but did not sign an agreement with the United Nations to proceed until May 20 this year.
The plan allows Iraq to sell up to $2 billion in oil every six months. But if the Secretary General finds that the agreement is being violated, this will be reported to the Security Council, which can call off the deal.
Most of the oil is expected to be exported through a Turkish pipeline to the Mediterranean, with the rest passing through the Iraqi port of Mina al-Bakr on the Persian Gulf.
If in the next few days the sanctions committee approves the procedures and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali advises the Council that all details are in order, the sale of oil may begin at one minute after midnight the next morning.
The Administration had been holding up final approval of the oil sale, which all other 14 members of the Security Council had accepted last month, because Washington wanted stronger monitoring to prevent cheating by Baghdad and to insure that emergency supplies reached the civilians for whom they are intended.
"What we have wanted to do all along is assure ourselves that all the procedures that go along with this are appropriate, and we will make sure that they are carried out very vigorously to get the assistance to the right people and not in any way to abrogate the sanctions regime," Ms. Albright said today.
She called the remaining tasks "very technical aspects" and seemed to imply that these would cause no further problems. But some diplomats are concerned that disputes could arise over prices Iraq wants for its oil.
"The Secretariat still has to make sure that the right number of monitors have been hired and that they are in the right places," Ms. Albright said. Diplomats assume that United Nations officials are clear on what Washington wants.
Monitors from the United Nations would be stationed around central and southern Iraq, where emergency goods will be distributed by Iraqis. In the northern three provinces, controlled by Kurds under international protection, the United Nations will distribute food and medicine itself.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Public Favors The Democrats, New Poll Finds

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 7

 BODY:
For the first time in four years, the Democratic Party is viewed more favorably by voters than the Republican Party, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Underscoring the challenges facing the Republicans as they gather here to nominate Bob Dole for President next week, the poll showed that the concerns that contributed to voters' repudiation of the Democratic-controlled Congress in 1994 have substantially subsided. 
 On several policy fronts, from specifics like fairness in taxation to broader themes like helping people "achieve the American dream," registered voters said they trusted Democrats more than Republicans by wide margins.
Despite lingering qualms about President Clinton's character, voters found him far more appealing in several areas than Mr. Dole and were more inclined to favor Democratic candidates for Congress as well. Indeed, when asked how they would vote in their Congressional elections this fall, Americans gave Democrats a larger edge than the Republicans had in the 1994 election when they seized both houses of Congress.
The poll of 1,166 adults nationwide, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, was conducted by telephone from Saturday to Monday. It was completed before Mr. Dole announced his campaign's economic platform on Monday and could not reflect whatever boost he might have received from that effort.
The survey found that the nation was divided over the notion of a 15-percent across-the-board tax cut, which formed the core of his proposal.
But the poll highlighted untapped reservoirs of potential strength for Mr. Dole and his party, particularly the anxieties of middle-class people over the future of their children. Nearly half of registered voters said they thought that the next generation would be worse off than people today, and close to 6 out of 10 said the Clinton Administration should do more to help the middle class. And, as they have for more than a decade, Americans said they trusted Republicans more than Democrats to insure a sound economy.
In announcing his economic plan this week, Mr. Dole made explicit appeals to the unease of middle-class Americans, and his advisers hope he can capitalize on those issues as the nation's attention turns to the convention, which opens on Monday. "Let me suggest this simple test," Mr. Dole said in his speech. "Ask yourself, do you believe America is on the right track today, and do you believe that we are building a future that is better for our children?"
Still, in making the economy a centerpiece of his argument that people should favor him over Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole has a hard sell. Although they express long-term concerns, 63 percent of those polled judged the economy to be in good shape. Only 23 percent gave the economy such high marks in late October of 1992; it was those anxieties that helped set the stage for Mr. Clinton's defeat of President George Bush.
Beyond Mr. Dole's potential inroads on the economy, the poll showed that he maintained his advantage on character issues. Seven out of 10 voters said Mr. Dole shared the moral values most Americans try to live by; Mr. Clinton drew 58 percent on that count. But both Presidential contenders fared better on this than the collective members of Congress; only 39 percent said members of Congress shared those moral values.
Even with Mr. Clinton's vulnerabilities, the survey made clear that the party is in a more competitive position than Republicans as the convention phase of the campaign gets under way. The Democratic convention opens in Chicago on Aug. 26.
Over all, 55 percent of registered voters expressed a favorable opinion of the Democratic Party, while 39 percent were unfavorable. By contrast, 46 percent held a favorable opinion of the Republican Party, and 47 percent unfavorable. That is a striking turnabout in the image of the Democrats. Not since before Mr. Clinton's election in 1992 have more than half the voters expressed such a positive image of the party.
Mr. Clinton's announcement last week that he would sign the welfare bill only solidified his support. Fifty-two percent of voters said he did the right thing; only 6 percent said it was the wrong thing to do and 40 percent said they did not know enough about the measure. Even so, voters were about evenly divided when asked if they would still back the President's decision if it meant that many more children would be living in households below the poverty line.
There was no sign of erosion in the President's months-long lead over Mr. Dole: Fifty-six percent of registered voters say they would vote for Mr. Clinton if they election were held today, while 34 percent would back Mr. Dole.
The picture may be even rosier for Mr. Clinton should Ross Perot, as expected, win the nomination of his Reform Party and run again for President.
When Mr. Perot is included in the trial heat, Mr. Clinton's support rises slightly to 58 percent; Mr. Dole's falls back to 28 percent, and Mr. Perot draws 10 percent. Mr. Perot seems to have lost some luster: only 15 percent of registered voters have favorable views of him and nearly half hold an unfavorable view.
Nearly 8 out of 10 voters said they did not know enough to make a judgment about Richard Lamm, the former Colorado Governor who is challenging Mr. Perot for the Reform Party nomination. The party is holding two conventions, one on the eve of the Republican gathering, and the other the day after that convention ends.
The Democrats' positive image is evident at the Congressional level as well. Democrats also had a significant edge, 46 percent to 39 percent, when voters were asked which party's candidate they would support in the House race in their Congressional district. If maintained, that margin could enable the Democrats to recapture the House.
Mr. Dole's advisers say that after four nights of prime time attention, they hope that their candidate will depart San Diego with a clear "bounce" in the polls to give him momentum in the 11-week sprint to Election Day.
But the first challenge may be for Republicans to turn around a wide impression among voters, including many Republicans, this early that Mr. Dole will never make it to the White House. Seventy-five percent of voters said they expected Mr. Clinton to win in November. Even nearly half of those who plan to vote for Mr. Dole said they expected the President to be re-elected.
As Mr. Dole nears a decision on his running mate, 9 out of 10 voters said that if he picked a woman it would not make a difference in whether they would support him. And half of the Republican voters said that the running mate's position on abortion does not matter.
The good and bad news for Republicans is that 68 percent of registered voters said Mr. Dole has not made it clear what he wants to accomplish in the next four years. That gives Mr. Dole an enormous opportunity to define himself here next week. But it also indicates that after more than a year of campaigning, Mr. Dole has failed to put forth a message that catches on.
Mr. Dole's advisers view the convention as a showcase to reintroduce the former Senate majority leader to the American people. The poll found that in advance of the convention, only 22 percent of registered voters held a favorable opinion of Mr. Dole, while 43 percent expressed a favorable view of Mr. Clinton. The President's job approval rating stands at a robust 58 percent. That ties Mr. Clinton's all-time high of 55 percent in March 1993, shortly after he was inaugurated.
Mr. Dole has said that his campaign's focus groups show that people do not know much about him, even that he was a war hero. But in the poll, 7 out of 10 voters said they knew that Mr. Dole had served in the military during World War II. An even larger proportion, nearly 9 out of 10, know that Mr. Clinton did not serve in the military during the Vietnam War.
Despite the searing debate at the Republican platform hearings this week over abortion, the poll showed that 7 out of 10 Americans do not think making abortion illegal is the kind of issue for which the Constitution should be changed. The Republican platform still calls for a Constitutional amendment against abortion.
The findings also suggest that it made good political sense for the Republicans to exclude Patrick J. Buchanan from a speaking role at the convention. Forty-six percent of voters have an unfavorable opinion of him; only 12 percent give him a favorable rating.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Monday with 1,166 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 900 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans or independents taken as a separate group. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Hernan Siles Zuazo, Ex-President of Bolivia, Is Dead at 83

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Hernan Siles Zuazo, the former President of Bolivia who was one of the chief engineers in moving the country toward political freedom, died on Tuesday night at a hospital in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he lived in retirement. He was 83.
The cause was an embolism in the lungs after a long illness, Guillermo Richter, Bolivia's Minister of Information, said yesterday. 
 Mr. Siles, the son of a former President, served as President of his small, landlocked Andean country from 1956 to 1960 and from 1982 to 1985. Although marred by uncontrollable inflation, his second presidency restored democracy to Bolivia after nearly 18 years of military rule.
President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada declared 30 days of national mourning in Bolivia, and Congress dedicated yesterday's session to Mr. Siles, whom the President described as an anchor of democracy.
Trained as a lawyer, Mr. Siles was considered one of Bolivia's elder statesmen. His father led the country from 1926 to 1930.
In 1941 Mr. Siles, with Victor Paz Estenssoro, another former President, founded the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement. Mr. Siles was a leader of the 1952 revolution, which abolished a feudal system that had held the Indian population in poverty, nationalized major tin mines and brought universal suffrage.
Before his first term in office, Mr. Siles served as Vice President from 1952 to 1956 under Mr. Paz Estenssoro, but the two later split. He also worked for The Associated Press as a translator in Buenos Aires from November 1947 to September 1948.
During his first presidency, Mr. Siles focused on protecting the country's economic viability by acquiring loans from the International Monetary Fund and requesting aid from the United States.
He set up an austere spending plan, cut back on some recently introduced social services, froze wages and invited American oil companies back into Bolivia. He quashed incipient strikes by countering them with personal hunger strikes, a ploy he would use throughout his presidencies.
When Mr. Paz Estenssoro returned to the presidency in 1960, Mr. Siles served as Ambassador to Paraguay and to Spain. But he fled into exile in 1964 when Mr. Paz Estenssoro was deposed by a coup.
It was during that period when the two parted political views, with Mr. Paz Estenssoro moving to the right of center and Mr. Siles to the left. In 1971, Mr. Siles formed the Leftist Nationalist Revolutionary Movement, which was widely supported by peasants.
In 1980, Mr. Siles won the most votes in the general election, but a violent uprising forced him to leave the country again. He escaped to Peru by dressing as a peasant and crossing Lake Titicaca in a boat. Simmering pressures within the country and international threats forced the leaders to turn to democratic rule two years later, when Mr. Siles began his second term.
Mr. Siles was jubilant when he was inaugurated on Oct. 10, 1982.
"We are going to construct a democracy with absolute liberty," he said. "Those who do not believe in democracy and have interrupted it many times, depriving people of their liberties, should reflect and understand that their time has come to end."
But the term saw his political unraveling in a chaotic economic situation that threatened to bring the military out of the barracks again. Prices rose by more than 24,000 percent during his tenure because of a miscalculated austerity program, forcing his successor to impose rigorous economic controls.
And though Bolivia was once the most important tin producer in the world, the collapse of international tin prices in 1985, coupled with Bolivia's inefficient production methods, made it more expensive to operate the mines than to leave them idle.
But Mr. Siles saw some successes, including the capture and extradition of international terrorists and of Klaus Barbie, the Nazi war criminal.
He tried to cooperate with the United States in fighting the traffic of cocaine. It was a difficult issue mostly because he had to defend the state-monopolized cultivation of the coca plant, which, as Mr. Siles once explained, "from time immemorial has been chewed by our people to relieve pain."
Born in La Paz, Bolivia's capital, Mr. Siles was the illegitimate son of Hernando Siles Reyes, the last Republican President of Bolivia, who held office from 1926 to 1930, and Isabel Zuazo Cusicanqui. He was raised by his mother, and although he was not very close to his father, they maintained a cordial relationship.
A half-brother, Luis Adolfo Siles Salinas, also served as Bolivia's President for five months in 1969.
Mr. Siles died on Bolivia's Independence Day, exactly 11 years after he stepped down under fire as President. His body is expected to arrive in La Paz at noon today, with a funeral this afternoon.
Mr. Siles is survived by his wife, Maria Teresa Ormachea del Carpio, and three daughters, Marcela, Ana Maria and Isabel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Down Slightly

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday, dragged down by disappointing demand at an auction of new 10-year notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 6/32 , to 907/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.77 percent, from 6.75 percent on Tuesday. 
 The Treasury sold $10 billion of new 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 6.535 percent, slightly above expectations of a yield of 6.52 to 6.53 percent.
The bid-to-cover ratio was below average at 2.22, indicating only tepid demand for the securities. The ratio is the total dollar amount bid divided by the size of the auction.
"This is what you have to expect when you have a set of auctions after such a tremendous rally last week," said Christopher Low, senior economist with HSBC Markets Inc.
Treasury prices jumped last week after fresh reports suggested the economy was slowing from the rapid 4.2 percent rate of growth posted in the second quarter.
The market, however, remains optimistic that the slowing economy will ease the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates when the central bank's policy makers meet on Aug. 20, analysts said.
Dealers -- investors who trade on the spreads between various Treasury securities' yields -- and portfolio managers were the most active bidders at the 10-year note auction, analysts said.
"Demand for the securities was somewhat disappointing. The auction was dominated mostly by dealers and some money managers," said one trader at a domestic investment bank.
The weak results followed sluggish demand at the first leg of the auction on Tuesday, when the Treasury sold $19 billion of three-year notes. The auction continues with the sale of $10 billion in 30-year bonds today.
Analysts said market participants would be a bit nervous going into the last leg of the auction, but that the sluggishness in the first two legs did not signal a bear market for bonds.
"Investors might be nervous," said James Glassman, senior economist at Chase Securities Inc. "After having seen what happened today, people will be more careful going into the 30-year auction."
But "once these auctions are digested the market will be fine," he said.
The market had little reaction to the release of the Federal Reserve's periodic survey of business conditions around the country, known as the beige book, which pointed to a slowdown in economic growth and waning inflationary pressures that already had been factored into traders' strategies.
"That was the same message of all the data last week, so there wasn't a lot of news in the beige book," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities Inc.
Analysts said the market paid little attention to a jump in June consumer credit growth to $8.3 billion from a revised $5.6 billion rise in May.
In the corporate market, high-grade bonds edged higher, spurred by solid demand.
Ford Motor's $250 million 30-year debentures, originally priced to yield 79 basis points over Treasuries, closed at 80 bid. The deal did not trade higher after an aggressive pricing on Tuesday, a trader said.
The only deal to encounter trouble was Wells Fargo's $300 million in subordinated notes, issued at a 64- basis-point spread, which some secondary dealers said was too tight. The notes widened almost 10 basis points, to 73 basis points bid.

HEADLINE: Dole's Tax-Cut Proposal Frightens Liberals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To judge from the reaction of the Clinton campaign, and the strident tone of your editorials, Bob Dole's tax proposals (front page, Aug. 6) have accomplished their purpose. At last, not only has he found a policy that Bill Clinton cannot steal; but it is also one that crystallizes the difference between the new Republicans and Mr. Clinton's old-line "big government" constituencies.
What makes the Dole tax reduction plan so scary to liberals is that, if he is elected, his spending cuts would be implemented by a Republican Congress that has shown itself both willing and able to legislate the drastic reductions he needs -- including shrinking the sacred cows of Social Security and Medicare that Mr. Dole himself exempts. 
 History has shown that lower tax rates produce higher tax revenues. But the tax "bonus" that Mr. Dole claims for his proposals would be helped by something else as well. As extracting more money from taxpayers became too politically hazardous, the Democrats in Congress switched to mandating, through new regulations, just how that money should be spent.
With Republicans in control of both the White House and Congress, we can begin to attack the network of burdensome regulations and mandates that impose such a massive indirect "tax" on this country's economic vigor.
 
KEITH MC DERMOTT
Greenwich, Conn., Aug. 6, 1996

HEADLINE: Dole's Tax-Cut Proposal Frightens Liberals;
Just More Voodoo

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 My understanding of supply-side theory is that lower taxes lead to higher levels of investment, resulting in bountiful economic growth that overcomes the budget deficit.
Every dollar in lost revenue from Bob Dole's proposals for reducing tax rates and offering tax credits for children needs to be replaced with a dollar from the proceeds of Government bond sales. The latter represents a dollar that very likely would otherwise have been earmarked for savings or investment in the private, productive side of the economy. The same can't be said about the increased take-home pay from the tax cuts -- leading to precisely the opposite of the intended result. 
 In leaving Social Security "off the table" -- in fact, proposing to lower taxes on Social Security -- Mr. Dole exhibits a profound level of cluelessness about the real long-term fiscal problem: the need for entitlement reform. So the end result is very little, or no increase in growth rate. Just more voodoo, and an even larger debt for the next generation to repay.
 
MIKE GLASS
Farmingville, L.I., Aug. 6, 1996

HEADLINE: Dole's Tax-Cut Proposal Frightens Liberals;
Governing Costs Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Perhaps it is a good thing that Bob Dole is proposing a massive tax cut, because the Republican-led Congress has just handed the states the biggest unfunded mandate in history in the welfare reform bill.
Those with memories longer than last week will recall that the slashes in Federal taxes in the Reagan revolution were inevitably followed by rises in state taxes as services formerly provided by the Federal Government were handed back (thanks a lot!) to the states. State governors and legislators who shouldered the burden found themselves out of office after the next election, the victims of voter rage. 
 Why, after so many rounds of tax cuts, are we still feeling so overtaxed? It is because sustaining the level of government services minimally necessary for a functioning modern society not permanently divided between the desperate poor and the apprehensive rich requires a certain level of expenditure. It is high time Americans displayed sufficient intelligence to grasp that simple fact.
 
LINDA MALONEY
St. Cloud, Minn., Aug. 5, 1996

HEADLINE: Dole Backs New Options For Auto Insurance

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
While Bob Dole's proposal of an across-the-board 15 percent tax cut has gotten all the attention, buried within his economic plan is a virtually unnoticed initiative to remake the nation's auto insurance system that could be worth billions of dollars to American drivers -- without requiring painful spending cuts or threatening to increase the budget deficit.
"Auto choice," as it has been dubbed by its proponents, would give car owners the option of buying less expensive injury coverage solely for medical bills and lost wages, letting them save hundreds of dollars a year by opting not to carry liability insurance against "pain and suffering." 
 The plan has already aroused organized opposition from trial lawyers, who have a big stake in the current system and a lot of influence among Democrats in Congress, and consumer groups with very different agendas for changing auto insurance.
But the potential saving -- as much as $40 billion a year by one estimate -- could make it a sleeper issue in Mr. Dole's attempts to stimulate his Presidential campaign by reaching out to skeptical voters. The nonpartisan Rand Institute for Civil Justice found that a nationwide auto choice program could reduce the average automobile liability insurance premium by 28 percent, for a saving of $221 a car.
The first two years of Mr. Dole's tax-cut plan would save Americans an estimated $70 billion; the auto choice program could be worth as much as $80 billion in the same period.
"Think of us as alchemists," said Michael Horowitz, a legal scholar at the Hudson Institute in Indianapolis, who, with Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School, persuaded Mr. Dole to propose the radical change. "We're transforming dry legal reforms into a consumer cause -- broccoli into ice cream."
That's not the way opponents see it. Indeed, for all its apparent populist appeal, auto choice would not be an easy political sell. Trial lawyers, who would be cut out of the loop in a system that left little to fight about in court, are bitterly opposed.
"The so-called auto choice plan offers a phony choice," Howard Twiggs, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said. "The high cost of buying extra insurance to maintain your constitutional right to the courthouse would mean choice is of, by, and for the insurance industry, not the people."
Under current state laws, drivers buy insurance against their own negligence. If a motorist runs a stop light and injures someone in another car, he can generally count on being sued, leaving his insurer to either settle the claim or fight the case in court on his behalf.
Auto choice is somewhat different from current "no fault" insurance, which many states, including New York, rely on for minor damages.
With no fault, a driver's insurer pays out-of-pocket costs related to his injuries unless they exceed a certain expense threshold. This sometimes has the effect of giving injured parties an incentive to exaggerate damages to go to court. When Massachusetts raised the threshold from $500 to $2,000 in medical costs in 1988, for instance, the number of doctor's visits for the typical injury claim jumped from 13 to 30.
Nationwide, insurance premiums for bodily injury rose by 150 percent during the 1980's, the Rand Institute said, even as accident rates declined and insurance industry profits stagnated. One particularly unwelcome result was a rise in law-breaking: in California, about a quarter of all drivers are uninsured, largely because they cannot afford coverage.
Auto choice attacks the insurance cost problem by giving drivers the option of buying no-frills, loophole-resistant no-fault coverage.
Those willing to give up compensation for pain and suffering in all but the most extreme cases of negligence could buy "personal injury protection" from their insurers, which would compensate them for tangible losses even in one-car accidents.
Anyone who preferred the current approach could keep buying insurance against both economic losses and pain and suffering. In those cases, the current legal system would apply, but pain and suffering payments would come from one's own insurer rather than from the insurer representing the driver who caused the injury.
City dwellers would be the biggest beneficiaries of the new approach, a point not lost on the Dole campaign, which would like to broaden its voter base beyond traditional Republican suburban and rural strongholds. The Joint Economic Committee of Congress puts the potential average saving for New Yorkers who insured only against economic losses at $393, or 35 percent of the bodily injury part of their premiums.
"Auto choice would help low-income drivers in the inner city who often have to pay higher premiums," said Dennis Shea, a policy aide to Mr. Dole.
Any auto-choice plan faces a steep climb in Congress. Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York are both supporters, which might make other Democrats more receptive to a proposal lodged in a Republican campaign document. But it would take a strong coalition to overcome the opposition of the trial-lawyer lobby; insurers, for all the presumed benefits they might receive, are ambivalent about the idea.
Insurers fear that accident victims who failed to buy the optional pain and suffering coverage might not be satisfied with their compensation, retaliating by filing lawsuits blaming their insurance agents for steering them in the wrong direction.
More important, supporters will not get help from consumer organizations, which largely supported no-fault auto insurance in the 1970's but have since drifted into opposition. Consumers Union fought a similar, but much tougher, initiative on the California ballot in March, arguing that it would deny injury victims their day in court.
And Public Citizen, Ralph Nader's group, is adamantly opposed, in part because it could pre-empt some state laws and might let some dangerous drivers escape the consequences of their actions. "Personal responsibility and states' rights are the first casualties of the plan," Joseph Belluck, a lawyer at Public Citizen in Washington, argued.
In the end, the issue boils down to a matter of who will get the lion's share of the dollars that course through the insurance and legal systems. "So much money that goes to legal expense and fraud," said Andrew Tobias, a financial writer who has campaigned for changes in the tort system, "could stay in victims' and consumers' pockets instead."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 20, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article in Business Day on Aug. 8 about a proposal by Bob Dole to change the nation's automobile insurance system referred incorrectly to the stance of the Consumers Union. The organization has not adopted a position on Mr. Dole's plan to give car owners the option of buying less expensive injury coverage solely for medical bills and lost wages. The Consumers Union opposed a related California state initiative, which would have limited the right of the injured to go to court.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
New Life for a New Jersey Development

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A housing development that was begun on the site of a former quarry in West Orange, N.J., in the 1980's and later abandoned is being revived by new owners, but at a much smaller scale.
A hundred single-family condominium town houses are to rise on the site along Eagle Rock Avenue in this township in suburban Essex County. The new project replaces the original plan for two additional midrise structures with 281 apartments as well as 48 town houses. The original development had been halted after completion of a single eight-story condominium with 179 apartments. 
The new development, called the Villas at Crown View, has all its local approvals and most of its state approvals in place and is expected to be under construction by the end of the year, said Marshall Tycher, president of the Roseland Property Company of Roseland, N.J. Mr. Tycher's company is developing the $27.5 million project using its own equity and that of its partner, BNE Associates of Livingston, N.J.
Roseland is to close on the purchase of the undeveloped site, for which it will pay between $2.5 million and $3 million, when construction begins. The seller is the Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan, a subsidiary of HSBC Holdings Inc. The bank took over the property, including the existing building, known as Crown View Manor, when the former developer went bankrupt several years ago. Since then the building has been completed and its apartments have been sold. But the undeveloped 34 acres of the 42-acre rocky tract, framed by a ridge climbing to 140 feet, has sat idle.
The site was part of the 60-acre Orange Quarry that for most of this century was mined for bluestone that was used for highway construction in the area. It closed in 1983.
Today West Orange, like other North Jersey communities, is seeing stagnant projects revive and new ones advance, underscoring the state's improving housing market. Often, the projects here, as elsewhere, are being scaled back, a response to the market and economic realities of the 1990's and communities' desires for lower-density development.
In the case of the Villas at Crown View, Mr. Tycher of Roseland said his company had scaled back the project for several reasons. Among them are that it felt town houses would be easier to sell in today's market, the township and existing residents would be supportive of a smaller project and the bank adjusted the purchase price of the land to reflect the lower density.
Nonetheless, Roseland spent the last year and a half negotiating with the township and the condominium board over how the project should proceed. Philip D. Neuer, a board member at the Crown View Manor I Condominium Association and a three-year resident, said homeowners wanted to insure that any new plan be for a quality development that was of an appropriate scale and provided open space.
To that end, Roseland lowered the number of units from 180 to 100 before an agreement was struck.
The new town houses will belong to a homeowners association, separate from that of the existing building. But both will be part of a joint association that manages common areas shared by the two communities, including the entrance drive, gatehouse and a five-acre lake on the site. Roseland has agreed to develop a walking path around the lake.
Susan Borg, planning director for West Orange, said that the original plan was something of an anomaly, adding that the revived project "is more in keeping with the character of West Orange."
The project is proceeding as the market for town houses in the West Orange area is strong, especially among empty-nest couples, said Richard DePiro, branch manager at the Caldwell-West Orange office of Weichert Realtors. The sales pace has increased and prices are slowly rebounding, he added, noting that town houses priced $200,000 or more are doing well.
The average price of the 39 town houses sold in West Orange from January through June was $215,000, up from an average of $199,250 for the 30 units sold in the similar period last year. Most of the sales this year, 28, were over $200,000, according to data from the Garden State Multiple Listing Service and the Suburban Essex Multiple Listing Service. The service recorded the average price of $205,500 for the 29 town houses sold in the western Essex County communities surrounding West Orange. The two- and three-level brick-faced town houses will be situated south and east of the existing building in a saucer-like valley at the base of the cliff. They will range in size from 1,900 to 2,350 square feet and in price from $247,000 to $300,000. All have two or three bedrooms, with the master bedroom on the first level in some models. They will also have two-car garages and about half will have basements.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher Against Yen; Pound Stages a Broad Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday for a third consecutive day on expectations that Japanese interest rates would remain low, but it mostly weakened against European currencies.
Traders said the market was more focused on the probability of rising interest rates in Britain, which incited a broad rally in the pound, and resilient doubts about the prospect for a single European currency by the end of the decade, which helped strengthen the mark. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 108.24 yen, up from 107.90 yen on Wednesday. The dollar traded at 1.4842 marks, down from 1.4848. The British pound rose to $1.5490 from $1.5430.
The yen's weakness was a spillover from statements by senior Japanese monetary officials on Wednesday that interest rates in Japan would stay low for the time being.
The remarks quelled speculation that the Bank of Japan might start raising rates as the economy shows more signs of strengthening.
The dollar rallied briefly in early European dealings on an unfounded rumor that Swiss National Bank might lower interest rates to suppress a rise in the Swiss franc.
Switzerland's central bank has said it believes the franc is overvalued, but when it took no action "the dollar came back down," said Frank Conte, chief trader at the Royal Bank of Canada. It ended marginally higher against the Swiss franc.
Traders said the big surprise in Europe was strength in the pound, whose broad gains were based on a Bank of England quarterly report that urged an increase in interest rates in order to forestall higher inflation. The news caught the market off guard because Britain's economy is not particularly strong, and rates were cut only last month.
"All of a sudden, people are starting to think about a rate hike out of the U.K. before year-end," said Bob Near, a vice president at the Bank of New York.
The mark's strength was a carry over from Wednesday, when traders sold other European currencies, particularly the French franc, on fears that France would not meet the strict criteria required for a single European currency by the 1999 target date. The mark, the dominant currency in Europe, tends to benefit from any skepticism about European monetary union.
